RATING: 4
130929  Yeah its just too long.  I don't think I will ever play this again.  Pax has everything I want in a game of this type.  And its more thematic to boot.  I just hate the fact that you need to know the deck to play TTR well.

121231 I learned this one day and then Pax Porfiana the next.  I wasn't really that taken with TTA anyways, but Pax just killed it.  I see why TTA is regarded so highly, its a very nice design (albeit physically slightly fiddly).  But not a game I enjoy playing.  If/when I procure a copy of Pax I'd most likely drop this game to a 2 rating.

Aside from personal preference critique, I have to say that I do not like the enclosed playing space of TTA.  All the age cards show up and that creates a closed ecosystem which makes for predictable game playing for those who enjoying honing their skill.  However, I much prefer the partial deck usage of Pax.  It creates an open game history which feels truly thematic.

That said, it is a nice implementation of Sid Meier's Civilization without a map.  I can't imagine that the actually branded Sid Meier Civilization is nearly this good (only read the rules to that game)

RATING: 6
Would like to try.. Love the Civ-like theme, but the game seems very fiddly and really ugly, so I'm not too excited..

***

Took me ages before I finally got to try this one.. It also took us ages (4 hours) to finish our 3-player game.

My first impression is really torn. I love Civ and this does give me some of that good old Civ-feeling. At the same time it gives me a lot of the micromanagement and tedious bookkeeping I really don't care for. The mechanics are pretty ingenious, but overall the fiddliness bothers me. I understand the elegant abstraction of the design, but I do miss a map.. When I think of a Civilization game, I'm thinking of something beefier than a glorified card game. I also have a problem with the butt-ugly art and graphic design. The main thing - the progress through the ages - flows quite beautifully, though.. although it does take it's time!

So.. I love parts of it, but for my taste it's too ugly, too fiddly and plain too long, and I don't see myself playing it very often.. This knocks points off the design, that is otherwise pretty impressive. I'll settle for a 7. Also, it's definitely too pricey for what you get. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
An interesting and sweeping epic game without the epic gameplay time (some might disagree with that). Each game tells a story, the game mechanics are interesting and keep things moving at a brisk pace, and the decisions that are balanced against each other are difficult and challenging. I've enjoyed every playing of this, win or lose... even when misinterpreting rules.

Speaking of rules, my one criticism of this game is the manner in which the rules are presented. Finding answers to questions that arise during the game is quite difficult due to not knowing the section of the rules (basic, intermediate, or advanced rules) to peruse. It's very frustrating.

RATING: 7
Normally you have boardgames with supporting card usage, and this game works the other way around. Many Cards and an oversized board which is just used as a scoretrack. The core mechanics are quite similar to Origins - How we became humans, where each wood marker can be used for different purposes. It is shorter than other civilization-games but it also lacks the epic feeling of other games which take up to 12h.

But I still haven't played it with more then 2 players. Lets hope I will have a chance to try.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Tengo sentimientos muy opuestos de amor-odio con este juego xD
Tras ya varias partidas, por ahora me gusta pero me ha decepcionado bastante, ya que después de todo lo positivo que tiene, tiene algunas cartas muy desproporcionadas. Y que esté tan desequilibrado a lo militar, no me gusta, sobretodo a 2 jugadores, donde la estrategia militar es casi la única a seguir (probarlo a 2 con la variante "pacífica"), y también cierto azar que tiene el juego, interesante de base, pero exagerado como consecuencia de estas cartas desproporcionadas (OP)  sobretodo de guerras y algunos líderes) lo transforman en un intento de gran juego sin llegar a conseguirlo 100%. Que salga ese líder o guerra en el momento justo, y sobretodo, que te salga a tí o al enemigo por puro azar, o una guerra que le quita al más débil tropecientosmil puntos, para dárselos a quien gana... etc, y cebarse siempre con el más débil, lo convierte en un juego difícil de digerir después de muchas horas de dura gestión. A parte de ser un juego muy abstracto, que no tengo problema con eso al respecto, pero en consecuencia tardas en pillarle el rollo al no ser en principio lo lógico o intuitivo lo mejor.
Habrá quien le guste, pero "currartelo" tanto, y durante varias horas en un juego muy muy largo,(yo lo estoy jugando casi exclusivamente online, por su duración) para que al final esos detalles descompensados y azarosos decidan, pues a mi me decepciona mucho, sobretodo el azar de los eventos finales. Quiero probar otras variantes, sin guerras o pacíficas a ver... Vlaada, que lo considero gran autor, y con juegos con grandísimas ideas, a mi me da la sensación que no termina de redondear sus juegos, ni de equilibrarlos, y siempre acaban teniendo algún defecto importante... (El Dungeon Lords y Galaxy Trucker acabaron saliendo de mi ludoteca). Será su estilo pero a mi no me termina de gustar, y me da la sensación de muy poco testeo... aunque em realidad no sea así.
Que rabia, con lo que podría haber sido este juego... Por el concepto, me parece un grandísimo juego en sí (sin hablar de las ediciones ni componentes), pero por todo lo dicho, ni de lejos un rank 2 de la BGG... 

Otra cosa:
Tema vs. jugabilidad: Lo ideal es un equilibrio siempre en los juegos, pero si hay que disminuir uno para mejorar otro, opino que siempre se debería mejorar la jugabilidad, es un juego, no una novela.
Muchos justifican en este juego el desbalanceo militar, porque es como han dominado las civilizaciones siempre. Bueno, pues que casi no sepas escribir y que tengas un gran ejército del medievo que pueda arrasar tu civilización del siglo XX que dispone de misiles, temático no es la palabra! xD Que esto esté justificado por la jugabilidad, estaría bien, pero tampoco es el caso, ya que los puntos de cultura/victoria, no represantarían para nada lo avanzada que está la civilización, y más cuando de esta forma puedes intercambiar muchísimos con una de las guerras. En fin que es muy abstracto y nada temático, para cumplir más con la jugabilidad.


Descripción/opinión inicial:
Si el juego de PC Civilization de Sid Meier estuviera hecho juego de cartas, sería muy similar a éste. Tiene 3 modos de juego: Básico, Avanzado y Completo. Cada uno más completo y más largo, que de por si el juego ya lo es, pero a quien le guste la gestión a tope y sensación de construcción y desarrollo, le va a encantar, aunque se puede hacer bastante tediosa toda la gestión, y eterna la partida dependiendo mucho de los gustos del jugador. 
Tres años esperando edición en castellano, y de componentes... la edición es carísima y muy cutre! Lo de las minipirámides es que es imperdonable, a la mínima se te mueve todo... ¬¬ Son demasiado pequeñas las casillas de puntuaciones, el diseño del tablero en inglés está mejor. He usado piedras transparentes para marcadores de felicidad, y si puedo haré sustitutos para el resto. Las ilustraciones, son horribles, cualquier ilustrador novel las haría mejor. Solo hay que ver fotos en BGG. El manual está mal estructurado, no te esperas que te cuenten las reglas "asi". El resto puede pasar, incluso me gustan los cubos de plástico de colorines. Pero en general, es de los peores juegos calidad-precio que tengo en cuanto a diseño-componentes, pareciendo por dentro un prototipo apenas adornado.
El juego en sí es una pasada, sólo tiene un "fallo" gordo, muy muy largo... casi estuvimos 8h una 1a partida a 3 con novatos entre explicación mucho AP, etc... En fin, para auténticos fans de los civi y con mucha mucha paciencia...

Vendido, ya que es mucho más corto y funciona mejor online que en mesa.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
but how often do I have that much time
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
To anyone reading this, heed my advice:
Make sure you have no other appointments the same day, bring a lunch box along, turn off your cell phone and enjoy the game.

I like this a lot. A long but rewarding game that keeps you in its grip. At the first play you can't have a decent strategy (don't even try to have one), because there are just too many cards to learn. But you'll do better next time, when you know what to aim at. 

There is a constant shortage of resources which forces players to make important decisions all the time. You cannot accomplish everything and hence you need a strategy. It is really rewarding to see your plan come into reality. The balance between longer term strategic and short term tactical decisions is spot on.

A few of things to whine about: 
First one is the fiddliness. The pieces are ridiculously small for anyone to handle comfortably. 

The second one is the counter intuitive corruption mechanism. It is an integral part of the game and it has to be there. However, now a big part of your game is actually about managing those blue production tokens so that you have precisely the number that does not trigger higher corruption. This forces you to focus on big productivity leaps instead of grinding your way there gradually. Yes, it is the nature of the game, but in my opinion it takes too much energy in a game that should not be about micromanaging. 

The third one is about the game length with four. Ideally more players should introduce more interaction and thus add to the excitement. This might happen but at the same time downtime increases drastically, and so does the game length. 

Verdict:
Absolutely one of the best games, but only with three players. In the end, I decided to sell the game. This just never hits the table because "it's too heavy", "I have to take the dog for a walk", "I have to blahh blahh". You get the point. TtA is a total pain to teach as well. Hence, as a part of the process of ridding me of unnecessary fire load TtA had to find a new caring home. I am going to miss you baby. Hope to see you sometime.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.2
I like the game, very good theme implementation.
Some of the mechanics take a while to get, and you definitely need an idea on what's in the game in total, to play even moderately successful. So consider your first game an intro, and nothing more.
I think the game is quite brutal in punishing even small development inefficencies, so it might not work well to play with different levels of skill. I seldom got so frustrated in a game about getting so blasted away after seemingly doing good just three round before.
Probably a bit like chess - a better opponent will always win clearly, as errors add up exponentially.
Still, I want to try again.

RATING: 10
Currently my favourite game of all, this has stood up to many repeated plays and I still haven't got my head around ideal play in different situations; the theme is perfect for me, streamlined civilization building without all the assymettry of a map that tends to create unbalanced games. the cards feel perfectly balanced, highlighted by different groups thinking different cards are broken, they rarely are they are just all situational.

Played with a fast group of two to three players this is a perfect game, I don't particularly like 4 player games as they seem to drag a bit too much.

More thoughts in:
http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/614055/new-voices-civilization-a-story-of-through-the-ages

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Wow.  Just a great, [i]great[/i] civ game.  I really enjoyed playing this one and I'm definitely looking to pick it up when the next print run comes out.

The random element is in the card draw.  Works very well, though, since the cards are separated into five ages.  The card powers and strength directly correlate with the advancement of the game (the current age), providing an excellent development mechanism.  I also like using the cards as the clock.

Takes a while to play, but entirely worth it.  For game length alone, I do not recommend playing with 4 players unless they're all experienced with the game.

The 3-player (2 newbs, 1 teacher) learning game I played took around 6-7 hours.  The 4-player (3 experienced & me) took about 5 hours.  Like I say above, 4-player isn't horrible if the players are experienced and really try to keep it moving.

Rated a 9 instead of 10 simply because game length, and length of a teaching game (which can be considerable), will often preclude plays for me.  Yes, that's largely due to the wonderfully implemented complexity, but it's enough for me to drop my rating a notch.  If there were a way to bring it out more often and get more plays in, it would rate a 10.

And yes, I know there's the shorter beginner game, but I really enjoy the complexity and choices of the longer non-beginner (advanced?) game.  The duration isn't a minus for the game itself per se, I'm more annoyed that the game length will prevent me from getting many plays in.

If you have any interest in deep games that enable long-term strategies with *tons* of choices, try this one.  You won't be disappointed (unless you are).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

There's just too much fiddliness here for the luck.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
We played a couple of turns of the simple game.  I think the rules are somewhat elegant and clever, love the idea of building a civilization, and like that it is a card game.  "Seeding" events seems fun, and rumor has it the 2-player advanced game can be done in under two hours once you know what you're doing.

UPDATE:  After one advanced game, I'm calling this a seriously good game.  It's long, but I don't know how that can be avoided.  The mechanics work, it's not too annoying to keep track of things, and it moves along.  Yes, you can take a break during your opponent's turn.  It's good enough to make me want a full game next time (Mrs. alexd trounced me by clever military among other things).

Ok, the full game is even better, though it pretty much adds an hour and a half, at least at first.

Seems like playing an age an evening for a few days might be the way to go -- take a break, ponder your progress, mull over the layout over breakfast...

Ok, the full game is fantastic, AFTER Age I.   Playing less than the full game seems like a foolish waste of time -- the overhead for the good part is too high.

UPDATE:  Ok, so.  In theory there's a lot to like here.  In practice, 2p, between making mistakes in resource management/cardplay if you're trying to play at a reasonable pace but make time for thinking, the game ends up taking FOREVER and having a disturbing "some mistake was made" feeling that isn't there in most things I like.  I love the idea here, in some ways, but the actual game isn't as great, after more plays, as I thought.  Perhaps... if the leaders were more balanced?  If there were more interesting eventful turns rather than slow runups to the occasional war?  It's not REALLY a 10, in some ways (well it may be when it's firing on all cylinders, but that often fails to happen, and it sure takes a long time for it), but... eh, at its best its great.  Just a warning -- it's not perfect.  Is it infinitely more fun and cooler than Agricola?  OH YEAH
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
:cry: :) :D :) This is a perfectly serviceable and well-made ultra-long game. It didn't amaze me the way my top three ultra-long games (18xx, Twilight Struggle, Maria) do. But it's a LOT more fun than some things I've played of roughly equal length. It's got a bit too much direct confrontation via military actions to ever really be a favorite, but I'd at least be willing to try this one again (we played the Advanced game with just two ages and honestly if one player was not taking forever and a day on her turns, it might have gone over better with me). The down side is we had a runaway leader problem although he was a much more advanced player than the rest of us (two newbies and one guy who said he's not very good at it); however I found it nearly impossible to get culture, which is VP, and advancing culture advances your VP increase every round. Our runaway leader had a "leader" card which gave him a colony bonus, and a military nobody could assail (by the time you got your military up to his, he built even further so you could just never attack him on your next turn). Twiddling everything every round was annoying (also the "leader" kept moving the wrong pieces; the board is AWFUL for scoring/tracking purposes -- it's straightforward but it's too small and too easy to screw up things that are changing constantly -- having the levels of stuff on your OWN board AND the main board, while redundant, would be my recommendation) And it's basically a tableau builder, which is something I don't mind. The resource mechanic is very, very good in the game... very economical and clever. But, once again, I played a top ten BGG game and found myself asking, "that's what people find so amazing?" I mean, it was adequate and I can't think of anything downright terrible about it, but my socks weren't exactly knocked off. 

Second impression knocked it back to a 5; I'll play, but the military stuff makes it into "bash the loser" so if you fall behind you will just get utterly pummeled and continue to fall further behind. And that's really, REALLY stupid for a four hour game (the Full Game rules must recognize this, as resigning is a legal move!). You're basically forced to play a certain way, which sucks out a lot of the fun. Especially since the rest of the game is very good; if military aggressions and wars were waged against some unseen enemy, rather than other players, I'd feel a lot better about this game.

Third impression after lots of plays gets it to a 6. I'll play it but mostly because I'm stubbornly trying to "get it" rather than because I love it. Once you start having a clue what to do it becomes less painful but this is a game you have to really stick with to come to appreciate, and the online version helps a ton with that. I'll never LOVE the take-that, bash-the-weak mechanics, but I at least got decent enough to no longer find them completely crippling.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.9
A fun game where you actually go from the days of Caesar all the way to Jet Fighters and Tanks.  I really enjoy this game, but the play strongly depends on who you are playing with.  The rules are fiddly on a lot of aspects with some detail rules that are easy to look over and can frustrate players who haven't memorized them.  Also, this game really suffers from AP players.  You start with 4 actions per turn, which can turn into 10 actions per turn by the end of the game, and you are flooded with choices (which I like for me, but dislike for AP players).  The only luck is the card draw, but it affects all players pretty equally.  Combat is resolved by #military units and formations (with a couple minor card bonuses), and no dice are rolled the entire game.  (not sure if that is good or bad :) )

RATING: 10
2-4(3)

I'm going to bump this to 10. I just keep wanting to play it.

---------------------------------------------------------

I've gotten this and played it (2p) a couple of times. We jumped straight into the Full game. I don't understand why anybody would start with the Simple game, as I feel the experience would muddy the waters for the Full game, and a LOT of what makes this game phenomenal comes out in the Full game. The rule book is a little bit too constrained in trying to force you into the Simple->Advanced->Full game progression, which made it REALLY difficult to just jump into a full game. I've tended to notice this about Vlaada's games: the rules hold your hand through learning the game (in some "training wheel" sort of way), but they subsequently are very poor as a reference for more experienced players or fuller versions of the game (Space Alert and Galaxy Trucker are both like this). Rules summaries here helped immensely.

ANYWAY, there are a lot of (really small) bits and you spend much of the game shuffling them about, but it does feel like a really rich thematic experience, with different ways to advance yourself and win. Yeah, a lot of the cards seem really weak compared to others, but there are a lot of interesting things to do. Military is brutal (of course), but still nicely favors the defender. I'm not sure if the Age IV business is necessary (maybe we played it wrong) but it made the game feel a bit overlong without much going on (as in, we both had way more actions than we felt we needed). It's definitely long, and some games can certainly feel like big runaways, but otherwise, it's a marvelous experience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
First the downsides. The designers clearly gave zero effort to the game's art. Basically all the components look terrible. Gameplay-wise, some of the mechanics (particularly growth, happiness, and corruption) are a bit of a pain to keep track of. 

However, this is a wonderful empire building game, allowing you to make many interesting choices to assemble a flourishing society. The game offers many different ways to interact with your competitors (by competing for cards, by invasion, most prominently), and there are multiple viable paths to victory. I would say that focusing on military is a little bit too effective in this version.

RATING: 8
The only negative is that the game takes over an hour per player and that it is a bit fiddly. (I dont have a problem with long fiddly games as long the gameplay worths the hustle and this one certaintly does) So, you need to find the right group of players. The game offers a wide selection of choices. There are a lot of things going on, many paths to follow. I like the feeling that you start with almost nothing and you have to build up a real economy and increase your cultural and science payout while you must keep the people happy and the corruption down. There is also the military aspect that makes the game much more interactive with the various aggression and war cards. 
Its a very well designed civilization board game. Excellent game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Part of me wants this game to be shorter so that it can make it to the table more often. But part of me knows that that's what makes this game so cool; it's an experience. This IS Civilization (the computer game) in a board game. You WILL forget that there is no map.

Update:
I LOVE this game! Changed it to a 10... The only ten I have. It's long. If you can't handle a long game, then stay away. But if, for any reason you think you can get at least one other person to invest the time with you on the game, you will not be dissapointed.

Second update:
I have never played a game with this much depth. I've played maybe 20 games now (on boardgaming-online.com), and still come back for more. Now if only I could figure out how to win more than 10% of the games I play... Eesh

Final Update: I've traded the game away. I loved this game, but darn it, it took too long to play. I will not change my 10 rating, because I think the game deserves it. It's just a matter of me never having enough time to finish the game. I'll still play it online.

Second Final Update (Just go with it): I have played Sid Meier's Civilization the Board Game... I am impressed. It has made me reconsider my rating of Through the Ages. I had more fun with Civ, however, it was only one game, so I'm going to be adjusting the two scores as I get more plays of Civ. But as it stands right now, Civ might knock TtA down a bit. 

I think it comes down to play time and that, in spite of my appreciation for the elegance of TtA, I think Civ appeals to my visual/spatial tendencies more, what with the map and all. Darn I like that map. We shall see.

Uno de los mejores juegos de civilizaciones que existen.

En él todo está perfectamente pensado y encaja a la perfección. Todo tiene un sentido y funciona como un reloj suizo. La sensación de evolución y mejora es constante y siempre hay múltiples vias de progresar, tanto si quieres ser pacífico, como si deseas guerrear continuamente. Eso sí, no es un juego fácil, es exigente neuronalmente. Simplemente excelente.

Por poner una pega, para ser un juego de civilizaciones es algo abstracto al no tener un tablero con un mapa, pero es que realmente no es necesario y la sensación es la misma abstrayéndolo todo mediante cartas.

Vendido para adquirir la última versión mejorada y en castellano.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Rating based on one play.  Advanced game.

I bought this a while ago and I've been waiting to get a chance to try it with two other civ-minded friends.  In the end I was underwhelmed.  It's nicely designed but it's a lot of time and work moving tokens around for the payoff.  It felt like there were shorter, more streamlined games that offered the same thing in the end.

There also wasn't very much player interaction, and I felt I could just as easily have spent the hours moving cards around by myself.  To be fair, none of us tried to build more military than the others and attack -- until the final rounds -- so that made it more solitary than normal.

I'd give it another try.  It would probably improve with some familiarity.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
This game is okay.  I think it's a little over-hyped, honestly, but it's not terrible by any means.

The primary problems with it have been listed by others- mainly that there is SO much downtime, and that once you're down, you're out.  If a person doesn't build his military to something respectable, he doesn't stand a chance.  And once you're at that point, you CAN'T get back into the game.  That's worse than being eliminated- stuck playing a game for another 3 hours where you have 0 chance to affect the outcome, or even do anything on your turns.  Yay.  It didn't get that bad for our game- but I could easily see that being the case.  And I had to refrain from attacking the player just so it WASN'T the case- he had no way to stop me, and I had the cards and military to successfully screw him over every turn.  

I'll play it if others want to, but I can't see getting excited about it.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Very intriguing. After 1st play, I immediately wanted to play again. And that's to say something of a game that took almost 8 hours (4 player - longer than I anticipated), and the time being around 2:30 am.

(2nd play - 6 hours, 3 players)

The rules are longish, but the main mechanics very logical once you get into the game. You soon stop to worry about rules, and start to worry about your strategy (except for certain card combinations where you need to consult rules and/or FAQ).

There's a lot going on, and a lot of variables to factor into your game plan. Aggression and events take a bigger role than I anticipated from reading the rules alone.
While in theory each player plays on his own, with an occasional conflict (and snatching cards away from other players), the game feels much more interactive in reality.

It's also one of those games where you need one play to get a feel for the flow, because you'll need different amounts of food/resources/science/happiness in different phases of the game.

It can be very frustrating. When you make a major blunder (almost bound to happen in the first game), you'll have your work cut out for you, just getting back on track. Especially when playing with aggressive players - as in real life, aggression breeds more aggression, and as army sizes increase, you must follow or get sucked dry by the other players.

There's some luck in card draw, otherwise, a skill game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
I can easily understand the popular complaints about OP military, card luck, play length, downtime, fiddliness, you name it.  Didn't get a real personal-ownership kind of sense of my stuff either, because there are only a few classes of card and card modifiers.  Despite all this, though, I easily love and continue to come back to the game.  With all the pieces put together, it's one of my favorite games.  There are other long games I enjoy, but none which seem to erase time like this.  I think it's worth at least a shot or three for just about any gamer.  Strongly prefer 2P to all other forms, and online for speed.

RATING: 8

RATING: N/A
4-2
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
12/2/16: Lowered this to an 7 because I've come to believe that the military really dominates this game and it must be in the forefront of your thinking.  Age III wars can really swing things.  This effect is lessened in the new version.

Think of this as a board game version of Sid Meier's Civilizaton.  I love Civilization building games, but this is not a short game, and would not appeal to everyone.  I think that 2-3 hours / player is typical when learning this game.  Played recently against someone using a military strategy, and the game is very fragile when defending against a military strategy.  You fall behind and you're toast.

I have the Czech edition.  The glass beads are cool, but hard to move, and I think that the cards are better in the FRED edition.  If you can get the Essen cubes for the Czech edition that's definitely the way to go.

3 players is definitely the sweet spot.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fantastic civilization building game. Despite its length, it plays differently every game, requires EVERY choice to be deliberately thought out, and offers enough of a varied experience that no two games feel alike. 

Another benefit is that you must grapple with the situation of the game's technology cards; you aren't guaranteed to get all the cards you need to build your civilization. It rewards adapting as well as advancing. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The best translation into a boardgame of the kind of mechanics that I really enjoy in the civilization computer games. Lots of good ideas to streamline resource management, but it's still a fairly long game, and probably too long with 4 players.

I should add that the rating is based on a limited number of plays where the predominant strategy was warm, lovey, peaceful sweet feelings towards everyone else. Not so sure how I would enjoy it when the fundamental strategy is cutthroat, no holds barred, military build up.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is the kind of game where you think about how you are going to play the next time. Very random thanks to the cards, so every game wont play the same. Very fiddly with small components and it is very easy to make mistakes all the time. Quite abstract for new players while it all makes sense once you get it and the mechanics are really clever. Lots of dead time, it takes a lot of time to play on 4 players. Some of the leaders can give a player large point bonuses every round, making it very hard to catch up. The luck of the card draws can have a huge impact on the game, which I don't think goes well with such a long game. It's an excelent 2 player game, full game on 2 takes 3 hours but you don't have to wait so much.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game was really really hard for me to rate. It's really good, and really elegant. It's near perfect in translating the Civ series computer games to a board game, and yet therein lies its fatal flaw.

I just don't see myself ever wanting to play it for these reasons: 
1) It's so long, and it would speed up the more you play but there's little chance you'll get to play it enough with the same group to make that happen

2) It's so fiddly...I generally have only had a "fiddly" problem with one other game so far - Antiquity but this is fiddly in a different way. Rather than just tons of very tiny bits to add and remove and track here there's so many different things to track and keep track of that it's very easy to cheat either on purpose or accidentally. I guess it's like that time I tried to play Arkham Horror with about 4 expansions - just too much to track...this is definitely something that PCs were made for. Tracking everything properly so you get it right turn after turn.

...and there's the rub...

For me if I wanted to play this I'd just play Civ 3, 4 or 5 on the PC and convince my friends to try play that. As complex as this game is it's still not as complex as the PC version (because it really can't be)...finally the PC experience also allows to play by mail over time that a board game has a much harder time to facilitate.

So do I rate it by how much I like it? Which is probably between an 8 and a 9, or how much I want to play it and - for me - how little of a space I feel it adequately fills in my gaming repertoire? Which is probably between a 3 and a 4. In the end I guess I'll pace it somewhere in the middle

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Un 10 en la BGG supone querer jugarlo siempre... Pues eso es el Tta.
Me chiflan las mecánicas de la población relacionada con la comida y con el handicap de la felicidad. Me chiflan los recursos relacionados con las minas, y su vez con la corrupción. Estos dos circulos que producen dolores de cabeza pero que si los controlas como es debido da placer ver cómo te permite avanzar en otras esferas del juego. El mecanismo de la ciencia es perfecto. Tan sencillo y a la vez tan complejo. Todo está interrelacionado.
Me tiene enamorado que cada carta esté pensada y que tengas un montón de estrategias según cuál escojas. Las maravillas son simplemente geniales. Los líderes lo mismo.
La mecánica militar, el esfuerzo que se debe hacer para que funcione correctamente y ver cómo puedes atacar a tus "enemigos" me parece simplemente brillante. Y el hecho de que lo militar no prime sobre lo demás, y cómo está conseguido ésto, me parece la reordiga.

Tengo ganas de seguir aprendiendo en cada partida, el juego tiene tantísimo recorrido que me encanta sentarme y probar por dónde va a discurrir la partida. Todo me parece elegante. Nada es forzado. Todo tiene lógica.

No encuentro mejor manera de estar una tarde con amigos que jugando un Tta. Eso es un 10: querer jugarlo siempre. Pensar en él y decir "bien, me encantaría ir a lo militar. Si esta vez logro hacerme con el control del juego voy a salirme con mis teatros o con mis laboratorios, o mis avances tecnológicos...".

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Yet another good game by the great Vlaada. I really liked this one, although the huge amount of options you tend to have each turn make for a very AP-prone experience, sadly.

If this was a more streamlined game, it would surely rank much higher for me. As it is, it's a game I enjoy, but one I just couldn't play anytime... I would have to have a lot of available time, and not the urge to play anything else that session.

UPDATE: With the new version out, it's rare that I would prefer to play this older, less streamlined version. Still a well designed game, but pales in comparison to the newer, and cheaper version.

RATING: 8
Simple Game felt way too short to accomplish anything, despite it taking 3 hours for reading/understanding rules + setup + first play. Hopefully the Advanced Game will be more satisfying but not take considerably longer (now that we're familiar with the rules)

Advanced Game was great, I liked the "goals" to shoot for, and it extended the game without making it too long.

Full Game was not too great. I didn't feel like the Age III cards added that much besides just more of the same (plus bonuses, bonuses, bonuses) and it took MUCH longer to play (about 50%).

All in all, I still love the game, but I think I'll be mostly sticking to the Advanced Game until I'm familiar enough for it to play faster.

RATING: 8
Fantastic game (most of my plays are against friends but online)

the start of the game feels wonderfully wide open with so many possibilities.  The mid-game feels tight and tense.  The end game a desperate grab for whatever you can get (as long as you haven't been obliterated by another player's army)

It's a game that feels remarkably close to the computer civs even without the map.  The downside is of course the playtime (which is why I generally play online).  Most people say that face-to-face games should be 2 or 3 players only, which sounds right to me.

A game that deserves its stellar reputation.

RATING: 9.9
Barely played it so far face to face, but I love this game and play it online a lot. Would be a 10 but the potential for incredibly lame endgame scenarios involving wars and the metagame of whether players will resign or not means this one doesn't quite acheive perfection. It would be a 10 if I could magically make everyone agree that resignation is the right move, but some people insist on staying in the game and that has the potential for a sour ending. It would still be a very good game without resignation, too- just not quite as rich, strategically. Indeed, I think I would rate it a 10 either with resignation or without. It's purely the "will they or won't they" guess-your-opponent's-gaming-philosophy metagame aspect that is truly a big enough flaw to warrant not giving a 10.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Végre!! Szerencsére lehetőségem nyílt profi gyakorlott játékossal kipróbálni (3 személyes teljes játékot). Hatalmas élmény!

Nem ajánlott azoknak, akik nem szeretik a hosszú, és bonyolult játékokat, de ez a játék nem öncélúan hosszú és bonyolult. Ez az általam ismertek közül talán a legjobban összerakott darab. Rengeteg apró ötlet van összegyúrva benne egy nagyon bonyolult egésszé, amelyben minden mindennel összefügg, a témának (civilizáció) megfelelően. Látszik a játékba ölt komoly tervezői munka, a sok tesztelés. Nagyon alapos, minden apró részletre kitér a szabály, ráadásul 3 fokozatban is játszható a játék, külön gondolnak a kezdőkre, illetve a rövidebb játékok kedvelőire. És nem utolsósorban a kivitelezés is profi. Igényes kártyák, igényes doboz.

Hogy miért jó a játék?
Tetszik, hogy végig van egy dinamikája, nagyon jól átjön a kártyákon keresztül a fejlődés érzése. Kis túlzással kőbaltától a repülőkig fejlődhetünk... Tetszik, hogy mindennek van következménye (lásd éhezés, korrupció, felkelés...)

Szerencsefaktor alacsony. A játék közepesen nyelvfüggő.

Nem nagyon tudok belekötni. Mindenképp dobogós nálam. Szerintem akit kicsit is komolyabban érdekelnek a játékok, ezt ne hagyja ki, legalább 1 esélyt megérdemel, még akkor is, ha nem kevés idő.
---
A rengeteg eredeti ötletről nem is beszéltem. Pl. az aktuális események játékba hozásának mechanizmusát emelném ki.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Dec-20-2010
So I played the game again more and I think it is one of the best games now.  My issue before with military cards are due to my inexperience and not valuing military action cards as much as I should have.  I am still interested in splitting up the military decks to see how different the game plays out.  It doesn't mean that military is worth less, just quite the opposite.  This is one of the very few multi-faction wargame that I enjoy because it doesn't matter how often people attack me, I don't lose military strength as long as I keep up with everyone else.  This game will definitely last Through the Ages.
Rating: 7 -> 10

Sep-25-2010
So I got to play the game again today and the military card draws reared its ugly head.  Military and military cards are so important in this game that just not having the right cards can ruin you.  You cannot fall behind of military or you won't be able to get out of that hole once you start getting attacked.  Thus these military cards are very important.  Not drawing the right tactics card will cost you the game.  Not getting the events when you are ahead in military while your opponents getting them when they are in the lead is just too much for me to swallow.  This randomness in the military cards for how long the game takes is too much for me.  I proposed splitting the military card deck into 3 that contains specific kinds of cards.  This way if you need a certain military card, your chances of getting it is higher but not guaranteed.  So this tempered my desire to purchase the game.  The game is still good, but the luck to length ratio pushes me not to purchase the game.
Rating: 8 -> 7


Sep-20-2010
I got to play this game again after a long time and I enjoyed myself.  Even though the game took 4 hours to complete with 4 players, I was completely engaged and enthralled.  I didn't notice that the time has gone.  This is a very good Civ themed game.  It does a very nice job with the arcing story for the game.  I am tempted to buy a copy.
Rating: 7 -> 8

Feb-14-2009
Suppose to be a good heavy "civilization" game.  A card game to boot for compactibility.  Maybe for my 3 player Heavy game niche.  Reading further threads, I am wary that there might be too much luck in here for me for its length.  There seems to be a consensus that the game should not be played more than 3 players.  Given at the moment that I play with my wife and another couple, will make this game untouched.  Also the fact that the game is a 3 hour game.  Also, the general consensus seems to be that this game is not good with 4 players, since 90% of my gaming is 4 player.

Reading the forums here about misprints on the board, missing components and curling cards certainly makes it very hard to justify spending $70 on it.  I shall wait for the next version to purchase the game.

[b]TRY BEFORE BUY[/b] and wait for the next version.  Do not buy the 2008 version.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The millitary cards are especially random!  It's annoying when you cannot take advantage of your superior millitary simply because you fail to draw any aggression or war cards.  

Your choice of actions are heavily dependent on the card drafting queue.  Obviously you get to choose your cards, but the order the cards appear will largely determine the game.  Even so, I still overall enjoy TTA.

RATING: 7.4
All my plays online.  There is much I dislike about the game.  It is over long, over fiddly, over abstracted (everything is kind of reduced to stone cost, tech cost and production of 1 of 5 resources with very little twisting from the basic pattern.  There is a bit too much rules that could have been streamlined but where the game really struggles is in the military side of things.  This can create a situation where the rich get richer and the poor spend the last 3rd of the game doing absolutely nothing other than seeing everything they have worked on be slowly destroyed.  Some like the tension of staying ahead but I think if a game can stop being fun for a player for more than a turn or two it is a design flaw.  Also aside from that the military / event side isnt that interesting , nor is there enough reason to not just pummle the weakest nation.   However despite all these strong weaknesses there is still something very compelling here and your turns are a lot of fun.  I cannot think of a civ game I like more and with online play options the fiddle and overlong playing time are not much of a problem.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
45€
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Best game I played for a long time and probably the best Euro game in my collection. Especially astonishing are the following aspects, which I miss in nearly any other Euro:

- The theme is not pasted but tightly connected with the mechanisms and very narrative.

- A lot of player interaction, which is not only indirect (card row and events) but in many cases very direct and very harsh (war and aggression cards).

-  Since I like long games, the epic scale of the game really got me. 3-6 hours is just fine for me. Anything shorter wouldn't allow me to get into the atmospheare of a game (i.e. with shorter playing time I tend to focus on mechansims and forget about the flavor).

Got me hooked up the first time I played it and each new game grants a new challanging experience.

Be warned: Downtime can be quite long (new and or ap prone players) and there may be player elimination. Most contemporary games try and manage to avoid those concepts, this one doesn't care.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
First Play: Despite downloading and reading the rules pre-game, we spent an hour before the game just running through it.Ouch! This game is demanding both with regard to learning curve and discipline required to ensure you do things correctly and in the right order. We all made mistakes so there is a need to be extra vigilant to ensure you are all doing things properly. There is an incredible game in there meshed up in a complex mechanism, but be aware the first play must be written off as a learning experience. Be grateful to get to the end and to have mastered the nuances.

Second Play: Another long session reading and rereading the rules before attempting the full game. There are lots of little details that are very easy to miss so a few notes to one side help a great deal. Once you get into a rythmn the action flows very nicely, there's always more to do than your actions or resources allow and you do need to keep the military topped up to stop being mugged.A marathon plate spinning exercise but a very well balanced game. Definitely to be played with those of equal experience and understanding of the rules. Rating increased.

Further plays have emphasised the importance of a secure military to defend, and attack when necessary. The don't pick on me variant is recommended to stop one player getting too down trodden.

After a long pause of 8 years between games and restarting to play on line, the 'anti-down trodden' variant seems even more crucial. Without it a player can be caught in an endless loop of being milked for points and resources so when it gets to their turn they don't have the means to reinforce or do anything. End of their turn they produce ready to be harvested all over again...rinse and repeat.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
très bon jeu à 2

RATING: 8

RATING: 10
1st Edition
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.67
We played the Basic game 2 player. It was actually very simple to understand with only 2 checks of the Rulebook once we got under way. The simplicity and length of the Basic Game are it downfalls. I would have loved to play through Civil Decks II and III. The game ended right when we started getting some good buildings in play. We will try the Advanced Game in the next couple of days and I will update my rating if it changes. 

EDIT, played the Advanced game, 2 player on 6/15/17

I would rate the Advanced Game a 9.00. It is better than the Basic game simply for the fact that it is longer. You have more time to build up your empire. Scores were 188-151, by the way. No Wars or Pacts, since we were just 2. The Events deck is a whole new mechanism that I really enjoy. I like how you can seed the Future deck. We did a little bit of Aggression but not too much as our armies were pretty close in Strength the whole game. Colonies seem very powerful as I was able to get 2 extra blue and 3 extra yellow tokens with mine. Next up is Full Game over the weekend. I will update again after that.

EDIT, played Full game, 2 player, on 6/19/17

The Full Game I also rate as a 9.00. We played w/o Wars or Pacts in our game. Once you get basics down of moving Population and Resources/Food, rules are a breeze. We got into Age III fairly close together but Brian pulled away by playing a couple of early Event cards right when he got more Strength than me. Final scores were 189-147. I would only play the Full Game going forward, even teaching to new players. I am sure that I will not be playing with the War cards at any point in the future, however. They just seem to be incredibly overpowered. Aggression cards are ok though. Another to teach Flo at some point in the future as she has really taken to heavier style games recently. Keeper! 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
I like the scope of the game though I am finding it difficult to learn. Lots going on here.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
One of the best games ever made. Its not a easy game to get a feel of, opinions made of someone that played this game less than 5 times is incomplete. Its like asking someone that never learned to drive a bike how you feel about bicycling. First you need to internalize the mechanics in your brain and automate so you can focus on the strategy and start playing the game. 

There is in only one way to play, with all the rules, skip the other variants (its like playing tennis but removing the rules of serving). 

There are many interesting decisions to be made during the game, invest in infrastructure, culture or war. No option is a ever obvious since decisions you make have impact on early and late game. Knowing the cards and how they interact and makes combos will make you a better player, but sometimes being opportunistic have it rewards. All cards are not made equal, some leaders, wonders are better than others. But since the game uses a dynamic card offer that modifies the cost of cards bad cards can become god cards if you grab them in the right moment. This is a game with many layers upon layers and is always rewarding to play. Sometimes you might ask "why do I even bother playing other games when there are so few that can compare themselves with this one".

Doesn't quite scratch the Civ itch for me but starts to come close.  Looking forward to playing again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Rating this an 8 for now after 4 plays.

In my first game one player had a huge army (thanks in large part to Napoleon) which he used to bash the weakest player repeatedly.  Though I did ok that game, it seemed to me that the game became very lopsided if/when one player falls too far behind in the arms race, and the luck of the card row makes the arms race a very random thing.

But my next three games, for the most part, saw a more balanced arms race.  In one game one player fell far behind, but that was because he spent too much for a colony.  He also quit the game two turns later, which was a good thing since it did not allow the other players to take too much from him.

So I'll keep this as an 8 for now, but it could go down if it looks like the arms race is just too random.

RATING: 9
The best civilization game after Civilization, even though this is a totally different kind of civ-building game than the orginal Civilization, both are great games and to me TtA has come closest to achieving tha holy grail of civ-board games as the game that is like the original Civ but not as long. However, the downside is there is really bad run-away leader problem and no balancing for players left behind, which were very nicely taken care of in the original Civilization. TtA is also a heavy eurogame that requires a long time for rules explanation and learning. But the work needed to learn this is worth it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Rating is based on several basic game plays; one solo advanced game and one advanced game with 3 players.  I love this game.  It has everything I want in a game:

a) multiple paths to victory;
b) tough decisions every turn;
c) deep and engaging gameplay.

Unfortunately, I'm afraid it may be hard to get on the table very often because other people find it:

a) takes too long to set up;
b) fiddly;
c) takes too long to play;
d) decisions are too difficult (analysis paralysis).

*Edit, I'm really enjoying this as a two player - advanced game (not full) - takes about two hours to play with very little downtime.

RATING: 7
Marred by production issues, but absolutly brilliant. The game has deep, multilayered, strategy, while not being too intensive, its multiple game versions caters for many different people. The game suffers slightly with long-ish downtime however, but I'm struggling to find a better way to spend 3 hours.

My rating is based on the 3 player game. My rating for the 4 player game is substantially lower as it compacts upon the game's flaws (long downtime, low intereaction) while not increasing the fun of the game.

This game, for me, has lost it's shine. I'm starting to find that the game feels too similar with each play. While it's a good game that I will play again. I can't see myself playing it for a while. Thereby my former rating of 10 is no longer accurate.

See my [URL=http://boardgamegeek.com/article/2894412]review[/url] for my full thoughts.

See my [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/302035]session report[/url] for a look at my 'Experiment in Military Power'
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A watered down version of Civilizations, and therefore more time efficient

RATING: 9.6
Absolutely brilliant game. Long play time but by God its worth it. Amazingly balanced, tons of strategic options, lots of choice. Don't play with people prone to analysis paralysis - actually, DO play with them, just bring a book. It's still worth it. Fantastic with 2 or more. Will probably be one of the hardest games to teach that I own (even topping other Vlaada games like Space Alert and Dungeon Lords) but the trade off is you get a lot of strategic/tactical choices and a huge amount of control. Just the right amount of interactivity to keep you on your toes but not get too far behind. Brilliant, fantastic, wonderful.

RATING: 7.5
Great civ game which makes you feel like you're actually building a Civilization in a fraction of the time of other games with the same feel. Lot's of agonizing choices to make and lot's of ways to victory! Components could have been a bit better.

Has since been replaced by the New Story.

Gameplay: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
Replayability: :star::star::star::halfstar::nostar:
Fun/Social: :star::star::star::star::halfstar:
Components: :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar:
Rules: :star::star::star::nostar::nostar:
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Got my second game of this under my belt recently. Really liked it.

It's a bit long, so I can't say I "always want to play it" and give it a 10. So this game rates a 9 for me. But I have to dock it another half point because the four player game is excruciatingly too long. And that is slight shame. So then it's an 8.5.

I heartily recommend this game to anyone looking for a solid, meaty, civ-type game. Many have called it a Civ-lite game. I think that fits almost perfectly. I say almost because I think Civ-lite is actually an oxymoron. There can really be nothing lite about civilization as a theme, period. Civilizations are immense things and they take time to develop. Through the Ages, in comparison, only takes about 3-5 hours once you know the system. For developing a civilization, that's pretty short.

That said though Through the Ages manages to streamline its rules to the point where even though the game is taking a while to go through four whole ages of civilization, the mechanics feel straightforward and easy to understand. Once you get the hang of it, you really start to look forward to each turn as you begin to plan and scheme for how you want to develop your civilization. Some turns are quick and some take more time as you carefully organize your taken actions for maximum effect.

I really can't recommend this to anybody whose ideal game experience is 60-90 minutes of light/medium strategy. This one is a grower, not a show-er. I would heartily, recommend this to anybody as a great meaty game of civilization building that doesn't require fiddly complicated rules. If you like Euros and you like games that grow and give you room to accomplish lots of stuff in a game, and you are willing to spend 3-5 hours of fun, you simply must play this game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
Initial impression.

I would want to play again with less luck involved where possible.

It would be interesting to perhaps put military cards onto the track, two per action level (above the card deck, likely), as opposed to taking them randomly, not performing the "remove the lowest X cards" thing at the beginning of each turn.

One could then have a completely open hand, which would improve things for the mild bit of interaction that occurs between players.

Update:

I don't understand why I like this game so much.  I need to figure it out.  I do enjoy it, something about it.  Is it a similar early Agricola reaction?

Oh, and lesson learned - do not play 4 players with everyone relatively new, even "just" the advanced game.

12-26-08

After a few games, I'm starting to see what I enjoy and don't enjoy about the game.  I might like to try the non-aggression version of the game, although that hasn't been a factor in our games - there has typically been 1-2 aggressions per game.  I could see more being a frustrating experience, too much "take-that."

I'm enjoying it more and more, oddly.

The advanced game leaves one feeling empty and unfinished.  The full game is great but takes a long time.  The simple game is at least short and can leave one feeling relatively satisfied, you go through more-or-less one age, not just two, so you get a different sense of finishing.

The Full is the best, but getting people to take the time for it can be difficult to arrange.

RATING: 6
Ummm.  Why is this thing rated so high? The engine is pretty solid, but isn't really better than multiple other build up your engine euros I've played.  The only real difference is that it takes 4 hours to play, but I see no justification for that time.

Also, the graphic design/layout/terminology is fairly bad.  When to score actual civ/science or move up your civ/science + tracker is ambiguous throughout the rules and cards.  The cards are somewhat confusing.  And, the rulebook does a poor job of explaining concepts and game flow, instead just listing things as if going through a sample game, but in three different layers (simple/advanced/full)

It's not that I didn't like it, but it was too long for what it was, and I have other games that do what it is trying to do but better.

RATING: 8.5
A mix of euro and civ game mechanics that create a very good game.

The four player game's duration is a bit to much and the two player game plays very differently than multiplayer. The 2-player game also seems to have some optimal strategy that almost always wins in high-level play.

I think that the 3-player game and possibly the 4-player game if you can stand the duration and downtime are among the best boardgame experiences that one may have. Highly recommended!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
TtA:ASoC captures the grand flavor and intensity of building and maintaining a nation... er... uh... through the ages.

Compared to the grand-poobah Civilization, TtA:ASoC is a much shorter game, it is however still rather lengthy, and downtime in a 4-player game can seem to last... er...uh... through the ages. The chaos factor of other player's card track selections and the outcome of events and aggressions can make long-term planning a tricky task requiring adaptablity laced with a touch of luck. Component-wise the game is adequate but definitley not preferable. The cards are quite nice, with decent artwork, though the scoring-board is a bit bland and the player's resource-cards are too small/user-unfriendly. The bits (microscopic beads, and wooden cones) are borderline annoying.

Ultimately, the overall design is very fluid, making for a fun and furious nation-management game that can be played during a weekday night.

RATING: 7.5
This is a swish, sophisticated civ building game that does not outstay its welcome. There is an element of randomness in the way that cards are laid out for everyone to pick from, but this is nothing like as wild as the stupid cards in the original civilisation.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Wow, this is a heavy, sophisticated game. It has a number of different mechanics which seem to work intricately together, the creating of a civ engine while taking the opportunities you can from the card drafting mechanic. At times the game can seem dry, but at other times you have that satisfying feeling of surveying the growth and sophistication of the civilization you've created (even without a map). In my very limited experience it is very competitive; you're either desperate to keep pace with your opponent or fortifying your military to be able to weather a war. The only reason it's not a ten for me is that the game can run long and those moments of dryness can pop up. I acknowledge it's a different game, but if I have a desire for an epic brain burner, I'd probably choose Twilight Struggle nine times out of ten. If I were more Eurogame inclined, I might feel differently.

Update: It might just be too dry for the investment - at least for me. I have not often found myself interested in pulling it off the shelf as the theme doesn't fill the room as a game this heavy and long should. I'd pick Twilight Struggle ten times out of ten. I have to keep this at at least a seven just because of the design, though. If I do find myself in a resource optimization mood, this is this is where I'll go.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
just what the tigers love best :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
As far as a game capturing the feel of Sid Meier's Civilization PC game, I feel this game gets it right.  The mechanics themselves are good, but there are some things that this games that I just can't forgive.

The first and biggest complaint is the length.  If you play this thing from start to finish, from Antiquity to the 3rd Age, you're looking at the better part of 4 hours.  I usually have no problem with long games, but my other gripes will explain why this game can be so excruciating to sit through. 

This is a game that will punish you for playing it incorrectly...which is fine, but I've found it nearly impossible to ever recover, since everything you're managing is so interdependent.

Through most of the game, this is a bit of a solo experience.  Every once in awhile, someone might declare an aggression on someone else, but the confidence to do that usually only belongs to one player.  Wars are interesting, but you're lucky if you see one within the first 3 hours.

Finally, the overall presentation.  So much of the design is counter-intuitive.  It's not impossible to figure out, but it makes introducing the game quite a chore.  The face of the card gives little indication as to what age it's from, the difference between the backs of the Age and Military cards from each age isn't significant enough, the rulebook is a mess, the game is RIDDLED WITH ERRORS (ON IT'S THIRD PRINTING!!!  INEXCUSABLE!), I hate the stupid little wooden discs, the artwork is ugly, the boards are bland...It's just no good.

I feel like I want to rate this game lower, but it is fun in the beginning and it does the PC Civ thing very well.  But I just can't justify the amount of time it takes, and I can't look past its flaws.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Hoo, this one can be unforgiving. Super fiddly, I hate the small round tokens, and the bare bones presentation isn't exactly going to suck anyone in. We persevered and got the hang of it, and it's now turned into one of the most engaging and satisfying games we play (all plays have been 2-player). Our "full" games average 3.5/4 hours of length, but they don't feel like they take that long, which I think says a lot. One of the few games I own that actually had me thinking outside of the game about how I was going to play it the next time.

RATING: 10
I like civilization games, and this looks like a solid entry in the genre.

After my first couple of plays I know I enjoy this game, but it's going to take some concentrated effort and multiple games to learn it to the point that I'll feel comfortable rating it.  I do want to play the required games though, so that bodes well for it's score.

After several plays of the full game I find that I really enjoy the game.  Many decisions to be made, and the game constantly keeps you on your feet.  I don't care much for how the conflicts are structured, but I think that I'm not quite grokking them yet.  I know wars and battles are not meant to be the easiest thing to use to your advantage, but so far I have yet to be in a position that I felt confident that I was better off than my opponent by my taking an aggressive action.  The only drawback to this game is that it's taking us around 3 hours to complete a two-player game.  That means we get to play this less often than we'd like!

RATING: 9
Σπουδαῖο παιχνίδι! Πολλὲς καὶ δύσκολες ἐπιλογές, ὁ παίκτης πρέπει νὰ διατηρεῖ μιὰ ἰσορροπία ἀπὸ κάθε πλευρά. Δὲν τιμωρεῖ κατηγορηματικὰ τὰ λάθη, ἀλλὰ δὲν ἀφήνει καὶ πολλὰ περιθώρια γιὰ χαλαρὴ συμπεριφορά.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Obviously inspired by Sid Meier's Civilization (computer game), this conversion to a board/card game works much better than Eagle's earlier attempt. Much more abstract and without a map, this version still has players building and tailoring their "civilization" according to their inclinations and drafting cards that support the direction they wish to take (or sometimes the reverse).

As in so many games lately, the player is regulated by an "action drafting" system where each action involves making choices between many options. The game is essentially one of constructing a victory point engine from the opportunities the game presents.

The game consists of three levels: "simple," "advanced" and "full." The simple game involves very little player interaction and serves mainly to introduce all the moving parts. The advanced game adds more to the game and can involve more player interaction (a lot more if all the optional rules are adopted). The game requires several playings to appreciate the flow and card interactions. With a full four players, the advanced game becomes quite long - the full game would be epic (and since being simply more of the same, I'm not sure the full game will ever need to be played except by fanatics). Three players may be the sweet spot (and I've not tried two players).

The player interaction, when it occurs, consists of taking "military actions" such as playing an "aggression" card which represents a raid or skirmish between two players with the winner being the one with the higher total military strength. In this, the defender has a slight advantage being the only one able to play "defense cards" he may hold. Attacking may mean committing to lose some expensive military units, so doing so (unless almost certain of winning) seems to be a needless gamble. In practice, it means that a player will attack the weakest opponent rather than your nearest competitor and thus tends not to be a particularly useful tool (and a possible design flaw). Nothing would frustrate a player more than investing several hours to his civilization only to see it savaged by an opportunist. So far in our games we haven't seen a lot of this sort of "take that" play - but we can see the possibility of this becoming an important element.

Another related aspect of player interaction is the competition for colonies and new territories where lucrative resources are acquired by bidding military units against the other players. However, as successfully doing so could leave you vulnerable to aggression, it becomes a very calculated risk.

It occurs to me that most players drawn to this game will be those who see this as a Euro version of Civ. The cutthroat nature of the player interaction may prove to be a turn off for many of those. So far I'm liking it (but have yet to see or feel the full force of the nasty things players can inflict on each other).

You have been warned - Caveat Emptor!
++++++
After an extended hiatus, I've had a chance to revisit this game and must admit to the genius of its design. I still think three players is the sweet spot but my hesitance about the military side of the game is proving unfounded. It is integral and self-balancing, and will be visited a lot or a little depending on the group dynamic but the game will stand up either way. Truly impressive!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Самая настоящая "цивилизация", которая при этом отлично умещается в несколько игровых часов. Похоже, у нас новая семейная традиция - воскресный вечер = партия в Through the Ages.

RATING: 9
** Update. Currently flavour of the month, so playing this quite a bit (full game).

Quite like the standard game - yes it's got the combat element cut, but it works and it's pretty short. Advanced game is good, adding in the elements removed from the standard game, especially like the way 'events' are handled.Definitely not 'civilization' or 'civ-lite'. It's a card game with a civilization theme - there's more micromanagement than in civ (more like the computer version with happy people etc). I like the draft mechanic for getting the cards, I like the limited resources and difficult choices and the way each civilization quickly diverges as different cards are picked and different routes to victory selected.I can see downtime being a problem with some with 4 players - but as a 2 player it's great and probably best with 3. Military aspect is interesting - you need some military might, but if you use it then you make yourself weaker and then a target for the 3rd person - so it's not just a case of get ahead and roll over the opponents.

All in all - like it a lot. Main 'missing' bit for me is there's no trading between players - but with the player numbers 2-4 that's not surprising, you need more for a trading game to really shine.

Not sure about balance though - 1st player seems a real disadvantage, and now we all know what we're doing we haven't seen player #1 win in a multiplayer game :( Considering tinkering with start and end game to fix the problem.

It's got a lot of card-combination stuff in it so knowing the cards well is important which makes the learning curve steep and long.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Based on one 3 player Advanced Game:

A good civ game that has a story arc that brings one through the times of development of culture and one's little empire. A lot going on in the game. It took 1.25 hours to explain the game and then another 4.25 hours to play. We will play the full game next time.

Three criticisms: firstly, the tie-breaker on event cards was exceptionally lame ("the next player in turn order wins the tie" - it felt like no thought was given on that mechanism). Secondly, it is very lengthy as stated by the game itself. Thirdly, it is very much a multi-player solitaire competition of who builds the better VP engine, so ubiquitously found in the oodles of euros out there.

Update: played a Full Game in under 4.5 hours. Still lengthy. I'm not an admirer of games that require one to know 'the tricks' of which card combos to get; usually leaves me underwhelmed. I don't think of my opponent as being particularly brilliant just because he knew which leader with which building scores the biggest VPs. Also received re-affirmation that this game is virtually all multi-player solitaire with minimal player interaction.

The return on time investment will prevent this one from being played very often.

RATING: 10
A really good civ game. I've always liked the idea of civ-style boardgames but found the long playtime prohibitive. These days I don't have an entire weekend to spare. TTA is a really nice balance between depth of play but with a reasonable playtime. You can knock out a game in 4 or 5 hours. The various mechanics for controlling the growth and development of your civilisation are elegant and devlishly tricky to master. There are numerous routes to victory, so it's not all about who has the biggest stick (Freud eat your hear out). If you haven't tried it then I would heartily recommend you do.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great design: very intuitive and easy to understand rules, despite their initial complexity. The game plays well with two players, being just competitive enough without being too long. I hate the appearance of the board and the really bad card art. I hope the redesign will have some half-decent art and maybe even a few pictures on the bland scoreboard. As it stands, it seems like a $70 print-and-play.

Nevertheless, it is a fantastic game: there are meaningful decisions galore, and so many possible approaches make the game different every time. For a strictly Civ-themed game, I'll probably always prefer the map-and-mini-based games like Sid Meier's Civilization or Clash of Cultures. As an intense and epic Euro game, however, it's one of the best, highly deserving of its top-five ranking.

UPDATE: Yay!! New edition is both beautiful and more streamlined. Still amazing first edition sold away. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Basic game was boring and solitaire like.  Looking forward to trying the advanced game.  Will re-rate then.

Update: I've played the advanced game.  You build up your own VP engine and get it going to produce VPs.  It's like Race for the Galaxy except not as elegant, the turns take 10x longer, and you can target specific people to hurt their progress.  Not only can you target people, but the opportunity exists to dogpile on people (with person after person attacking the same player on the same turn).  This will not only take the leader down a notch, but knock him out for a good, long time.  And that's if you can even target the leader!  This game actually encourages players to pile on the weakest player, who is probably in the worst position overall.  The mechanics themselves encourage you to team up, putting people in a bad position into a worse one.  If the pile on happens towards the end of the game, there's absolutely nothing you can do about it.

Now this type of military action may be thematic (kind of, I mean, if you're going in after another civ has trashed the place, wouldn't you have to fight the conquering civ for the scraps?), but it kills one aspect: fun.  This was not a fun game.  It's slightly fiddly on top of everything else, and if I didn't have a lunar eclipse to watch between turns, I would probably be rating this game even lower than I already am.

So if you want a longer, less elegant Race for the Galaxy that takes 10x longer... this is your game.

Update:  Thinking about it more, if you want to make this game enjoyable.. go all the way:  Allow players to draft for Military cards instead of a random draw.  Get complete control over your personal civ and cut down on the randomness completely.  That may make the game palatable (and take an extra 2 hours).

Second Update: Knocked it down again for the completely shoddy production and mistakes.  The amount they're charging for this card game is absolutely ridiculous and should not be encouraged by actually buying it.

Third Update: Played a Full Game to make sure my rating isn't crazy.

There are some really uneven cards in the game.  Overall, I enjoyed the two player experience more for two reasons:
 
1) The game seemed quicker, and more enjoyable.
2) The military aspect of the game was one more of brinksmanship than aggressive action.  An aspect I found much better than the multiplayer scenario.
 
That said, there are tons of problems with the game.. most of which I've already explained.. but a lot of uneveness in the cards became glaringly obvious... here's an example:
 
Fast Food Chains:  This card needs a nerf pretty badly.  It's far superior in terms of VPs able to be earned because it falls along natural lines in which you're already building, and it's an easy 30+ vps if you happen to pick it up (which is also part of the randomness of cards coming out, so a huge luck factor).  By comparison, the other Wonders from this age require a specific plan to capitalize upon them, and one you need to be in the path for, while Fast Food Chains provides the most VPs, and it works for everyone.
 
There are other examples, but overall this game just doesn't have the bang for the buck considering time investment, etc.  Race for the Galaxy gives me everything I want in a much shorter timeframe, and has a lot of the same components to gameplay (building your own VP engine, finding ways to maximize around others (actions/card drafts), solo gameplay, and value added from knowledge of the deck.
 
The fact that I was not able to bury any age 3 scoring cards that hurt me simply because I didn't see them is something I would chalk up to bad luck.. but in a 3 hour game, it's largely inexcusable in my eyes.
 
I've raised the rating of Through the Ages to a 4 as a two player experience, which leaves my rating at a 3 overall.  It's just not worth the time investment, and I would probably only play it again in 2p (where military is the only thing that matters)... and then, I'm suggesting anything else over it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
This comment will not be popular with my friends.

I just don't like this game that much.  It's THE FIDDLIEST GAME I have ever played.  I don't think it's a good sign when, an hour into a game, I am just praying (almost literally) that a computer would appear to do all the work.  I know it tries to represent a PC game to begin with, but in my case, I would rather this had been designed as a Civ-lite computer game.

All that said, I respect the design and its depth.  It offers a lot to a gamer (although I am still of the opinion that its nature does not create a true narrative).  I can even see developing your skills at this game becoming a life pursuit.  These are all admirable qualities.

I am just not sure I ever need to play it again.

You know what I would like to see?  The designer of Armageddon Empires should take a shot at developing this into a PC game.  Then, I would get REALLY excited about playing it again.

RATING: 9
UPDATE (7/29): Now on BGA!

My rating would be a 9 if this game weren't so damn long. But other than length -- wow. Well balanced game, lots of ingenious mechanisms (future events!), lots to think about every turn. What's really remarkable is how two players can build up completely different civilizations and yet keep up with each other, due to the game's diversity. Downsides: the rules are a total beast (I spent several hours learning them well enough to teach and play the game), there is a [i]lot[/i] of moving bits around (I can only imagine how much easier this would be as a computer game), and, as I said earlier, the undue length. Other than that -- wow. UPDATE: 8 -> 9. Only its length and complexity keep it from a 10. The online implementation is a gift from God.
