RATING: 9
Played again and increased the rating another notch - this is a very good game indeed.  Now playing online at boardgaming-online.com - which is a fantastic implementation - recommended.

Initially the rules are a bit difficult, but they come together after a turn or three.  An initial partial basic game whetted my appetite, the advanced game didn't dissapoint and the full game is even better (but long).  There are a lot of issues to consider, not least just striking a balance between resources and population, while keeping an eye on the problems caused by corruption and the need to avoid famine and revolt.  And then there's so many tempting options to pursue as the civilisation cards flow past that there are tough choices not only every turn, but every action - even using the Peaceful variant, which is a helpful way to begin but leaves a whole lot more to explore as the military aspects really complete the game, making it both much tougher and more enjoyable.  The only downside is the long playing time but it is worth it and does reduce with experience.  I'm left looking forward to playing again soon.  And then some more.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Comment Cleanup UPDATE:

I have a review here which pretty well summarizes how I feel about the game, so I won't go into excessive detail here. I think Through the Ages is clever in spots, not so clever in others; it's definitely overwrought and has way too much rules grit (a borderline-competent developer could have helped a ton), but has a nice "grand sweep" to it, even if it's not particularly thematic. But it is absolutely *killed* by length and, especially, downtime. This is a totally linear game in which all you can do when it's not your turn is sit around and wait. There is no player interaction to speak of. And that downtime can get extreme, especially late when players have many actions.

This game has a vocal and dedicated fanbase, but personally, I just don't get it. Through the Ages is mediocre at best by most reasonable critical standards. Fans of Sid Meier's Civilization computer game may find some fun here in the evocation of the feel of that game, but folks looking for an actual multi-player boardgame would do well to avoid. This has absolutely nothing on the Avalon Hill classic - it's more complicated, less thematic, more punishing with less control, every bit as long while being far less interactive ... etc.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Excellent game if you don't mind the length, which is the only reason this one doesn't get a 10 rating from me.  The game is a little mind boggling at first (I was taught the full game right off the bat), but begins to make more sense after playing through an age or so.  Really tough to do everything you want to do.  Once the game gets going, it's really cool to see the civs progress from ancient societies to modern cities, and there are many different paths you can follow based on your leader's abilities.  Cool game!  The only drawback for me is that I'd never want to play this game with 4 due to game length and downtime.  Great with three though.

Update: Many years later, Nations has killed this game for me, as I prefer it by quite a bit, and it does almost exactly the same things.

RATING: 6
Played almost all of a 3-player full game.  The game is fun, but the length is a real issue for me.  If I can't play it in under 4 hours, I can't play it very often.  It's particularly disconcerting because everything feels so repetitive.  There are a lot of similar cards, and none of us got our production engines going enough to use most of them.

I would also prefer to see a more gradual step up between the ages (maybe 5 ages with smaller increases) and larger decks of cards from which the combinations are drawn randomly for each game.  I already have a favorite leader and wonder in Antiquity.  If I played more often, I could probably also develop set strategies for other ages.  That really takes away a lot of the fun.  

I love all the bit fiddling.  I like the idea of this game alot.  I like a lot of the execution.  But something just missed the mark.  I really don't think it's a game for me to own.  I'm more than happy to play it once in a while, however.  

The rating is preliminary, and could change with more plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
[20/03/2007] Having only played the first two ages, I haven't by any means gained a firm opinion regarding TtA. Many question-marks remain for the time-being:

Direct player interaction in TtA - lacking a trading element found in many other Civilization-style games - is limited to military affairs. Since that part of the game is rather toned down in its importance, direct player interaction is pretty low. This is particularly true if the arms race remains relatively balanced and attacks are sufficiently deterred.

This means player interaction is more indirect in nature (a feature common to many eurogames). Such as in regards to card drafting. Unless I underestimate the importance and frequency of military confrontation, I'd say TtA has only low player interaction and approaches the "multiplayer solitaire" character of say Princes of Florence or Goa.

The question then is whether managing your own civilization holds sufficient interest as to compensate for the lack of player interaction.

Creating and maintaining a balanced and productive economy does offer an interesting challenge. So does judicious card drafting and play. But is this solitaire-esque puzzle sufficiently engaging for the pretty long time it takes to play TtA? As far as I'm concerned, the jury's still out on that vital question.

My tolerance of "solitaire puzzles" in games tends to diminish the longer it takes to play a game. A high degree of player interaction is what keeps
me engaged in say a 'Britannia' or 'Twilight Imperium', while a "solitaire puzzle" may easily get stale and repetitive of the course of hours.

I think the key to keeping the managing one's empire exciting is for different problems to emerge in each age. A true story arc. My very limited experience suggests that the various ages only provide more powerful cards, rather than altering the underlying economic dynamics(e.g. ages creating different scarceties). I am interested to see whether further play of mine will confirm or refute this suspicion of mine.

"Free-form" multiplayer games tend to struggle with the "runaway leader" and "leader bashing" issues. The right balance between rewards for successful/aggressive play and opportunities to reverse the game situation needs to be found. The greater direct player interaction (often manifesting itself militarily) happens to be, the more opportunity for the latter there tends to be. I'm concerned that the relatively marginal role of military affairs in TtA isn't compensated by a further area of direct interaction. So reigning in the leaders and catching up might be overly difficult (rich get richer problem raising its ugly head).

I fear the game may well see too many situations in which the trailing players have no chance whatsoever to win and the outcome of the game will already be in no doubt well before the game draws to a close. Such anticlimactic endings are particularly problematic with long games, since the endgame's then correspondingly longer.

So, I do find myself rather in doubt whether TtA suits my taste. I will need to play it again to gain a proper impression regarding the said dynamics in this game. The overarching question's whether the game has a true story arc which makes the various ages truly different and hence engaging so as to compensate for the low player interaction (and possible downtime symptoms) arising from this.

Despite my rather skeptical first impressions, I'm quite eager to study this game more since it's thematically in many respects an original and clever design. Certainly solid craftsmanship.

What a stark contrast to the horribly flawed and loathesome "Sid Meier's Civilization - The Boardgame" by Eaglegames our gaming group recently brought to the table.

I wonder whether TtA can win a place in my affection next to "Mare Nostrum", the game in the Civilization genre I most favour (provided one uses the general naval blockade variant rule and a couple of other tweaks, mind you).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Really enjoy the burn on this one. Still, I have a couple of concerns:

1. Length. Does it offer enough control to make it worth the investment? 

2. Still feels like a bit of a point-churner Euro rather than a Civbuiler. 

3. Does the wrong card flop imbalance the game (i.e.,are certain cards overpowered?). 

Liking it a lot. If we can play it in less than 3 hours (maybe cut down to advanced game?) I could see the rating rising. 

UPDATE: Nah, I think that it is just too generic and long to really be much fun for me. While the card names and drawings give sort of gave me the impression that TtA is a Civ-builder with some history built in, it's really just a cube-pusher , and a cube-pusher with too much luck of the draw. With more than two players the group could maybe gang up on the guy with killer card, but egad, I can't imagine how long a three or four player game would take. 

Still, the game is well-designed, and I admire what the designer was trying to accomplish, but it is just not for me. Another much-hyped game disappoints.

RATING: 9.5
[u]May 2009: [/u] Just bought this, I'm really excited to try it out, though I'm a bit scared that it won't be great for 2p and that it might be too long... We'll see.

1st game, 2p, simple game: the simple game is not good, it is pretty much uninteresting but it does help to get a grasp on a good part of the concepts. Play one of these but just once...

2nd game: 2p, advanced: The advanced game is significantly better (and longer). It took 3 hours. It was a good 3 hours though, even if I did feel kind of left with my mouth hanging wanting for more at the end. I didn't have that feeling of accomplishment near the end that I like in civ games. The game could be shorten I guess once we know the cards better and when we're both not tired.

[u] June 2009:[/u] Ok, 2 full games: this is GREAT!!

I just love the game, the cold war arms race style works great and brings a lot of tension. The events bring nice interaction.

Don't play the simple game, it sucks. But play it once to get the hang of it. Then play the advanced game once but that's it. The advanced game is too short and you can basically (I feel) forget all about military which is where the game really shines.

The full game is the real game, the other 2 variants are just to be considered as tutorials. Don't buy this game thinking you'll have a short game playing the advanced or shrt games, these are not that good. But if you're not afraid of a 2h30+ game, I can only recommend this.

[u]January 10:[/u] 20+ plays, I stand by my judgment, the full game is GREAT! There are still tons of stuff I haven't tried out and am anxious to do so. I wrote a review [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/474645/no-map-so-what]here[/url]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I finally got to play Through the Ages – this was probably the game I was anticipating the most to get on the table! I loooved the Civilization computer games, and in general like civ games, so my expectations for this game were extremely high! However, even though it was a very good game, my first play didn’t convince me that it was such a good game I had hoped it would be. Mind you, I did like it very much, and I do think it was almost impossible for the game to live up to my expectations. But I did not think I would only rate it a 7.5… The main reason for this rating is this: time consumption! The game takes 3½-4½ hours, and that’s too much for me considering the enjoyment I get out of the game. I could play 2-3 other great eurogames in that time span!

There are other reasons for my somewhat low rating. The two biggest reasons, besides the length, are the fiddlyness and especially the emphasis on military which seems too important to neglect. 
To elaborate on the first one, all of the little round discs are hard to pick up, and you constantly need to move them back and forth! There is a lot of upkeep you need to watch your step tread carefully in order to avoid mistakes. While the fiddlyness was a little annoying, it wasn’t part of the gameplay. What is, is the importance of military, and that was definitely what I disliked the most.

I was told that military was important, but not THIS important! If your opponent(s) start building military units, you simply have to follow, because if you don’t you are going to get smashed! And the need to build an army is a shame I think… But I guess that without the military aspect, the game would be too much multiplayer solitaire. Furthermore it felt a little odd that military isn’t really that important in the last round (unless a war has been declared earlier etc). Regarding war, military strength is even more important as you cannot use defense cards! In my second game I won by 70 points, and I probably got half of them due to a couple of wars…
Furhermore, the game is highly strategic but also features a lot of tactical elements (as the card row, which was fantastic!), and I think the random card draws spoil this mechanic somewhat, especially as you can draw a lot of useless military cards.

After my ramblings about my issues with the game, I need to talk about the good stuff! It’s awesome to control your own little civilization! The management concerning feeding your population, keeping track of corruption, planning your actions and keep a balance between military, culture and science is brainburning but fantastic! While your race isn’t unique at the start of the game, it quickly turns into one. The wonders and Leaders work very well too and are a big part of why your civilization feels unique. I have my favorites among them, and there are also some cards I would certainly not buy, but again, it’s situational and I’m sure they are balanced. I was pleasantly surprised that a civilization game like this actually works without a map, which was one of my biggest concerns. Finally, the bonus cards you reveal after the game add tension as there are some final hidden bonus scoring cards which can shake things up!

After considering the good thing and the bad things, I cannot give it a better rating. It’s a good game, but 1½ hour per player is too much and is the reason that it’s not a game I always want to play. As said, I can play 2 or perhaps even 3 very good eurogames in the same time. It’s a shame, and while I don’t mind the occasional long game, I have come to the conclusion that I prefer my games to last less than 3 hours. 
I dived right into the full game with 2 other, very experienced players. I managed okay and was actually close to winning, which I was surprised to see considering all of the mistakes and sub-optimal decisions I made. My second play was against another inexperienced player, and once again the military played a decisive factor. I am eager to play the game again, but if it continues to have these “problems” (length, fiddlyness and importance of military), I’m not really sure what to do. Anyway, my next play will probably be against my wife, and I’m going to play it with the rules without military and see what happens. And after that I am going to try the advanced game again a few more times before I make up my final conclusion. I can’t wait, because I love the idea of this game and I want to love the gameplay too!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2

I disliked the abstract feeling of having no map and just moving pieces around like an accountant. The small round population and resource counters were extremely annoying to handle. Never again!

RATING: 10
*10* (15+ Plays)
Love the gameplay with all player counts, and I discovered Tom's Solo Variant, which I really Enjoy. RATING: 7.5
I am only going to give this game a 9.5 at this time because I have only played the Simple Game.  Chances are, it will increase with the full rules implemented, but for now, it is slightly incomplete.

This is definitely a thinkers game, with a significant amount of strategy.  A very well done job by the designer, and after playing the Simple Game, it begs to be played again with the Advanced and Full Rules.  The rules can be daunting at first, but like other highly-rated strategy games ([gameid=3076], [gameid=18602], [gameid=2651]), they can be overcome if one sets their mind to it.  An excellent job.

Oh, and if you have played any of the later iterations of Sid Meyers' Civilization PC-based games, you will find a few things (somewhat) familiar.  However, unlike the computer game, having the most CULTURE is really the victory condition.  This is definitely a game that will see a significant amount of play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Feels like a very long Euro - as most of the game is resource manipulation where you want to do 10 things but can only do 2.  You try to make strategic plans to get certain upgrades in play only to find out that those plans need to be re-adjusted because even better upgrades come along that you now need to plan for - and in a nutshell - that sums up all the interesting decisions you make in the game.  The theme is well integreted into the card choices and even though there is a military aspect to the game, this is by no means anything close to a wargame.  The military is just another resource you need to manage, along with food, material, population, science, victory points and overall happiness.  Recommended if you can find the time to play through at least the second age and with at least 3 players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
It would probably take too long to play.

Wow it really took too long to play.  We played with four players, using the advanced (but not full) rule set.  One person had played before, the other three had not, but were all experienced gamers.  The game is not particularly engaging to look at unfortunately, and everyone else's turn is pretty boring.  There isn't anything to do while someone else is taking their turn, and there's not much reason to pay attention either because mostly they can't affect you.

Although you could be planning your turn while you wait, the burning and shifting cards are sufficient change that you'll likely have to re-assess when you get to act.

I think with repeated plays speed could be improved, but it remains that the game isn't very engaging to look at.  Also some interest in other players may be provided with the FULL rules, including pacts and wars, but I don't know if it was good enough on the first play through to draw us back to try that.

Less players has also been recommended, and I think 2p may be where this game shines... more at least.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Through the Ages is an odd beast of a game. I both admire it and conclude that it has some traits about it that are off-putting. It's a game that I tried, enjoyed, traded for, hated, traded away, played online, and now grudgingly admire.

First off, it's an admirable design that provides players with a broad playground for teching up a civilization. It's a demanding balancing act that forces players to juggle, resources, happiness, military, science, and ultimately culture for the win. I imagine every time I play this game I'll learn something new.

And, the game is also fiddly, with a player's turn taking quite some time. It's long. And most disconcerting, it's incredibly unforgiving for inexperienced players. I don't think anyone can prepare a new person sitting at the table with experienced TTA players for the arse-whipping they are about to get handed. Military does incentivise players to beat on the weak, and there's a reason that "Leaving the Game Honorably" is written in the rules.

Now that I have a few plays under my belt, I think ultimately I will enjoy playing this game online most with a core group of people. It's certainly not a game I need to own, but it is a game I enjoy very much via the slowburn of online play.

RATING: 6
Once making a mistake during the game; it is hard to setting up check point for re-do the process.  Also the playing time seems to be to long for the advanced game.
I think that if you have a consistent game group and you are willing to spend 3-4 hours at a time playing one game, this will definitely be a hit. For new players, if you are unsure about playing this game often in the future, it may not be the best choice. Not that it is difficult to learn, but more so because it is not worth the initial investment unless you know you can play this game again and become better at it. This game is best when all players know what to expect in terms of time, skill and complexity. If one or more players is not really into the game and just selecting actions on a whim, the game could fall flat. There are so many things to keep track of and so many decisions to make, that the level of enjoyment really depends on how the players participate.

RATING: 5
2 plays with 3 players

Love it my first play, hated it my second.  In the end it is a good economic engine game, that takes a long time to play but in which I felt I never had the time to develop my civ.  Technology cards race across the board before you can "buy" them - what does that model historically?  There's no map to explore which is a HUGE minus in my book, and there's no tech tree.  If my people have developed printing presses, why can't they develop journalism?

The game is rife with niggley little rules that make no sense given the theme and obey no logic ... making them hard to remember and internalize into one's play.

It's a good game, a 6 that takes way to long to play and seems to either fly by or drag endlessly depending, in no small part, on how lucky you are.

I doubt I would ever play again - other titles do the Civ building thing better.

The production quality (FRED 1st edition) is horrific, North Korean level stuff.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.75
:tobacco: :( :D :D :D I don't think I've ever had a game go from zero to ten plays this quickly (thanks largely to boardgaming-online.com; may their tribe increase), and I'm still ready to play again, in fact I just launched two online games as of this writing.

TTA is, at heart, an engine-building efficency Euro where players (civilizations) have a variable number of action points based (primarily) on their system of government. Variables that must be managed are food (for adding much-needed population), resources (for building just about everything), science (for discovering just about everything), military strength (used to crush your enemies, see them driven before you and hear the lamentation of their women, or to defend yourself from same) and culture (aka victory points). Like Dominion/Agricola/Le Havre/Puerto Rico/Race For The Galaxy/etc., the early game is all about setting up the engine to churn out everything except VPs, and the grand-strategic decision point is when to pivot to start building the big point generators. Too much early point scoring is a drag against your endgame, pivoting too late leaves you horribly behind. The equivalent of Agricola's "feed your family" mechanic is the arms race, which really does end up being an arms race in a game-theoretic sense -- military (depending on your opponent's approach) is either your key to victory, your total undoing, or a persistent annoying (but necessary) drag on the health of your economy.

TTA is a bit long but once you get used to the end-turn fiddling (it helps A LOT to do everything in the same order every time) it's not oppressively long. And it actually handles the book-keeping quite elegantly, considering. [i]And[/i] it's in that rarefied category of games that are both good for two and good for three and four.

A worthy choice as a main-course game for any lover of heavier Euros, and an addictive temptation as an asynch online game. Play this thing.

RATING: 5
Too tactical for length.

Okay.  I hate TtA.  It's too reliant on tactical efficiency optimization.  I can't implement a strategy because there's no guarantee that I can get the necessary cards.  

I was trying to use a military strategy, which gets around the reliance on civil action card somewhat, but then often  I don't draw military cards I need.

On top of all that, the third era cards can be incredibly swingy but there's no way of knowing which ones will come in to play to optimize for from the beginning.

So the best strategy seems to be do a little of everything, and hope for the best.  Bleh.

Plus engine building just doesn't interest me.  I wanted to see if I could avoid engine building successfully, and it seems to work 40% of the time, but it's such a narrow path that now that I've fine-tuned it I see no use of playing the same way every game.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Wow, the more I play...the more I want to play this beauty. Is it the perfect game? No.  But its thoroughly engaging and is the most satisfying civilization game I've ever played.

The production values are disappointing. I recall noticing that when I opened the box. But as soon as I started the first game, that became irrelevant. The components are adequate to play, and the design and game itself are impressive. Its nice to see an undertaking like this which has been well developed and adequately play-tested. I don't see enough people giving credit there, when it would be easy to imagine discovering that a card or card combo was ambiguous or over-powered. I'm finding no such issues.

Its loooong to play the full game, but its really the only way to go if there's the option. Things just barely started happening in the advanced game when it was at the end. The added manipulation of playing secret scoring events adds just the right bit of caginess.

Initially, I had some concerns over how well the military interactions would work. In time, I came to realize that they are the genius that makes the rest of the game work. You really can't do everything. If you invest too heavily in infrastructure, you'll be militarily susceptible. And if that's the case: your infrastructure will eventually take a hit. There are multiple ways to interact with your opponents. If the aggression/war options weren't there, there might be no viable way to reel in the leader at times. That said, it can sometimes be pretty hard to gauge who the leader is. 

Finally, the game works well and feels different with each different number of players (2-4). I guess the biggest downside is that waiting for your turn in a 4p game can be a bit slow. But the pace feels OK in 3p games. I don't usually play multiplayer games 2p, but this is one that really works. It feels to me like a CDG, like Twilight Struggle. There is some deck management and racing to optimize. But you can get at your opponent in more ways than he/she can defend. And vice versa!

My rating only rises. Maybe it will settle in at a 10 for me. Its pretty darn close.

Update: After about a dozen plays (all full games) I'm starting to feel that the military race supercedes most other strategy. The player who is ahead there most of the game tends to always win. Our local games have turned into a giant race for military strength, with lower overall scores.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I assume that most people reading this have some idea of what this game is about, but here's the quick:

TtA is a civilization themed game where the players draft personalities, technology, wonders, and so forth from a central display, occasionally kick the crap out of each other with military strength, and generally build large scale economic engines. The entire thing is one big economic game in essence, where you need to get resource x, convert that into y, and then turn that into z. Everything is tight in the game, and you always need more of something. The game is quite comparable, in terms of fiddle, to the Civ computer games, which are nodded to directly in the form of a Sid Meier leader card.

So you build a snowball, which you then use to make a bigger snowball. You MUST keep up with the technology curve in the farming, agriculture, science, and culture areas, or you will find yourself in very dire straits. The game essentially amounts to juggling 14 balls at once.

Now, I like the game, and I found it enjoyable to play. We went straight to the Full game, which goes through all 3 ages, and has all of the rules present, and I really couldn't see playing this game any other way. That said, the game is long with that many cards, and I really prefer to play it with either 2 or 3 rather than 4 simply because the pace is faster...TtA is one of those games where each player takes their entire turn while the others wait, so each player adds about an equal amount of downtime (because you can't plan ahead well, the card display turns for each turn, and it often dictates what you want to do...). All of this said, with 4 relatively fast players who know the game it's easily doable in 2.5-3 hours, which I think is fine for this title. If your group isn't pretty fast and experienced, then 3 really has to be the cap here.

Frankly, after having played it with 2, I feel that it is best at that scale. The downtime is almost non-existent, and the game keeps the engine-building feel that I like it for without bogging down unnecessarily. I don't actively dislike it with more, and I don't mind playing it with 3, but the 2 player game is probably my favourite way to pull this out. In the two player game, the card draft gains more texture (i.e.: you can actually leave stuff behind with the intent of picking it up cheaper later) and the "problem" of the weak player being beat on by multiple people (which I have not personally witnessed, nor think should be a problem given competent play) doesn't exist. With 2 the only thing you lose is a touch of combat flavour, and the occasional pact. What you get in trade is a fast-moving game where your turn comes back in short order and the engine-building heart of the game remains beating, but more steadily.

I like this game, it's easily the most grand engine building game that has come down the pike in recent years, and the theme is outstanding given Euro conventions and the cards all seem to work in thematic ways, particularly Bill Gates. To me, the criteria for good theme is that the game mechanics must seem to flow naturally given the veneer that has been pasted onto them, and TtA succeeds on that count with flying colours. This is not the type of game that is going to come out every week, but I'm glad to have it around for special occasions. 

This is one of the few games where the rating has to be a sort of average: probably a 9 for 2 players, one of my favourite games at that scale. Perhaps a 8 at 3 players, and a 7 or lower with 4 players depending on their speed of play (i.e.: me with 3 newbies would be something like a 2, me with 1 newbie and 2 other experienced players, maybe a 6, knowledgeable group of 4, easily a 7-8). I rate it an 8 because it frankly deserves recognition for being an excellent design that I often enjoy playing, but it does have to fit into a reasonable time frame and even one slow player can easily add an extra hour to the game.

Notes on the editions: The 1st edition (Czech) printing is superior in almost every way to the 2nd from FRED. The card stock in the first edition is better, the board configuration is superior, and it also has 3 Age III leaders who had to be removed for copyright purposes when the game was reprinted (Bill Gates, Elvis, Sid Meier). The 2nd edition is still worth owning, but I highly advise at least producing paste-ups for the missing leaders. The 3rd edition cards from FRED are reputedly much better, though paste-ups are still recommended for the missing leaders, and I still prefer the original board config.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
This is the best civilisation game I've played. It lacks the one of the 4X elements (no map to explore) but more than makes up for that in doing the other three Xs very well indeed.  

Does require some effort to learn but most of the rules are intuitive and the consequences of your action are usually clear.

This is a rather good 2 player game something I never expected. Despite its lengthy play time this game just floats my boat.

2013
The economy in the game never really explodes exponentially, even if you playing well the lack of one of the following: materials, food, workers or research will put a break on progress. So I'm comming to the conclusion, that if you are seeing rapid improvement, your playing wrong.  Last night we forgot to take away the food costs for a large work force at the end of the turn. Consequently one of the breaks on the economy was removed and progress was rapid.  We should have seen the clues but I foolishly thought it signified an improvement in our gameplay.  The subtle interaction between the different elements of the game shine through.

When we spotted the issue I suggested that we from then on implement the rule.  This was not a good idea it broke my opponents economy two turns before the end of the game and that in retrospect was unfair.  He had no time to mitigate the lack of food and stagnation set in.  I was insulated from this issue by a stock pile of unallocated workers because I had invested in a small improvement in food production a few turns earlier.

I was so focused (this game causes this kind of excitment sometimes) on the main part of my turn that I forgot the political part of the game sequence.  I only played one event in Era II despite a handful of relevant cards (lost the culture score but this may not have otherwise been an advantage).  I also forgot to implement the power of my period one leader (still being used) for a chunk of period II with an additional loss of culture.

I think we were not making quite as many mistakes in Power Grid after 10 plays.  Some of the games subsystems are easy to overlook and there is more to keep an eye on.

2014
I am now playing this game on Boardgame Arena where I have learnt the importance of a stong military the hard way (in period three I was systematically demolished in the first three games).   Despite getting involed in approximately 25 games simultaneously this game shows no sign of losing its shine. I will at some point scale this commitment back if only to improve my play (for instance last night I made several decissions in haste and have blown my chances in a few games) and spend more time studying good opponents.

This game could have be designed for a turned based online format and losses its all night monster status.  The fiddly and easliy forgotten maintenance is gone and now have to learn to slow down, watch my oponents more closely and move away from tactical cosiderations and form long term strategies.

After 127 plays I will be resting this game for a while.

RATING: 7.5

RATING: 10
Gioco con un regolamento semplice , relativamente veloce da giocare e ogni volta estremamente divertente . Non esistono strategie prefissate , il gioco premia chi ha l'abilità di sfruttare al meglio le oppotunità (carte) che gli si presentano . Ovviamente bisogna prima aver fatto qualche partita per avere un'idea di come siano composti i vari mazzi di carte . Ogni scelta è cruciale , ci si trova spesso con la testa che fuma . Nonostante sia sostanzialmente astratto , le carte creano comunque una buona ambientazione legata al tema del gioco . Si nota anche l'ottimo lavoro svolto per bilanciare tutti gli aspetti produzione/tecnologie/militare . In sostanza un grande gioco , oserei dire geniale . Faccio i complimenti all'ideatore e a tutti i suoi collaboratori .

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Holy moly.  This is the real deal, folks, not some stinking area control exercise with a supposed civilization theme haphazardly draped over it.  Through The Ages is a complex, detailed game that thoroughly provides the sense of development, progression, and strategic variety that anything claiming to be "Civ-Lite" routinely seems to miss.  I have to admit that I was quite skeptical about something initially described as a "Civilization card game" but after a couple of plays it's clear that Mr. Chvatli knew exactly what to cut away and what simply had to remain- the result is a modern game aware of Euro innovations but steeped in the detail and theme-rich traditions of American games and the PC games of Sid Meier.  The card drafting mechanic seemed at first blush to resemble St. Petersburg (which could have been a disaster) but it turns out to be a really interesting way of moving the game along and forcing tough decision points at times when the last thing you need is another option.  Speaking of which, there are tons of branches on this decision tree and you'll never feel that unfortunate sense of having only one or two choices to make per turn.  I was also unsure of how a style of game that really requires a geographical element would work but the way conflict and territory is handled in a somewhat abstracted way works very well- I particularly like how wars are fought with specific goals in mind and aggression is handled in the old Dune manner- how many people are you willing to lose to win?  As far as length goes, the game should be completely playable in 3-4 hours with a full table of 4 folks who've played at least once and I think the 2 and 3 player options should be almost as good as a full table and shorter.  Downtime?  Some, but if you're engaged in the game and have an idea of what you're doing when your turn comes around it's no more than in any other game of this scope.  In my games I've been pretty amazed at the epic feel the game imparts in a relatively short amount of time.  I do think the production, although serviceable, is a little spartan (I hate those tiny glass beads) but the translations- in particular the rulebook- are flawless and complete.  Vlaada Chvatil has found himself a place on my "hot" list, I loved PROPHECY as well and I think GRAENALAND looks interesting too- definitely a designer that has a great sense of combining rich theme with modern mechanics.  Replayability is probably the only thing keeping me from a 10 rating- I _feel_ like it has legs thanks to meaningful interaction and variability but if certain strategies and pathways emerge that render the variety of choices meaningless then it could suffer.  A great design regardless- a fun game that could very well last...Through the Ages!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
I got to play this at BGG con. In a 4 player game we spent 8 hours and played the game to the end of the 2nd age. You can play to the end of the 1st 2nd or 3rd age. This was our first game and we would be faster especially with fewer players. The game is all its cracked up to be. I will certainly be getting it but will it ever get played thats another question. I've heard of 2 people finishing in 4 hours so it can be done and even with 2 people it would still be a good game. However I thought the player interaction is somewhat limited. This is very much a engine game. Possibly the most fascinating engine game out there. If you are prepared to spend the time then you'll love it. I should mention the time is not really related to it being overly complex. All the pieces fit nicely together and it works great, there are just a ton of things you can and need to do. Traded for Civilization.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Through the Ages is my favorite board game. It's a complex, resource-management game in which you build civilizations with resources. The game is card-driven rather than dealing with some big map. It never plays the same way twice and is exciting and always challenging. 

I can't rate it a 10 because it does have flaws. Namely, two-player games can get out of hand militarily,three-player games enhance the kingmaker effect and four-player games have a random distribution of points due to end-of-game impact cards. And when played live, the game is very mechanical. Like Vegas Showdown, this game is played much better online, where the computer gives you vital information (i.e. notifying you when you're in corruption) and performs the mechanics for you. 

Sure enough, there is a FANTASTIC website http://wwww.boardgaming-online.com in which you can play the game online. I have been satisfied with the game enough that I have yet to play the version of the game at http://www.boardgamearena.com

RATING: 8
Good solid game. Needs more plays to make a full assessment. First impression was that as civ games go, I still prefer Clash of Cultures. In Clash of Cultures everyone starts the same and has to choose a path (usually a specific tech specialisation) for victory. And you get to use warrior units on a map. 

Through the Ages has a more random element to its gameplay in that the timing of the cards will dictate your strategy. So even if you would have liked to go a particular strategy, the cards may not let you. Random events can also screw you without much ability to control them. In that sense my preference is for Clash of Cultures. Nevertheless, this is still a solid game.

RATING: 7.5
Very enjoyable and fairly compact Civilization game (as far as civ games go...it still takes up most of our table!) Players have a lot of important choices to make concerning how to allocate resources, and what to focus on. If you leave military alone you become vulnerable to other players and political events. If you spend too much on Military you may leave yourself with not enough food or resources for other important buildings. It's a great balancing act that takes you through the ages of history. Intriguing and fun that's worth the 2-4 hour playing time.

---
My bar for games that last over three hours is pretty high (relative to my own preferences only). I've only played the the full game, and only once, but I really enjoyed it. Even though I was the whipping boy with the wimpiest army. Even though it has one of my least favorite mechanics: "choose a player to attack". I prefer when there's some rationale behind choosing the target, like something they have that you want, etc. But like I said, I still liked it. I like that there are so many paths to development that each player's path can and does feel different form the others. This is large part due to the wide variety of cards. In general I also am not a huge fan of card driven games either. So it's a bit surprising to me that I like this.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
This game has been circling around on my gaming radar as a very faint blip ever since it came out in 2006. I remember thinking that newcomer Vlaada had balls of unobtanium to present this sort of game [i]as a newcomer[/i], but apparently his approach met with a lot of favourable approval from the gaming enthusiasts to end up this high on the ranking lists. (At the time of writing, it is at #4.) Rank doesn't say much, of course, certainly not on an individual level, but still, you need a special type of game to reach that high and apparently TtA is such a type. Unfortunately due to the game's high price and long playing time I never purchased a copy, nor could I persuade anyone to play a game with me—that is, if I remembered it existed. 

But eventually it [i]did[/i] happen, someone was willing to walk me and two other newcomers through precisely 2/3rds of the full game. We didn't finish due to timing constraints: we'd already been at it for like 5 hours and it was time to call things a day. Night, even. I should add that before we started playing I knew very little of TtA: only that it was, more or less, a boardgame version of the earlier editions of computer Civilization (I and II, to be precise), but then without some complex features, such as a map or a tech tree. After finishing our trial game I could indeed agree with that assessment, although I think it is better if you just leave out the comparisons alltogether. TtA is, when you get right down to it, a huge exercise in constructing a snowball growth engine, held back by several 'brakes' on both population and resources, which are intertwined themselves too (as you need population to produce resources in the first place). TtA is the answer to the question [i]I'm done with Puerto Rico, what's next?[/i] The civilization you're building is really just window dressing to give you something to visualise the costs and benefits of every card in the game better.

Because that is basically all you do: grab cards from a row, 'construct' them on your tableau paying resources, then activate them using workers (which had to be 'grown' in an earlier action), reap the benefits, and slowly (especially that) build up your engine over, like, 70 or 80 cards until you begin to hit the actual point cards and can see how your initial design held up against your expectations of the future. Despite our rules explainer assuring us (on multiple occasions no less) that the game would be quicker with experience, that the engines would run more smoothly with experience, ..., he could not really deny that 2/3rds of the game (already taking 2 hours in an ideal case) is spent struggling in an uphill battle for bits and scraps, when, at some point, it simply becomes 'easier' to do things (meaning it takes less actions to do so, and the compound effect of several wonders and technologies making their influence felt), and then, finally, the race for points can begin. It is, in other words, the perfect game for many gamers: no brains required, no complex emergent game patterns, only discussions on what path to take, and then repeating the required growth actions for an eternity. The computer game does exactly the same thing, but at least there you can save the game state and pick up where you left if you feel like it. Plus it handles a lot of micromanagement stuff (although it introduces others). Here, you need to finish what you started :x.

TtA represents a type of game which does not really agree with me. If I must/need/want to play a snowball growth engine, then I want to be done in an hour or so. If someone manages to obtain an insurmountable lead, the suffering for the other players is short, and the restart is quick an easy. (What notably bugged my partner, for example, is that some events clearly punish the player in last place. I know from experience with Olympos (the Ystari game) that such a mechanism will bite in the first games, and then players learn to divert effort to make sure the last player revolves around the table. But in TtA the penalties seem harsher, and can really put you back significantly... which is hardly acceptable in a game of this length.) The length of TtA probably makes it eminently suitable for many hundreds of repeat plays... But that is something which is not going to happen at my table anyway. So the added complexity in the various paths to take is wasted on me.

In the end I'm glad I got to play the game, as I now have a good idea of what it is about. But it's not a game I need to play again anytime soon, if at all. I'll stick to simpler fare. If that doesn't make me a True Gamer, then so be it. The game itself does not really deserve the rate I'm handing out: it [i]is[/i] a fine example of the genre, certainly one to look out for if you like this kind of thing. But it's not for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
I was tempted to rate this game lower due to the issues.  But I want to rate my games based on my enjoyment so it is a 9.

The reality is that this game has some issues that you are probably already aware of. 

Didn't like:

1. The games is basically a video game.  It has a lot of counting and whatnot that would be a lot easier if it was played on a computer.  It slows the game down.

2. You need experienced gamers or it will be slow.

But if you can get over that this is a must play.  Kind of like Antiquity the joy is in the building and experimenting first, winning second.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Through the Ages: A Story of Civilization is simply an awesome very heavy Euro game!!!  Having played Sid Meyer's Civilization computer games and Avalon Hill's Advanced Civilization - I find Through the Ages to be a fantastic game that captures the two other games just mentioned in a Euro game.  The abstracted military mechnanisms, abstracted expansion of your civilization, technological achievements gained and marvelous wonders built by one's civilization are well designed.  Historic leaders of various ages are present.  There are game mechanisms for forming pacts between players, a bidding mechanism for gaining territories, minor abstracted combat in the form of raids and major war in an abstract kind of way.  Just like other epic civlization games, there are whammy cards that can hurt or help your civilization designed in which players use a unique "seeding" mechanism to put these cards in play and hopefully reap the benefit over time when the cards appear for their impact to be realized. If you like Civilization games - Through the Ages is a MUST for your collection.  Through the Ages is also a game that players enjoy playing over and over again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
     A very good 'Civ' like game.  If you're looking for a game that is full of 'whizz bang' action- this is NOT it.  If, however, you looking for a thematic sense of the rise and fall of your own little Empire (Mine is Freedonia- Hail, Hail FREEDONIA, Land of the BRAVE, and, THE FREE!!!)  *Apologies to the Marx Bros.* that is a constant tightrope balance, you'll like this game.  In a lot of ways, its like 7 Ages- but without a lot of the tedious elements that make 7 Ages take so long.  Quite good game, highly recommended for Eurogamers looking for a good game with quite a bit of conflict, and for wargamers looking for a 'Euroish' building game that still has some very edgy conflict.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Posiblemente, el mejor juego de civilizaciones que existe. Algo abstracto, pero eso no le quita genialidad. Partidas bastante largas, pero es lo que se espera de este tipo de juegos. Las versiones corta y media están bien para aprender a jugar, pero se pueden quedar cortas. El juego de verdad es la versión larga, pero... se puede hacer larga xD Eso sí, este juego vale lo que dura.
Una pequeña cosa que no me gusta, es la importancia del poder militar. Si no tienes poder militar alto, vas a perder. Lo necesitas o, para atacar, o para que no te ataquen, pero como te quedes atrás en la carrera militar, va a ser muy duro. El juego recompensa atacar al débil, y creo que es el único y principal fallo que tiene.
Además, el factor azar también es alto, si consigues tener las combinaciones de líderes y cartas óptimas, es muy dificil perder la partida. Y al revés, si las cartas deciden no salir, si vas pensando en hacer una estrategia, se siente. Una pena que un juego tan grande como este tenga esos dos fallos.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Civilization is a genre created by game called Civilization. But to this date it's still unclear whether the boardgame or the PC game (by Sid Meier) is the trigger of the genre. It doesn't really matter anyway, since the elements inside are things that make this genre great.

- Span of ages in time, from primitive to modern.
- Different technologies to research, giving many abilities
- Different civilizations, giving each player different powers
- Explore the world and use it resources
- Managing population, happiness, and other resources to successful civilizations
- Complex gameplay

Those all the great aspects of Civilization game. And to some extend, Through the Ages nearly captures it all. Sid Meier should be proud, since it's inspired by the PC game more than the boardgame. Great game, great mechanics, all together in one. The randomized setup and how things are available game make it very high replayability. Luck has some part here, but ultimately the decision is the one that make or break the victory. A perfect situation for controlled luck. Combined with there are so many path to victory, I can say this game is perfect.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Components: The tokens are a bit too small for my taste. In general the iconography is very clear. Good layout of information. Linen-coated cards. The various tracks are a bit confusing.

The income tracks (science and culture) are perhaps harmful to the game. Yes, it saves me from having to add up my income every turn. But if I forget to adjust the track, it could be several rounds before I realize the error, and now it's too late to adjust my income. Better to perform a full audit each round.

Experience: Simple production system (food, resources), but the cards lead to quickly differentiating strategies between opponents.

So far I've only played the beginner game.

First Played: 2011-04-24
Last Played: 2013-02-18
Eagerness to Play Again: Soon

Plays (2):
2 players: 2

RATING: 9
This is a masterpiece. This game recreates a lot of the aspects involved in the growth of a civilization, politics / people / culture / resources / military, with cards. Every game is different from the previous, thanks to its enormous amount of cards. I played it twice in a week after learning the game (advanced rules, not even full rules),one with 2 players and one with 3. I believe the game with 4 players could be even more rewarding (I'll try it someday with another good friend) but even longer and slower than with 3. The downtime between players could be a little high, you've got a lot of actions to pick from and the first games are a little slow. Gets better with repetitive playing of course. One of my favorite all-time games. EDIT: after more than 150 plays, I believe that political cards draw is a very strong but random factor. You can be the strongest for 5 turns and never draw an aggression card. Or you can be the weakest and never draw a defense/colonization card. This is very luck-depending and my vote went down from the initial 9.5.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I played just a few times, but I don't like the enormous downtime in the game. I also don't feel like the game progresses in any way. Time passes, but nothing really changes which makes it rather boring. I'm also disappointed with the event cards, that benefit the leading players while punishing the ones that are behind. It seems rather cruel and it's something I've yet to see in any other euro. The design of the game is also questionable. The scoring board is totally counter-intuitive and I think that the player boards should denote in some way which buildings are public and which are not. I'll have to try it with less players (we only played with 4 so far) and see if it goes any faster, but for now - I don't really like it.

RATING: 8
One word: Epic.  

The time requirement is going to prevent this from being played as often as I'd like, but I still hope to get it to the table frequently.

There is so much going on that it can feel quite daunting, but if you power through the initial overwhelming feeling, there is a fantastic game to be enjoyed.

There are many moments of frustration when you aren't able to do everything that you want to do when you want to do it, but it is a good frustration.  It's not like the Agricola frustration, where you know you are going to be punished severely if you make a mistake or are a turn late with a certain move.

I enjoy seeing and experiencing how different cards interact, and expect that the variety present will keep this game interesting for a long, long time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Plays: 2
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I never thought a civilization game could be any good without a map but Through the Ages proved me wrong!  Love how all the concepts of a civilization game have been abstracted out to a few decks of cards.  There are a lot of different ways to accomplish what you want but you can never accomplish everything you need.  I love that type of tension in a game.

I only have two minor complaints.  First, it very much encourages you to bash on the weakest player.  So long as you understand that going in you'll be fine; the game is very much an arms race and military has a very cold war feel to it.  Second, Through the Ages has had one of the worst print runs ever, constantly plagued with print errors and poor components.  Would love to see some sort of deluxe edition that really knocks it out of the park.

Fantastic game though.  Yeah, it takes a bit to play but it's absolutely worth it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

Note: I now have played and own the revision of this game, and much prefer it.  The rules changes and graphics overhaul have fixed my problems with the game and made it more enjoyable to play.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Looking forward to playing this Civ game
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
"Sid Meier's Civilization for the PC, the Card Game!"

Well, not quite. 

Civilization on the computer has both a strategic and tactical component, with the tactical in this case being the minutia of how to grow and advance your civilization. You struggle with ever-constant decisions throughout the game by having to overcome limited resources, deal with military threats, and get your society out of the dark ages via the advancement of science and theology -- all while trying to keep your people happy and content. You make your choices and the computer calculates the consequences of your decisions.

Through The Ages strips away the strategic element of of the PC Civilization experience and instead makes *you* the computer, wherein the traditional eurogame pastime of pushing cubes back and forth across a tableau now becomes the means of the calculation, thereby making what was merely a function of CPU cycles in the background now the actual game itself. Oddly enough, it works.

My only complaint -- hence why I rate it a 7 instead of an 8 -- is that the game takes way too long for what it is. This is exasperated even more so if you've been exposed to other Civ-type games that occupy a similar headspace (Chudyk's Glory to Rome and Innovation come to mind). I've played with three and with four, but now I find myself hoping from now on that I'll only play it with two...even if that makes for a comparatively lesser experience.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6

RATING: 9
El juego es redondo, todo en este juego fluye y encaja a la perfección, hay muchas posibilidades para ir mejorando la posición de cada jugador en la partida, no todos tienen que ir a lo mismo. El tema militar está perfectamente encajado, es como una guerra fría, si te quedas atrás todos irán a por tí, de manera que se ven pocas guerras y agresiones si todo el mundo se mantiene en la carrera militar. Las cartas dan opciones a todos, no hay que ofuscarse con tal o cuál tecnología/maravilla/líder, siempre saldrán otros más adelante. Es un juego en el que se premia al que es capaz de conseguir cierto equilibrio en cuanto a crecimiento/producción/ciencia/poder militar/descontento/cultura ... Un juego genial !!

La pega es que hay mucho tiempo de espera entre turno y turno, el juego es largo, pero es divertido, no lo veo un problema, lo que sí es un problema es la espera mientras juegan los demás.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
My initial rating was based on a single play at a game night.  The more I read about the deep strategy, the more I wanted to play again.  Also heard it is an excellent 2 player game, so I finally bought the game, but haven't gotten it to the table yet.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
First play was long, but was so much fun that time flew by.  Current plays are now about 1 hr/player.  More enjoyable than Civ/Adv Civ and plays in half the time.  I appreciate the small box and smaller area the game takes up, but the tiny discs make setup a pain.  The FRED rulebook is pretty bad as well.  Several areas in the rules are not clear (i.e. discontent workers, military discard pile), and if you're playing any version other than the Simple game, then you'll be flipping around all over the rules looking for setup and rules inquiries.

As for the gameplay, it's pretty darn perfect.  There's a steep learning curve, and the game is quite fiddly, but once you get a game or two under your belt, you'll be glad you put forth the effort.  There are so many directions in which you can take your civilization.  Will you lead in military? Science? Production? Population? Or a combination of the above? What kind of a government will you enact? What wonders will you construct? etc.  All of this is there, and more.  This game has a tremendous amount of tension in it.  You'll always be short something, whether it's resources, science, or actions.  How you best deal with these shortfalls is what will determine the winner, usually.

The designer has come up with a great system where multiple players can all affect one another, since there is no "map". Scales wonderfully from 2 to 4 players.

Edit: Lowering my rating a bit, as I've played this so much online and in person, I've become a bit burned out on it.

RATING: 8
This game's ranking is well earned. It overcomes its many minor flaws (lackluster art, tiny and difficult to handle counters, lots and lots of rules) through shear depth of play. I have only played two-player games, but even so, every game is truly unique, and the timing of cards means that each player's strategies change multiple times during each game. Both tactical and strategic thinking are needed, as well as a small degree of luck. Above all, though, the game is fun. It's not short and it's not quite elegant, but it is a great game.

THROUGH the AGES
A STORY OF CIVILIZATION

RATING: 7
A clever and thematic civilisation game that does the tech tree development side of Civ very well - echos of the computer game abound. The conquest/military side of things is not so well done - partly because the game plays so long with more than 3, and the nature of the military engine only works properly with more than 3.

The lack of a board doesn't feel right for me given th level of detail in the mechanics. Because of the long playing time it can incur the 'multi-player' solitaire epithet - i.e., apart from the military aspect of the game the player interaction requires a careful assessment of what other players are doing and therefore what cards they would like to pick up. However to keep the game moving along you really only have time to optimise your selections for what would be good for your own tableau. This is often a problem with build an engine euros but more so with Through the Ages due to the playing time.

RATING: 6
I ordered Through the Ages on a bit of a whim. I had been aware of its Top 10 position for a while, and had largely ignored it because of its length and weight. As time has gone, however, I have grown to appreciate heavier games more and more. In addition, I am a big fan of the Civilization computer games, having played 2, 3, and now 4, and I had heard that the board game had structural similarities to the computer game. So I bought it and played it. I was not disappointed. I ended up playing the game a total of four times over the course of 4 days, with three of the games being 2 player and the fourth a 3 player game. Based on those plays, it easily assumed a position on my Top 10 list.

Update: I think my current rating is probably a hard cap on how I can rate the game. It will probably not go down, but it definitely will not go up. Its length is too much of a drag on the game, as both of my three player games have taken 4 hours+, and that is more than I usually want to spend on a single game. Three hours? Sure! Three and a half hours? Probably. Over four hours? Eh, that is pushing it.

Another Update: This game has been coming out a bit more lately and I have been enjoying it a LOT every time I play it. This is enough to tip it over into nine territory. The fact that we are finishing in 3 to 3.5 hours now has also been very, very nice.

Session Reports:
http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/398095
http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/396505
http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/398754

I have grown tired of Through the Ages, partially because I have started to win it every time using essentially the same strategy, and also because of my general fatigue with Civilization games of this type. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Players develop a civilization, from Antiquity through to contemporary times.   Players take turns to spend "actions" (civil and military) to do stuff - populate, increase their food or resource production, construct buildings - forces - mines/farms, draft future purchases off a Show Manager-esque track of diminishing price, and so on.  A lot of the game is low level shuffling of cubes and beads from card to card, which changes the effect of the piece moved (i.e. yellow beads start as potential population, turn into people, and become a building/soldier when allocated to a card).  The scope of the game is astonishing, and much beyond a short paragraph here.  You begin with almost nothing, but must grow an economy, while keeping the people happy, the corruption down while the science and culture (VP's) increase.  An excellent, almost faultless rulebook presents the rules in 3 chunks of increasing complexity, gradually adding in aggression, wars, pacts, etc.  The cards are excellent, but the rest of the playing material is only so-so (the slippery glass beads were replaced by cubes very quickly).  The game is long (two player "introduction" games take about an hour, but it goes up from there).  We're knocking off the two player full game just inside 3 hours.  Rating has climbed with each playing - after eight games I'm convinced that it is top shelf.  Excellent, well designed game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fantastic game. Set aside an afternoon for this one, as the rules explanation alone can take up to 45 minutes. Games are typically three or more hours. Rating would be a 9 if it weren't so long.

RATING: 9
I consider this game to be a crowning achievement in game design.  The mechanics of the game are simply brilliant, and the game elegantly and yet complexly gives the feel of civilization building without needing to even bother with a map.  Everything in this (incredibly compact) box just works, and it works well.  It rewards multiple plays, it carries its theme pretty well, and it packs a LOT of game into a small, efficient package.  One of the all-time greats.

RATING: 7
March 2013 - I've played this game atleast 30 times and I've changed my rating to an 7 - in my opinion, most games play out in a similar fashion; someone falls behind in culture, realizes that the only way to win is go military and switches to a military effectivly switching everyone elses strategy to a military strategy as well. Additionally, I don't like the decision that I'm often presented with - if its close between you and someone else, you'll often have to attack the player in 3rd or 4th to have a chance to win...I hate making that choice. Finally, this is a much better computer game/app than board game.

June 2012 - I've been playing this a ton online. My rating of the game is now a 10 - it's so good, I'd never turn down a game. With the online implementation, there's none of the cumbersome bookkeeping. Definitely a game that has grown on me. I can't stop thinking about it and definitely want to play it more.

Initial comments after playing at Origins 2010:

RATING: 6
A tough game to rate, and one that might raise after future playings. The customized civs, each creating different unique empires, is done perfectly. Also the use of famine, unhappiness, and corruption act to check some of the runaway leader issues in a realistic fashion. The randomness in cards and events creates tons of replayability. My only gripes are the constant fiddling with resources and the lack of psychological interaction with my fellow players. More of an exercise in accounting and optimizing, but at least a very flavorful and engrossing one.
 
Rating is tentative and may raise after playing the full game.

RATING: 9
Rating based almost solely on 12+ 2-player games, only 1 3-player game in the mix.  That said this game is excellent.  I normally enjoy a more 4X-oriented game with a map and such, but this game does a great job of giving you the feeling of the challenges of lifting up a civilization from scratch.  Card drafting dictates the feats your civilization is capable of, and worker placement dictates which of those benefits you can reap.  Resource scarcity is always a problem, but it doesn't feel as crippling here as in some games; you can accomplish what you want with the right plan.  I haven't played the new edition of this but hopefully they fixed some of my complaints, such as imbalances with wars and that obnoxious Michelangelo card.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
2011\08\06:  This is a great Civilization game.  Now I understand why it is ranked so highly.  I had gone 8 months between my two plays, and it took quite a while to get back up to speed.  I am really looking forward to playing this again soon.

2013\03\17:  Had a four player "short" Advanced game last night.  For starters, this game is best with three players.  With four, there is way too much downtime.  This title also suffers from the same problem [thing=31260][/thing] does:  You can be easily 'steamrolled' by experienced players who have intimate knowledge of the cards.  Best played with a group of equal experience.

In my three hour game, I had about 90 minutes of fun, which was around the time the most experienced player pulled off the Michaelangelo + Bascillica combo and was garnering 16 points per turn.  This is a borderline game-breaker in the Advanced game for me.  My personal rating has dropped from 9 to 8.

RATING: 10
Great civilization game.  This has been what I have been waiting for since [gameid=71].  A longer complex game, but not as long as or complex as [gameid=71].

Basically a "meaty" game that takes some time, but it won't take all day or a weekend to play.

I love playing this game, and it is my favorite strategy game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The game mechanics aren't as complex as it might appear, but there are a ton of cards to work through and plenty of opportunities to customize your overall strategy.    It's essentially a VP-churning civ-building game, with four resources:  people, science (light bulbs), rocks, and food.   There is an element of engine-building here too, as your resources feel like they can go up exponentially if you do it right.  Consumption and corruption provide the necessary diminishing returns. The aggression and war cards are handled in a simple way, but the ramifications can be far-reaching.   One warning, however:  this game is "fiddly" to the max.  You are constantly sliding tiny bits and cards all over the place - if you can't handle that for 3-4 hours, then look away.  I appreciate the different strategies that can be pursued and the high number of effective card combinations to explore.

It's ironic how so many people say that they will only play this online or electronically.  Silly.   At that point, why not just play the computer game Civilization?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
I loved this one at first, but soon discovered that it's FAR too unforgiving for a game of its length.  Make a mistake or two and you'll sit there through hours of getting pounded while having no recourse whatsoever.  It's still fun to play as long as nobody screws up!

Love the game play, though.  But after it was updated to "A NEW Story of Civilization," I got the new version and donated this old one to Goodwill in August 2016.  After buying the new version, I didn't think I'd be able to interest anyone in trading for the old version, so I just donated it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.75
This is another of those games that I recognize as mostly good without any real desire to play it myself.  I should want to play it: I love civ games and long heavyweight strategy titles.  I don't know whether it's the length, or the lack of a map, or the randomness of the cards and events, or the extreme restrictions on your actions, or the massive importance of military buildup, or the fact that you need to play 3 successively more difficult teaching games just to learn the beast.

The downtime may be the worst thing about it.  You really want to play with 4, so there's some good competition for the cards, tension in the auctions, and a middle ground in the arms race.  If you do, though, you'll be sitting there doing nothing for large chunks of time while the other players take their turns.   Last time I played, I actually broke out my DS during these periods. 

Even players who really like the game seem to acknowledge its flaws.  I've heard complaints about the timing of cards coming down through the display, such that you might not even get a shot at the one you need.  Getting the right military cards (not selected,  but drawn at random) also seems to be an issue.  You can have the dudes, but be stuck with an out-of-date formation for the whole game.  Or, you can have the overall strength, but no way to exploit it w/out the wars/aggressions.  This is also one of those games where knowing the cards in the deck is a huge deal.  Which leaders work with your strategy, etc.  It seems like having the same main deck every time and seeing the same cards every game would hurt replayability.  

It doesn't look like much, I have to say.  The art is very spare, and the components tiny.

Any way, I may have to try it a few more times to decide for certain.  It seems likely that those will be online games, since that's how everyone around here seems to play it.  Haven't really rushed to do that, as I prefer face to face for my board games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A more abstract, and probably more fun civilization game than Sid Meier's Civ.  I've really gotten to dig this game, with some good replayability.  It takes a while to play, which is the only downside I can think of.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Finally got the game! The only thing that held me from getting it is because it has no map (I know it should'nt be matter). When a friend is selling  his used copy (only few times played) at a good price, I grabbed it in an instant.   

Played the game for the 1st time on 8th July 2013. My first impression is that what an amazing game. It doesn't need a map, it's just brilliant even without one! The game has bookkeeping and I normally dislike it (to a certain extend) but I like the one in this game.

I understood why the game can take so long. The fact that you need to finish all the cards in the whole deck of an age before moving on to the next age is the main reason, other than player taking their turn.
 
It's probably has become one of my favorite game just like that! It's also my very first Vlaada Chatil game that I've played although I own his other designs. It really deserves the top 5 BGG ranking.

The rulebook is hard to grasp and I was fortunate that a friend was willing to help.

My copy is 2nd Edition 1st printing by FRED. It has been corrected with the fix pack.

[b][Update][/b]: I've scanned the player boards in the recent editions and made a copy for myself as earlier edition doesn't come with these boards.

RATING: 7
this is possibly my favourite euro. And i do consider it much more a euro than a true civ game. Its a game of collecting the right cards and managing your economy (spreadsheet) to get those precious vps. It does tell a bit of the civ story and theme through the cards but you could easily swap the theme for running a shopping centre or anything else that passes through time.

There are a ton of cards with this game, that provide plenty of variety, numerous ways to score points and a challenging econmic engine to build and manage. Its very easy to shoot your self in the foot by the mid game, or through use of the military cards, shoot someone else in the foot. being a card game, theres a little room for bluffing too. Works best with 3 in my experience.

RATING: 8
While this isn't something I would like to play all the time because of its length, it says a lot about a game that I cannot possibly win that I would rate it so high.  We played 3 games back to back and I never got any better at it.

While the game has a runaway leader problem, I ultimately think it's just because of my poor play.  I think this is just a game you need to 'get' in order to maximize your engine and I have yet to reach that point.  I don't know if I ever will.  Despite my inability to create a scoring machine, it's still fun to try to maximize the efficiency of your turns and just go at it.  The downtime, however, even at 2p, is insane.  I can't imagine playing a 4p game.  I would lose my tits!

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Being a huge fan of Sid Meyer's Civilization on the computer, I decided to pick up this game. It was a tough decision because there is now a Sid Meyer's civ board game, and I didn't know how to choose, but this game got better reviews so I took a chance. I am so glad I did, after 2 plays this game rocketed up to my absolute favorite game on the shelf. Past old favorites like Pandemic, Power Grid, Ticket to Ride, Last Night on Earth, and Agricola. This is the first Vlaada Chvatil game I have played, but I really enjoy it. At first, the rules are very daunting, and this is not a game to just jump into blindly. The first game I played seemed like it took forever, and I had to reread the rule book afterwards to find I had make so many mistakes it wasn't funny. After the 2nd game, the rules made more sense and the game flowed nicely and we were able to get into the more advanced ages and really have some fun. I will admit that I have tinkered the rules a little (house rules) but mostly this game is great right out of the box.
