=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Enjoyed my first game played of Through the Ages. It gaved me a good idea of the game mechanics. Played 1st era only. It's a very long game.

As much fun as Civilization by Avalon Hill. Lots of different routes you can go. Looking forward to my next game to better know the cards. 


Played a second game. It was a two player game and played through almost the 3rd age. I had the least military starting about the mid game, (before it was very close, sometimes we had the same amount), but I still was able to get 3 colonies. With James Cook, I got lots of culture points with my colonies.

I was leading in culture points by a huge margin. In the 3rd age, my cousin develope more a military edge over me. He did 2 raids. He destroyed 3 of my Iron Mines and 3 Jornalism urban buildings. Journalism was giving me 2 culture and 2 science points for each building. He received lots of rocks to build stuff at my expense.

We stop when the pile was getting low in the 3rd age. It was going to be a tight race. When we stop, he was doing more culture points than me. In his hand he had 2 political cards which I lose 7 culture points and he gains 7 culture points. So right there, he would of closed in with 28 points.

I had a runaway lead in culture points at the end of the ancient, 1st and 2nd ages. In the 3rd ages with his political cards and a bigger army than me, he turned the momentuam a in his favor.

Next time I'll know how powerful 3rd age political cards can be. Also, that in a 2 player game,we can't do a pact to save our asses.

*UPDATE*

Though, I enjoy this game very much, one thing I do not like is in the last era, it`s too much of a wargame for my taste. Start of the game is excellent, the end not so much in my opinion. If you are not high on military, get ready for the mother of all ass-kicking. My end game wasn`t fun at all. I was like, what am I doing wrong? I had a very strong start.

RATING: 8
For my taste, just the bit too long for what it delivers. Plus I genuinely suck at it (4 games, 4 times last), maybe this does make me biased ;) Unfortunately this will not get too much table time due to its length, but I know I will want to play it until I'm not last once...
In total, very good and extremely cleverly designed game. Fun factor is low, but enjoyment is high nevertheless. That is, until you look at the time at the end of the game.

Edit after 4 real and 10 or so online games: I show symptoms of addiction. Last time I felt this was when I played chess in my teens. Still pretty much suck at he game, but when I win it feels like a grand achievement as it's probably due to above average concentration and focus.
Luck factor is considerably high as noticed in a solo 2p play. Player 1 was ridiculously ahead in military, but player 2 drafted all aggression and war cards.

Edit after a few more games:
For me, more fun online than in real life, which casts a shadow on its qualities as an actual board game, but this is subjective. Needs a lot of play with the right group to be enjoyed. A niche product with a tremendous fun factor for the target group.

RATING: 8
really super interesting super absorbing game ... lots of choices and every choice leads down a differing path ... everything you do has to balance, and the military has to be looked at very well, as you just do not wish to lag behind ... this is THE civilization building game, every move matters -- if there is one complaint -- it plays far too long , not many will sit over the table to play in person, which is a shame; also there can be many fiddly pieces and one has to remember the rules as to when each age ends, which leaders and how much population are dropped -- great for on-line play, and the positives far outweigh the negatives -- one needs a ton of experience in this game to compete -- with each play , this game just grows and grows -- a serious winner
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
game works and is fun to play. likely would never play with 4 (far too much down time).
the game is highly fiddly as you move counters back and forth, on and off cards, in addition there are many small rules involving card interaction that need to be learned and understand or you spend extra time looking them up in the rules. (that said the rules address all of these very well).
A good number of these rules could be removed with little effect on gameplay. For example .... Wonders taken after the first one cost an additional action point for each existing wonder you've built. does this rule impact actual game play yes a little, would the game change with the elimination of the rule, essentially no... but if I remember the rule and you don't you gain a big advantage especially early due to the compounding effect of an extra action. So you really have to police everyones actions to make sure that the rules are collectively followed.... Another fiddly type of rule is that some cards have to be held for a turn and others can be played immediately...
why have this??? really has little impact.... 

However, the big reason for the lower rating is the game fails in its comparison to other games requiring a similar time commitment that scratch the same itch. for example antiquity is a quicker game, has cleaner game play with fewer exceptions, and and equal amount of strategic and tactical play. So i'd happily play TtA again, its just that I would choose to play other games first. 

I do not see a need to add it to my collection. 

lowered rating from 6.5 to 5.5 with additional plays... has serious beat on the trailing/weakest player issues, and a innocent mistake early can realistically eliminate a player when compounded with the pick on the weakest player issue... very hard to catch back up. 

Also, having played 4 times in 3 days, I can say that game play is pretty repetitive. most cards are essentially the same from era to era with a cost adjustment. Are there many paths to take, yes... do all the paths feel essentially the same. yes. 

(updated again- lowered rating to 4 - this game is a tough call, i like the idea of the game i just hate playing it as it feels like work and just way to fiddly)

RATING: 6
Difficulty rating this game. I find the game extremely interesting on one hand, but where the progression of the card drafting and micromanagement of one's economy, science, and cultural production (balanced with staying on your toes militarily)... where all of that draws me in thematically and I can appreciate it. But, the overall fiddliness and the fact that if someone snags "Coal" before I do, then I can likely never get it? That just flies in the face of the civ theme all together. It's just way too abstracted to hold my attention. Just as I am getting into it, the game will slap me in the face and say, "Aha! You are manipulating a spreadsheet!"

I feel like this is personally a "5" for me, but I leave it up at a "6". I will play this online when given occasion, but there are several other games I would much rather play than this.

RATING: 6
A good representation of a Civ game, but it has its flaws. The buy-in is huge and will take several games to even learn the finer points of the system. Recommended only for hardcore civ fans willing to play many, many games.

RATING: 7
Played once.  A good game, but has some flaws.  Lots of little round markers to track various in-game attributes, and lots of shifting around.  My main complaint, however, is that the game encourages stronger players to beat up weaker ones and various events punish the weakest player while giving rewards to stronger ones.  Still, this is fun if you like to build up civilizations -- it's very good for that.

RATING: 10
Had this one for a coupe years now, have played numerous times both IRL and online, and still consider it the best boardgame I've ever played. Especially after playing the comparatively simpler and clunkier Nations, I've come to realize just how elegant and balanced the design of Through the Ages is. The art is terrible, and manipulating those little dots (especially the white one) is rather tedious at times; but these are nothing next to the brilliance of the game overall.

Best.

RATING: 9.5
A highly rated civ game - a genre I enjoy immensely.  Doesn't have a map though, and warfare is somewhat abstract.   And can be quite lengthy (esp. with four players - but great with two or three), but it has the civ elements I like.  Enjoying tremendously after several plays of the Advanced game.

Criticisms made by others: fiddly and too much spreadsheet accounting, too long, too much downtime, too multiplayer solitaire and not enough interaction, warfare is too abstracted, poor quality components. Concern: [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/317535]is it really an advanced version of St Petersburg[/url], i.e. a resource management/optimization euro game with an economic engine and a civ theme, rather than a true civ game with random events etc?  As [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/386394]my review[/url] indicates, this is a true civ game.  

One lingering question: why is the weight so heavy?  

Own the updated 3rd English edition (strictly speaking the 2nd edition, 2nd printing), which has improved the components.

Potential solo variant [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/651137/soloplay-variant-for-through-the-ages-is-now-avail]here[/url].

If playing the Advanced rather than Full game, consider removing Michelangelo, as described here: [thread=310504][/thread]

See my comprehensive pictorial review: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/386394

Updated version here: [gameid=182028]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Awesome game that lives up to its reputation as the best civilization game ever. Far better than SM:TBG by FFG, and I doubt anything will ever eclipse it. The decision to eliminate the map was brilliant as it's not needed. The advancement of your civ is all in your techs. As a fan of action points, I'm in heaven here. The pull between building more stuff of what you have, taking cards, adding military, or contributing to a wonder is endlessly interesting.

Now for the chinks in the armor. I don't like the game with 2P (had a very wonky play of that) and will only play with 4P if they're very experienced. Three people seems to be the target number for this. Furthermore, I'm still not sure of the claim that players who know how to use Napoleon/military will rule such that it's a crapshoot as to who gets Nappy. I will say, I used to think Michelangelo was overpowered so perhaps that will prove false here too.

The components of the 3rd edition (2nd printing) suck. I highly recommend buying the new 2009 version as it has fantastic pre-printed player mats.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Less than the sum of its parts? I thoroughly dislike the handling of military matters - warfare without manouevre. I also dislike that my civilisation can have the pyramids, Genghis Khan and the scientific method in play concurrently. In fairness, many of these criticisms are equally true of other civ games.

Still, at heart it's a spreadsheet.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The resource production and usage is so complicated here that it takes a lot of experience to really start to figure it out.  The card drafting, military mechanic, civil and military actions, tactics cards, etc. interact in a way to make the game varied and interesting.  Also the length of the game with the three primary ages really forces players to transition from strategy to strategy to reach victory.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Through the Ages has to be commended for providing Civilization-like gameplay in boardgame form. Even without a map, it provides meaningful player interaction through events and a shared card row. I especially like that almost every decision in every turn is important, compared to (for example) Civilization on the computer, where many of your turns may be spent doing boring upkeep and other mechanical decisions. On the flip side, there can be a great deal of downtime in the later stages of the game when each player has multiple actions to take, and sometimes the bookkeeping can get a bit difficult to keep track of (to the point that we have a computer program to do it for us now).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

x
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Rating history: 7|8|9|10|10|9|9|8|8|9

Played 9 times for 17.5 hours.
2p sim - 2 - very simple
2p adv - 4 - enjoyable, but take Michaelangelo out
2p ful - 3 - my favorite way to play as long as player are aggressive
3p adv - 1 - one AP player killed the experience


Nov 2009 - I'm actually writing this comment in 2014, and recollecting my initial impressions of the game. I remember it being unattractive and overwhelming. Lots to track and make work together, and not understanding well enough how battle tactics worked. I did however rate it a 7, and remember see some meat on the bones that I really liked, and I wanted to play it again.

July 2014 - Welp - that was awesome. Played a game of 2p simple and got a ton of rules wrong. (A. TON.) So we ended the game and didn't count scores. (We didn't understand costing correctly for building buildings, and paid the sicene and ore ONCE when the card came into play.) Played again immediately, had a blast. Up to an 8, easy, and hoping to play again soon.

Two days later, got an advanced game in and BLAMO. Upgraded to 10. Adding in the military deck was a blast, and all the decisions about both that and how to structure army. Also, bonus buildings, more development of infrastructure. Nice.

Just played 2p full game and it FLEW by. Definitely would be hard to go back to Advanced game now.First play of Full only took 2h45m, and we weren't racing. I think a full game is doable in 2h30m.

Do not play this with AP players. I just finished a 3p Advnaced game that took 4.5 hours. My turn - 60 seconds; player 3, 2 minutes; player 1, 5 minutes every single turn. This game is painful with that much downtime.

I've heard this described as "civ lite", but I should warm casual gamers that this is NOT "Civ lite". It's all the micromanagement of civ in a lite form; if you hate the micromanagement of civ, and only enjoy the exploreing and expanding (i.e. the map) then this game is not for you. When some people call it a "spreadsheet", they have a point. I still think it's fun, and theme translates well to a civ game, but it is still balancing a LOT of numbers. But that's part of what ruling an empire is, yeah?

Finally a Chvatil game I don't hate.

7th play: 8. Aug/14, 2p full. - Rating fell because of lack of conflict. Game needs some battling.
8th play: 8. 2p Adv - Again, little conflict. Adv game feels incomplete. 08/14
9th: 9. 2p Ful - One player turtled with two leaders, but comeback victory!
12th play: :star::star::star::nostar::nostar: The star is fading. The design is very tight, but I'm just not finding it fun anymore.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The first game 4 of us played was a full game and it took 7 hours.  2nd game, 3 players, 5 hours.  That is a little long, although I must admit it didn't seem to drag.  We all pretty much had our turns planned by the time it came around to us.  I am told a 2-player, full game can be done in 1 1/2 hrs.  If that is the case, I would rate it higher than a 7. 

Now I have raised the rating to 9.  Each player takes an hour to play the game.  3 players, 3 hrs., etc.
This is a gruesome game if some know the cards, and others don't.  I usually do not like games where knowing the cards and combo's is a huge, game winning advantage.  However, I played this game enough to know the cards, and I play with others on pretty much the same level (although I lose), so I am comfortable with this game.  It's is a game that needs playing on a fairly regular basis so I don't forget the cards & count--doesn't mean I will play the same way, but when I know what might be coming up I have a better chance of pursuing or changing strategies.

There is a big luck factor in the cards that turn up.  I like the game with 2 (best)or 3 players because while in your current turn, you usually have an idea of some card choices for the following turn (less so with 3), and can take actions tailored to a plan.  With four players it is far less likely any of the cards on the board will be available for you on your next turn.  Just a little more chaotic, which I don't like in this particular game.  

This is the only game I play online with an opponent, (a long time friend).  In-between emails, I have a lot more leisure to plot and read the cards, and my game is improving because of this.  In fact, I now enjoy this way best.  Thank you, Joel L. in NY!

2nd copy-$39
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Wonderful game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A close relative to the computer Civilization game.  Micro-management with tiny glass tokens and plethora of cards with varying effect and value.  I suspect that the game grows on you after a few plays which should cut down on the long play time.  Down time between turns has to be dedicated to planning your next move as much as possible.  Otherwise, we're looking at 6  hours for an advanced game.  I was intrigued enough to try it again at some point, but I will read through the cards to make sure I know what I am sacrificing in the future with my present choices.  My first "blind" attempt was fairly successful but I'm sure the next game will be very different.  Good replay value as experience helps a lot in this game.  Especially in cracking the production limits.  The cards are definitely not balanced so knowing which has the best bang for the buck for your particular setup is key.  Will play again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
There is definitely something here.  1st game took 4 hours with 2 other experienced players.  It seemed interesting, although I made a few crucial errors that hampered me during the mid to late game (not upgrading my farms and mines soon enough).  I made some classic early blunders, but overall it was a good learning game and helped me realize the need for consistently upgrading your investments otherwise your Age 2-3 stuff won't be there.

In the future, similar to Axis and Allies, I would only play this online.

RATING: 7.5
Molto lungo ma bellissimo
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Action point based civilization game that takes place over 3 different time periods

Pros
-Well balanced and well designed euro style civilization building game
-Thoroughly enjoyed the choices a player needs to on a turn to turn basis - e.g. which card do I need to take (how about my hand limit?), which cards can I play (with my limited resources), what infrastructure do I need to have in the near future (food, happiness, technology ???), and how is my military doing? 
-Some direct player/civilization interaction, and very neat political/event deck

Cons
-Long game length (3+ hours) not for everyone
-A few imbalanced/useless leaders (about 20-35% of them in my opinion)
-Very strong emphasis on military, aside from variant, encourages picking off weaker players (can lead to near elimination situations)
-After several plays, seemingly not many different strategies available (???).
-Somewhat fiddly. Hard to take back moves.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I like the absence of a map and the seeding of the event deck. There's too much upkeep that could be streamlined away, and military is brutal.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
There's and endless stream of small cards that crawl across the top of the board.  You have a player board full of tiny cubes to shift around.  Why do I love it?  Because it is full of theme and history and is not math based.  It's wide open and lets you combine elements as you wish.  Its streamlined and entertaining though it looks dull.  Great game to dig into.

RATING: 6

Coupled with the fact that military is so necessary, it quickly felt samey.  I wish all the duplicate cards all had a little twist to them.  It's quite possible after a few more plays here, the events will make up for it's other shortcomings.  We'll have to see.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I played this game a little early in my discovery of board games so at the time while I appreciated it, I didn't enjoy it then as much as I would today. 

This game has such a wide scope of decisions to make, and playing it is really, really satisfying. 

Unfortunately, it's also really long (though you feel like you don't have enough time to do everything you want!), not the most interactive, and has lots of bits and pieces to keep track of. So many places we missed rules and got things wrong. Also not the most interesting game to look at. All that means is that my fiance won't play it with me because he thinks civ games are much better on a computer and I don't know when I'll have a chance to play again so I can re-rate this. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Initial rating based on one play of simple version of the game.  A lot of fun, with some really interesting mechanics.  All of the fun of a civ game without the micromanagement of tech trees and army management.

My only concerns are the wait time with a full 4 players, and whether the full game will feel like multi-player solitaire (the simple version is -definitely- multi-player solitaire, but that's just fine for a tutorial.)

Must play again - wouldn't be surprised to see my score go up for it.

EDIT:  Played it again, this time with the advanced rules using the peacful variant.  It was a blast!  So many different paths to victory, and the game feels incredibly balanced.

EDIT:  Played it with the full rules - so much fun!  You really have to be at least prepared for war, even if you don't plan on going down that path.  Raised the score again - I hope this game will continue to hit the table.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Too long. Too much bookkeeping. Too many rules. Not enough theme. Not enough player interaction. Beat up on the weakest. There is almost nothing for me to like here and I think it probably deserves a one as I don't consider this one a game. To me its work. 

edit. Played three games online turn-based. Playing online helps to speed up the play time significantly and I can go do other things in the still significant down time. SO for that I upped my rating from a 2 to a 3

But the end still feels very random. The learning curve is steep. The time is long. But the biggest thing that makes this a dull game. Is the ending and the theme. After committing  a significant time investment in the game I don't feel like I made a civilization or created an empire. This is all a game of min/max.  The last game I played the winner had knights, swordman and the airforce... 

Except for wars, aggressions, pacts which come up pretty rarely (they can be devastating), this is a multiplayer solitaire at it's worst. I mean there is card drafting and you have to eye ball the table but I found that I am rarely able to block something that some.

This game is only for people that like think heavy euros. This game is not for me. I still don't understand why its ranked so highly. In truth I get the same enjoyment out of 7 wonders as I do tta and 7 wonders plays 7 in far less time then tta takes to play 2.

RATING: 9
You're basically only moving cards and tokens around. But somehow, even without the geographical aspect, this games succeeds impressively well in the "civ-like" genre. You could see it as yet-another engine-building game, but the effect of the cards coupled with the somewhat abstract mechanism of corruption and population just works perfectly well and you can "see" your civilization expanding or specializing. A very nice tour-de-force.

I tried the advanced version. I'm a little afraid that the full game would be too long.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
2013/08/15 UPDATE: Advice! This game is really tough and heavy, a "serious gamers game", in the whole sense of the word.  Definitely not the kind of game for a casual gamers (in fact, this game represents the antithesis of the concept "casual gamer's game").

I'm absolutely in love with this "built a civilization" themed game.  Brilliant mechanics. Perfect balance between choices-risks. Very small luck factor involved here: the game result depends almost totally on your desitions, never of a bad card drawing or something like that.
Perhaps the one and only problem I have with this game is its duration, 'cause it takes at least 4 -5 hours to finish a 3 or 4 players complete game (till the end of age III/beginning of age IV).
-------
I'm the very proud owner of a copy of the Spanish edition by Homolúdicus, wich includes 9 new cards inspired on Spain History (2 wonders, 2 leaders, 2 actions (yellow cards), 1 formation (militar strategy), and 2 events.

RATING: 4

To be honest, it's not really hard to see what detracts from my enjoyment here: Long downtimes with solitaire micro-optimization, overbearing importance of military advancement coupled with direct player attacks, extremely long playtime with a gradual ramp-up that makes you see the winner a few hours before the game actually ends or gives way to huge swings in the last age, and just a general tendency towards game state administration overload.

RATING: 3.5
I'm baffled by the high rating of this game.  It's not a bad game.  It was fun, but not fun enough to justify its length.  I guess the length is not bad for a civ game.  Maybe - I don't play civ games much.  

This game gives new definition to the word 'fiddly' (it includes very small wood shavings that are forced to pass for tokens).  Lots of downtime in a 4-player game - I'd rate it a 2.5 as a 4-player game.  Three players was okay, though.  With the downtime and the bits and the rating drops.  It's likely I'll play this again some time, but it's too long for our regular game night, and I wouldn't want to play with more than three players.

I'm deducting a full point for the inability to correctly count to 100.

RATING: 8
I received this as a gift from a friend, who then balked at attempting to teach me the game and declared that a four player game was out of the question.  Thus, it sat around for three months until I finally got the nerve to dust it off and was able to talk a buddy into playing a couple of learning games.  I'm glad I finally did - this is a terrific game - but I can see why the friend who gave me a copy was a bit dubious about having a go at it at the time.  The rules aren't so complicated as to be daunting, but it is awfully fiddly and there's a fair amount of bookkeeping involved.  And, while I'm looking forward to trying a three player game next, I'm pretty sure a four player game would be way, way too long.  That said, I'm stoked for more, if I can talk a couple of folks in my game night group into a relaxing round of Civilization the Board Game the Computer Game the Board Game.  Update: Having played a simple four player game we're ready to give 3-4 players a go on the standard game.  Brace for impact!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Vlaada sure knows how to make complicated rules systems relevant to game immersion. This is more complicated than I want a game to be, but because the rules are so thematically relevant, I enjoy it thoroughly. I would like the game to have some visual map of our empires and its parts. Scoring along various tracks is helpful for gameplay, but detracts from immersion.

All that said, in the 8 months since I have learned this lengthy game, I have logged more plays than any other game I have logged in the entire 3 or 4 years of logging on BGG. I suspect I have only played Chess more.

It is so so delicious. Every element of the game is tightly balanced with rewards and consequences. 

I have reached a point in my plays where my moves are moderately predictable. I need to shake it up, but I am not sure what to do.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Interesting game on civilization development. 

Pros: The lack of a map seems to alleviate the usual 3 player game difficulty where the first two players to fight basically hand the game to the third player. The mechanism for worker assignment and resource consumption works very well.

Cons: 
1. Very steep learning curve. I would suggest that when teaching new players you play two or three turns and then reset and start the game for real. This would add to the length of the game but it would enable the players to really screw up once without losing their first game by a humiliating margin. A new player should otherwise expect to be in last place and to consider it a victory if he scores more than half of the leader's score. 

2.  The game defines fiddly. However the many bits used in the game are essential. I do not believe tracks, dials or cards would function properly to deal with the worker placement mechanic. Just be aware that you will screw up at least once when you play the game. I suspect that even experienced players will forget to execute one of the many steps in the advanced game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
I'm rating it on what I think it could be; it might go up - it might go down. Chvatil's games are the type that you have to play dozens of times in order to get passed the fiddly game-bits downtime, player downtime, 1000 rules-lookups, and figuring out basic strategies. I'm mature enough to say he makes brilliant games, but brilliant like Chess, which is a game I know needs careful and thorough study in order to be good at it. I like games where I do okay half way through and then learn as I go on. By the next few plays, I've got a solid handle and rarely does confusion play a part in the game. With Chvatil's - I stink like shit, then I do horrible, then I do barely good. Putting all that energy into something that you'll only be half-good at after 16 hours of play, well, that's not my type of game. I've already closed the book on some of his other games, but TtA is something I would definitely want to try again, this time bringing in the Advanced rules.

Comment update: Through the Ages Second Edition is sooo much better and fixed pretty much every issue I had with first edition. Thank goodness! It's a great game!

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a fantastic game and I can see why as of November 2013 it is the #2 game on Board Game Geek. It is a very complex game and not for those who don't take the time to study the rules over good. It takes a few games to really get the hang of it due to the complexities of it. There are simple, advance, and full game variants. There are also variants for peaceful (non war) games. My first 2 full games with peaceful variant (two players) took well over 7 hours to finish. The full game can be very long, but with more experience players it can probably speed up quite a bit (but you have to have played quite a few games and understand how it works with leaders, science, mining, military, events, placing workers, building things, and making right choices with what's available).

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Very initial rating after 2 solo plays simulating 2 players. Advanced rules.
Probably too long and too much of a solitaire - for me the cards saying ,,do this to your opponent" are not really an interaction.
On the very other hand - the whole game is too much about the VP's. I mean - you've got 4 sliders: VP's, military, science, happiness, but in the end - the most important is to get more VP's every turn then your opponent.
I've got ambivalent feelings. On one hand - it was quite an enjoyable experience. On the other hand - come on, I'd rather play Caylus or Brass and I'm sure TTA will annoy me in the same way Dominant Species did.

EDIT
It is annoing, it is random at times. It does make you feel like you don't have anything to do sometimes. But it is SO addictive, that I can't resist to rate it 9. Maybe one day it would be even 9.5-9.9. Need a bigger surface to play and mainly with 2. With 3 downtime is too long.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.2
First two plays with 3 people everyone had a good time.  Played simple and advanced rules and finished in under 1 and 3 hours respectively.  I assume the full game would add another 2.5 hours on so the game length expands similarly to the number of days in Mage Knight.  There wasn't a ton of rules consulting which speaks to a certain elegance.  

The game is certainly a bit abstract as workers and buildings don't do a great job at implying the rise and fall of civilizations.  Still would enjoy playing a full game on a long patient night to try to become more efficient and focused while learning the ropes.

---- Was 8.8

Made it through a full game in about 4h with 3p.  It really flew by - this is very fun game that fills the time with a lot to think about.  The only 4h games I would consider playing these days are this and Mage Knight.

RATING: 7.7
After playing a large number of 2-player games, I almost feel like the 2-player game is "solved."  Generally if a player is disadvantaged by mid Age II, his opponent can play a denial game, and it is very hard to come from behind.  That is why I lowered the rating from 8 to 7.7

I would like to play 3-players, but it's hard to find opponents who can set aside that much time for a game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
As a game system, a solid 10. As a game to play, an unfortunate 1. As BGG ratings emphasize one's desire to play, I have no choice but to give this a 3.

Quite simply, TtA is a nightmare of fiddliness and possible mistakes. In a four-hour game with just two players, perhaps one hour is devoted to actual game playing decisions and card play. The other three hours? Administrative drudgery in the form of bit shuffling and and bookkeeping. Until a computerized referee and scorekeeper for this game is developed, TtA will remain, for us, an unbuilt wonder.

User fubar awol's comments are spot on: "Take St. Petersburg and add 5 times the fiddliness, 5 times the complexity, 5 times the game-length, 5 times the card luck and 20 times the between-turn down-time and you've got Through the Ages."
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I can see the appeal, and why people are so passionate about it, but it is long and a bit fiddly.  Plan is to try to play several game over the next couple of months to get on top of the game and get the time down.  If it won't fit into an evening it is not going to be played.

5 games in and it is starting to come together - Advanced game in 2.5 hours is doable in an evening.  Full game in 4 hrs (3p).  Still a bit fiddly but never feels slow 3p as you are planning your turn. Only problem is if the event on your turn changes things too much.  Any AP will kill the game.  4p can drag.  One issue for some is that it is very hard to check things - did I remember to collected the culture points for playing an event?  Did I remember to pay that extra action point for my second wonder?  Did I pay the food cost?  etc
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Well heck, another potentially overhyped game that was actually worth the buzz.  It's overwhelming at first and it does take some getting used to, but it is easy to see the potential in the game.  It is strange not having a map, and I confess that I sort of miss it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Definitely not in the Civilization class.  Our 4-player game took longer than regular Civilization (about 5 hours, which is what 5-player Civ has usually taken; 4-player Civ would be even shorter).  And there are a lot more rules than the much-cleaner Civilization. 

Still, it was interesting for one play.  No player interaction like Civilization, and I miss the geographic layout of Civilization, which really helps the game feel historic, and to have a flow (yes, I'm going to keep comparing this game to Civ). 

However, it seems like if someone gets behind in military strength, they are just screwed.  Using Aggression cards on a much weaker opponent costs almost nothing, has no risk, and yields free resources, which improves your position relative to everyone at the table.  Attacking the losing player is so clearly the correct play, it's a bit disturbing.  I suppose the answer is "don't get way behind in military strength," but that's not really a good answer.  The game should provide some incentive to attack the leaders, not the trailers.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Lackluster game that is too abstract and too long for what it is trying to accomplish. I generally like civilization type games, but was slightly bored the several times I played this one.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I like the game, though even the full game feels like it ends too soon - just as the best technologies are being drawn from the deck, but before you can get a return on them (or even get many into play). I seem to have more tolerance for long games than most people, YMMV. Downtime may be the games largest problem. If you aren't inclined to idle socialization during other players' turns you probably need to bring short filler games to any four-player game of Through the Ages.

However, I will not even consider buying (or trading for) the error ridden and overpriced FRED edition, which is short on components to boot. In addition to the typos and layout errors, the second edition doesn't include pact markers and there aren't enough cylinders for even three players in a full game, let alone the four specified on the box. It is unfortunate that Fred Distribution's poor QA and business model may mean there won't be another edition, but I won't subsidize incompetence or price gouging just because they scored a good license. Perhaps another importer will pick it up in the future, or perhaps Fred will learn from their mistakes. Until then, its similarity to the digital Civ series makes it easier to play that instead.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Components: good components, cubes are too big for the board
Complex: hard to learn and master
Weight: heavy
Players: 3
Length: 3 to 4 hours
Opinion: this is a game I like a lot, and I would like to like more. The theme is awesome, the pace of the game is amazing, but I am lowering the rating the more I play it. How you develop your civilization is really lovely, really strategic and, probably, a bit static (you do not have many options to change any strategy rapidly).
On the other hand is the war affair, do not get me wrong, I like the idea of a cold war, that you have to follow your opponent quite closer, besides that, how it works is very disappointing for me. No matter you do not want to go to war, you have to go if your opponent goes to, other way you are out of the game, the effect of wars are very annoying as you can be out of the game after 2 or 3 hours playing, and, if you want to be in, you have to play one way you do not like to. Moreover, once you have suffered a disaster like this, you can be the target of more wars or aggression... you know who to hit if you are playing and see a weak player.
I like the game, but the implementation is not my cup of tea, if I have to play the way others want, I prefer shorter games

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Condition: New
Edition: 
Math Trade Shipping: Free to CONUS via USPS or UPS
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Through the Ages is the best civilization game I've ever played, and it's not really even close.  Eliminating the map was a brilliant decision, circumventing many of the design problems that plague this genre.  The game presents tough decisions, it rewards planning, it resists stereotyped strategies, it excites, and it leaves me wanting to come back for more, again and again.

I'm especially impressed with the military system in Through the Ages. There are many ways that this could have gone wrong, but it's handled so well that it becomes one of the game's principal strengths. The military arms race regulates the pace of the entire game. Players who lag or procrastinate in their military development can get ahead of the curve in others ways, but they risk total ruin if they get too greedy. The military actions keep the game in balance, thwart the "perfect" optimization strategists, and allow an aggressive player to have a tremendous impact on the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Probably is the game best with 2 players, but then you can't use the pact cards. In any case I've bought the new edition.

Replaced by 4th edition, which is better.

RATING: N/A
2013-05
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The event deck can be frustrating when you place knowing that based on table-plays there's a 1/5 chance of being shafted, and yet it happens. The earlier in the game it happens, the stronger the butterfly effect is at the end scoring. Ag and Ore tech can be poorly distributed in the main deck (all towards the bottom, or 1 at the top [for one player only] and the rest at the bottom in a worse scenario). Going last is just strictly worse than going second, which is strictly worse than going first. If TTA was a 30 minute game, these faults wouldn't hold it from being a 10, but the game usually takes anywhere from 180 to 225 minutes with some considerable down-time. In spite of these faults, TTA is still a great game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Since I love civilization building games this was a no-brainer for me. There is both a sense of development and the struggle between specializing and balance. This is more of a civilization management game and less of a world domination. War is present and important in the game, but the most interactions are more indirect. That leads to a game where you try to build your engine to come ahead the other player, while still not being too vulnerable to what other players does to you. I sense that there is a pretty good replayability, but with time I want an expansion to the game, to stir things up.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Played 3+ 2,3,4 players. The 2 player game was to learn the rules. My one full game was with 4 players. I say full game but it was abandoned after a little over 4 hours when we could see we were only half way through. Through the Ages is way, way too fiddly. The concentration needed to track everything is more effort than fun. It is nice watching your empire develop but it satisfies few of my requirements for a good game. The down time is more extreme than in any other game I own, the guy at the back militarily is having no fun getting whipped turn after turn and regularly players are going to be knocking over their tiny pieces causing exasperation all round. Through the Ages stole my much anticipated, once every 6 months, 5 hour gaming session. For that I give it a “3” *UPDATE* Played again this time with 3 which is the only number I would now be interested in playing this with. It could well get played in another 6 months but only because I have access to no other games which will fill a 5/6 hour time frame with 3 players. It is so fussy, I promise you that at several points during the game the little cubes are going to get knocked and the players will be looking at each other trying to guess whos marker was where on the score track or which cards had what yellow cubes on them. April 09

UPDATE
Ok second game. This is an unforgiving sucker, you can easily get drawn in and have a hard time coping with all the demands your civilization needs. You need to plan things ahead and be very careful with what you do. 

A good thing is that you play for a long time, and during the course of the game you may have time to get out of the loop and play on your strengths. 

Do not ignore the military, if you do you'll be out of the game quickly.

RATING: N/A
Update: I have increased my rating to an 8, simply loving the two-player-game. For three and four players, I would rate this 7 and 6.5, respectively.

RATING: 8
After one incomplete play: I like it. There is a lot of depth and variety. 
Pros: 
Very interesting decision tree
Great variability in the game and play styles
Lots of options

Cons:
Length
Very fiddly (too many bits to keep track of)
Rule book difficult to use as a reference

The cons, though annoying, do not take away from the excellent game play. I expect my rating to go up after more plays.

This would be a fantastic game for online play.

UPDATE: Played a complete Advanced game finally. I still agree with all the Pros & Cons listed above, but the game is very engaging. Despite the length, it feels like it is just rushing by. It takes so long to develop your civilization, and just when it gets going the game is over (with the Advanced game). Maybe playing a Full game would mitigate that. Sadly, I don't know how often I'll get the chance to play.

RATING: 6.5
A good civilization game, but it is not that good when playing with more than 2 players. 3 Players, alliances are a not fun since you can either have 3 alliances and no one attacks each other or it is a 2 vs 1. In a four players + game, what happens is while you play your turn, everyone else is falling asleep because the player is inactive and has nothing to do... especially the guy that just did his turn before the current, he needs to wait three turns before he is allowed to play. That is a huge downside of this game. 

Another downside is that one edition came with super tiny blocks of wood that required thin nimble fingers to manipulate.

The good side is that you don't have a map where you move tiny pieces and takes room. Everything is abstracted.

Overall, it is a decent game worth buying if you can train people in playing it. Otherwise, stay away from this one, it is way too long to play with a large group since you do nothing when it's not your turn.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This game employs very interesting worker placement mechanisms; keeping track of one's population and resources is implemented in a surprisingly smooth and elegant manner. This aspect of the game has considerable strategic depth and is highly enjoyable.

What bothers me somewhat is the fact that the players' choices of moving their civilisations on to new technologies/ideas are determined by the development cards that are available. While there is a look-ahead factor involved in this aspect of the game, there is really no telling what cards will actually be available when it is your turn. 

This can result in situations in which a civilisation is nicely developed and ready to move on to new ideas, but there is just no interesting idea that is worth being picked up, and thus the civilisation stalls, whereas a badly struggling civilisaton is just lucky and has the opportunity to pick up instant VP cards or the badly needed bonus card. In particular, lucky head starts by means of strong leader cards are somewhat hard to catch up. 

Nonetheless, this is a really entertaining game with strong mechanics.

RATING: 9.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
1 play, advanced game, 3-players.  It's very fiddly (meaning it takes a lot of manual manipulation and bookkeeping); if that bothers you, then look-away.  Otherwise, it's a wonderful abstraction of a civ game into an economic engine game.  The civ aspect is mostly thematic, as you are indeed building a single economy rather than building up an empire, but this is necessary due to the removal of any sort of geographical maneuvering.  There are wheels within wheels, and many aspects to balance.  There seems to be multiple paths to victory, and I like the way the leaders shape your strategy.  The pact cards add a very cool diplomacy element.  It seems like the Advanced game leads to unbalanced cards and strategies since certain combos aren't given time to develop, or are active for too great a percentage of the game.  A bit long for the full game I expect, but the time flew by in our 3.5 hour advanced game.  There can be a lot of down time, but that seems like it will improve with further play.  Hopefully the reprint will make the bookkeeping easier, as the little gems - while cool - are too hard to manipulate, and you'll be doing a lot of it.

RATING: 6
The simple game is quite bad. There is no combat and thus little interaction with your opponents. Also, the tracks are quite fiddly. We are going to try this with the full game next. I'm sure my rating will improve then.

The full game is quite long. The pieces leave a lot to be desired. You have tiny dowels (3/16") used to track your workers, food and resources. These are simply too small. They roll all over the place and are difficult to use effectively. The game would be about 30 minutes shorter (and much more enjoyable) if it had components worthy of a game of this high rating.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I need more plays before giving this a 10 but for now I would always try and play it.

None of the negatives hold water for me:

1. Sub par components - they do the job just fine and the art has a charm of its own.

2. Long playing time - that's a group not game issue

3. Long downtime - not really if players play efficiently and avoid excessive AP

4. Fiddly - Not more than many other games

5. Runaway leader/ hit on the weak civilisation - Sure if you play badly and lose the game as a result. I want that not some pointless catch up mechanism for bad play.

6. Unbalanced - Everything is about managing resources in an optimum way. There are many ways to do this, there is no imbalance.

7. Not enough actions/resources/always feel left behind - welcome to a resource management game and it applies to everyone. This has to be the silliest accusation I have seen.

8. Wars and aggressions too easy/hard/imbalanced. No, the mechanics for this are subtle and it is all about trade offs and opportunity cost. Seeding the event deck is a great concept to ensure some tension and uncertainty. The threat of aggression or war can be more important than an actual aggression. Any player that ignores this will suffer.

9 Boring game -sure, it will be for some. We all have our own preferences. I love to see how my Civ develops over time and getting rewarded for earlier decisions or punished for them too.

RATING: 8

I would really like to slap their wrist for this kind of behaviour by not buying this game, but I'm honest enough to admit to myself that I would break down and hand over the money, if my friend hadn't already done it. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Fascinating game of balancing four or 5 different intertwining resources.  If you don't have enough food, you can't get enough workers, and if you don't have enough rocks, you can't deploy your workers as buildings or military units.  If you don't have enough happiness, you're effectively limited in how many workers you can deploy.  If you don't have enough actions, you can't draft as many technological advancements or other useful cards, and if you don't have enough science, you can't bring your technology cards into play.  And on top of it all, there are VPs (culture points), which are all that matter in the end!

Sadly, the first game that I played demonstrated that if you are far behind one player in military, then you're going to get attacked by him, and when you lose that battle, you're going to be attacked by all other players on every turn for the rest of the game, because they all get benefits at your expense.  So make sure not to fall behind in military units, because this game definitely rewards  a "kick the loser and avoid confronting the leader" strategy!  The fact that such a strategy exists annoys me.  I much prefer Advanced Civilization, where it's more profitable to attack the larger civilizations, because they have better commodities to steal.

The first game I played took 5-6 hours for 3 players; I hear that it takes about 3-4 hours once you know the game well, but I've played it a handful of times, and it always takes much more than that, because I take too long to decide (and because I'm not familiar enough with the game and the record-keeping required).  This is another game, like Advanced Civ, that could seriously improve with computerization to handle all the micro-management and speculative analysis.  Ironic, since this board game seems very inspired by Sid Meier's Civilization computer game...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A very impressive design
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game has some kind of "Mother of All Board Games" status in my mind. Don't know exactly why but I quess it has something do with the fact that it takes hours to finish and because of that it doesn't get played very often. It's almost like preparing for a real war when you start planning to play this game(not much war in the game though).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The best civilization game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My first game of this was painful. I spent more energy trying to figure out how to play than actually playing. The second game was much easier, but still cloudy. There are many interacting parts in the game. Your civilization is an efficiency engine made up of a bunch of smaller efficiency engines (farming, military, politics, mining, religion, science, etc). These are all difficult to build and balance, but the game throws a steady bunch of wrenches into all these works so that holding the civilization together is tricky. In my third game of this I was able to keep on top of the gameplay more or less, play a bit quicker, and think more about a long term plan for the game. Overall I like the game. It's long (4+ hours), but the arms race is quite exciting, and the game has produced some nice surprises.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very meaty and challenging. A great game that I should play more often. I'd bump this rating up if it had a funner war mechanic.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a card based game of Sid Meier's Civilization (certainly feels like it!).  If you enjoyed the PC version, there is no reason not to like this one!

The game flows well, but the full game takes about 6 hours to complete.

Seems to suffer from the runaway leader problem, as in a 3-player game our scores were close when around the 90 point mark, but the end was... well see for yourself:

238, 175 and 159

Still trying to understand what went wrong and why such a large point spread.  The person in the lead was ahead in every field, something which felt rather odd.  Perhaps she just had better card selections, as none of us lost a turn switching Gov't types, yet the spread between 1st and 2nd was 63 points (~30%), and with last it's 79 points (or ~50% of his points!?)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Simply wow. This is -the- game of civilization-based micro-management. While I recognize that this is either a huge "turn-on" or "turn-off" for many, whether it be the word civilization or micro-management that does it for you, this achieves what it sets out to do in spades.

This game provides mounting tension, as well as a resource race, and a bevvy of difficult but meaningful choices. While I have only played the Advanced game so far, I can only imagine the game escalating all the more so into a bonus-scoring arms race at the end. The card track, while nothing terribly new (even at the time) provides an interesting way for technologies of various sorts to increase in efficacy at a slow and steady pace -- while the consumption and corruption mechanisms prevent you from the excessive rush that is often encouraged in other games with economic structures. The military aspect of this game is, as the designer states, not blind aggression but rather a subtler system which you do not need to continuously build armies but if you do not ramp up your military, you will find yourself too weak to resist direct aggression or take advantage of very desirable colonial opportunities.

As a note, it is also a difficult game to teach, and my first teaching/learning game took time -- I can imagine that once everyone understands the basic mechanics, and can take care of their end-of-turn board management that the game can speed ahead at a much more reasonable pace.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Terribly long and complex. Yet... I keep playing it! There's a lot to like under that mountain of rules and chrome.

RATING: 3
这游戏啥玩应啊……冗长且无趣，还挺累脑
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is based on one play of the "short game", which is really meant to be an introduction to the mechanics. These are my first impressions...

Theme?! What theme? It's a freakin' spreadsheet!!! More fiddly than Antiquity, what is the fun in shifting a bunch of teeny-weenie wooden cylinders on some process flowchart in multi-player solitaire?! (breathe, breathe...) So I'm gaining technology points and culture points... big freakin' deal! (more deep breathing...) I was bored out of my mind while waiting during the interminably long turns, that I longed for the sweet release of death represented by the end of the game. (End rant)

The historical flavor seems to be forced with notable historical figures popping up in the linear card queue, and development is somewhat dependent on what shows up in queue. Population, food, resources, technology, and culture are highly abstracted to the point where I have no attachment to the gameplay; I'm simply collecting more blue and yellow cylinders to optimize my "engine" to collect more cylinders to turn into technology or culture points. There is no "board", so there is no expansion, area control or majority, like in some other civilization games, and in this vein reminds me of Phoenicia (a design I dislike), which seems to be a super-stripped-down version of TTA. I realize that I am not forming an attachment to this game because it has no visual appeal whatsoever, unlike Antiquity, Antike, Age of Renaissance, Civilization, Rise of Empires, or La Citta. (End second rant)

When playing a civilization game, I have been spoiled into expecting some kind of technology tree, but this is not immediately apparent in TTA, as it is dependent on what cards show up. Thus, the focus on collecting unique cards from the queue reminds me of Innovation (another recent design that I dislike), so this isn't doing it for me. 

I hear that the full-version should include more player interaction, with warfare and such, but that it is progressively longer to play, clocking in at four to six hours for a 4P game. I suppose I should be willing to give it a try before passing judgment. I also probably need to get up on the right side of the bed of the day I play this again. :-) It's a '6'.

Update (07/04/12) It's coming up on a year since that first play. With the exception of Prophecy, I have not enjoyed the handful of games designed by Chvátil. On the other hand, since I am now enjoying longer, more complex, epic games, I may have to revisit this with a proper "learning" game; I may even grow to like it. It has happened to me before: Antiquity and Age of Renaissance come to mind, where I didn't care for either of those two designs (but the aversion wasn't as strong as for TTA). For now, it is still a '6'.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
Okay, I guess.  My one and only play so far was with enthusiastic experts—stuff happened, and then it was over, and my score was tiny for some reason.  Not really hot to try it again, though I know next time could be different.

[size=7]NOTE:  The following issues are entirely my own and do not reflect on the others who taught and played the game; they were kind enough to include me and any inability to get more out of the experience is my own fault.

The above session highlights why I don't like learning new games out of the blue at game events:

1)  Unlike most on this site I don't consider myself good at games in general, and much prefer to read the rules ahead of time, then get a couple learning games under my belt before I'd even dare to think of myself as worthy competition.  A 30-minute hodge-podge of verbal rules salad just means I know enough to function as an idiot tool for the savviest players, or at least gum up the works real good.

2)  There was a definite clash of play styles here; I much prefer emergent narrative and hilarious storytelling, not quiet contemplation as cards are flipped to the occasional soft grunt and nod.  I get it that for most gamers it's the mechanical stippling of the gears as they roll through time that's the thing, but I'm compelled to connect those dots and create a unique story, a memory of the game experience that goes beyond "we played and so-and-so won by some number of points."[/size]

RATING: 6
Played the german version. Rating is only 6 because the graphic design is to old fashioned and illustrations are ugly (except the cover - the cover promises more than the cards and other game components can offer). For a game with a civ-theme, it appears to much focused on the mechanisms, it lacks of the real flavour, which could have been easily achieved by investing in better illustrations and graphic design. Thus, the components look very cheap to me and don't make me want to play the game.
And it is multiplayer solitaire, with massive AP, the conflict/aggression/war feels like pasted on to create the illussion of player interaction. 
My rating would be higher, if the playingtime was much lower, if the illusstrations and the very tiny wooden tokens weren't that cheap and if there was more real player interaction (if I want to play a war game, I play a real wargame).
I will play it again so, to see, if further plays will change my opinion on the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Not so much a civilization game as an engine game with a civilization theme. First and foremost I think this is strictly a game for 2. With more, playing time becomes excessive and there's simply too much temptation to keep attacking the weakest player which isn't much fun for them. When learning it's important to recognize some vital cards as they come down the track: Iron Working for one, certain Leader Cards and Monarchy all add a lot to the first civilization to get them in play, indeed the game really consists of opportunistically cherry-picking the good cards and ignoring the pap. This is my major complaint, the game doesn't allow really divergent strategies to develop, which cards are available on the track is very much left to chance and some are wildly more valuable than others.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Downtime is still a problem (and there's a limit to how much you can plan ahead when you have so many actions to work with!).  Looking forward to playing with two.

RATING: 9.9
Una obra de ingeniería lúdica. Combina muchas mecánicas sin que el juego chirríe ya que hay una buena cantidad de conceptos en él bien integrados: felicidad, corrupción, revoluciones, colonización, conflictos militares, cultura, líderes destacados... Largo. Épico. Debería venir con dos tardes libres incluídas en la caja. Buena mecánica la de acciones civiles/militares (varían en función del tipo de gobierno), la construcción de maravillas (consumen muchos recursos) y la de los pactos entre civilizaciones (para que haya interacción entre ellos). Cada turno es un ejercicio de control y ajuste económico. Contras: muy largo, acojona al más pintado empollarse todas las reglas. No tiene mapa. No tiene árbol de tecnologías. Pierde mucho sólo con 2 jugadores, aunque gana en agilidad y acorta muchísimo su duración.

[ENG]

A real game-engeneering work. It combines a lot of different  mechanisms without a crunch during the game: happiness, corruption, revolutions, colonization, military conflicts, culture, leaders. Long and epic. It should have two free afternoons inside te box. Favourite mechanisms: civil/military actions (they are different based on the current goverment), the wonders (they need a lot of resources) and the pacts between two civilizations (they give the game much interaction). Every turn is a tough control exercise and economic adjust. CONS: Long. Too long. And the rules are long too!! There´s no map, no technologies´ tree. It´s no good just for two players, but is shorter and more agile than the 3-4 players´ games.

RATING: 9
Agricola meets Civ-building and just as great (yes, I know this one came first, but I played Agricola first so sue me).  Like Agricola, Through the Ages really nails the feeling of having to do so many things but only being able to do a small fraction of them, while also adding a great narrative sweep to the whole enterprise.  I've only played the online version and am a bit hesitant to try the physical version due to the extensive bookkeeping and serious downtime issues that result from working through your turn multiple times to figure out the optimal moves.

RATING: 8
Suggest: Enthusiastic. Although new ver. seems to be superior in every aspect, I still like this very much.

1. The brutal nature plus the tactic-card issue is annoying. Hope the new version([thing=182028][/thing]) will solve this.
2. The downtime, the game length, and possible AP make the game far from being accessible.

It's a very intriguing game. After so many plays, I still wanna this :) I love this so much that I would rate it a 9, but the game has the flaws mentioned that can not be ignored.  But still, one of the best civ games out there.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
For those having played the Civilization video game, the parallels of the various mechanics surprisingly work their way well into this tabletop game. Tight action economy with inter-player opportunity cost make the "conveyor belt" mechanic of the cards more than just a shopping isle. Players can choose to pursue science, military, production, or culture directly to eventually win the game - keeping in mind neglecting the other tracks is a risk.

RATING: 4
Looked forward to trying this one.  The game sounded fun.  And I do like the theme of the game.  Creating a civilization...shaping it through the ages.  And it does start out fun.  There are so many choices that shape everything about your civilization.  And then it continues to be more of the same.  Sliding fiddly bits from one part of the board to another and upgrading one building into a slightly better version of itself....over and over and over.  There can be a lot of downtime.  Waiting for your turn to come around again while other players finish out actions can lead to phone browsing to pass the time.  Its not difficult...its just boring.  Hours later, I'm glad to see this one go.

RATING: N/A
Alfre
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.7
Nov08:  Alright, I'm done with it.  Let's spend some pros and cons time.

Pros:

Tons of variety in the cards.  You won't be able to use more than 20% of them in a given game, so there's always more to try out next time.

Plenty of resources to balance.  And multiple ways to get those resources.  Do you go high tech or just a slave army funded by colonization?

Time seems to fly while you're playing this game.  You don't really notice how many hours have gone by.

Cons:

Hours *have* gone by.  It will take multiple hours to finish any king of game.

The components are questionable.  Little discs had to be the stupidest choice ever made.

The accounting takes far too long.  In addition, everyone always forgets some part of it or their political action.

The payoff just isn't there.  And it's a little too abstract for me.  I don't look at my cards at the end and say "my, what a great little civilization".

Other games do the same thing in less time (Race for the Galaxy anyone?)

So for me, it just didn't cut it.

(Full disclosure, I played 1 2-player simple game, 1 2-player full game, 1 3-player full game, and I do mean the full 3 ages.)

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Through the Ages is a very meaty game with all the cards and the rather complicated rules but also manages to reproduce the tension of simpler, classic German games. At a high level it is very thematic, though the actual details often make no sense (e.g. an army combining ancient swordsmen with tanks). At first the game can seem too long, the rules too complicated and the number of cards excessive - but these issues fall away after a couple of plays when you have got to grips with the complexities and become familiar with the cards. Through the Ages has no major faults, offers several viable winning strategies and produces a different game with each play. It works well with 2, 3 or 4 players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
What an awesome undertaking, deftly executed.  This is not the much promised Civ Light.  Its is not particularly short, and it is not at all light.  That said, it is BETTER than either Civ or ACIV.  That's because this game captures a number of the clever mechanisms from Sid Meir's Civilizaiton, Computer game.  There is serious downtime, and the planning is constrained by the revolving card choices that can be vital to your turn.  Nevertheless, you don't complain because you get a feel that you are actually playing something epic, while you are playing this game.  Additionally, the game really encourages civilizations to develop along different paths.  Its something I wish were true of AH's Civilization games, but it just isn't.  If the play time were more reasonable, this game would be a 10.  As is, it is a fine game, that I will play again.  Sadly, its length will keep it from hitting the table as frequently as it should.

RATING: 8
Great game.  Complex, demanding, with lots of  possibilites.  A key to winning is finding a tricky and narrow path of balancing all aspects of your civilization (military, production, food, science, culture, no. of actions).  For me it's hard - one of the few games I cannot truly master after many plays.

  I'm really impressed by this design even if sometimes luck or just specific flow of the game - accidentally - bears too much weight on a gameplay.

2-3 players is the best for this title.  With 4 there's way too much of downtime.

[Interestingly many concepts (or at least terms, names) were taken from computer Civilization.  In fact it feels a bit like playing this Civilization, just without a map.]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5

I can never seem to get my military off the ground, some wonders are obviously better than others, and the way victory points are earned can mean someone could win by a long shot in the first age while the other 3 hours are a futile game of trying not to lose AS poorly.  Still, it's the best civ-building game I've played.

RATING: 6.5
The downtime between turns in this game is horrendous, given that each player performs all available actions followed by production/upkeep, before the next player gets a turn (compared to Nations where each player does 1 action on their turn only, then repeat, until everyone has passed before everyone does upkeep at the same time).

Despite this fact, I like alot of the mechanics in the game which i think are better than Nations. It's enjoyable as a 2 player, and while 3 player is probably the sweet spot, in order for the downtime not to suck the life out of the game, it has to be played with quick players.

RATING: N/A
