=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I've played more than 200 games of this.

Pure genius in game design. I love the many avenues to success (and failure), the anticipating and seeding the event deck, the difficult choices on limited actions, the military escalation (that varies every game.)

Many cool "little" things. There's a card that actually rewards the culture leader -- BUT it has to be "seeded" into the event deck and there's no guarantee you'll be in the lead when it hits. AND... when you put it in the deck, you're triggering a more immediate event that might bite you.

I don't think I've ever played a game where conflict is handled so well. Aggressions and wars have impact, but they're usually not game losing. And 90% of the time you can blame yourself if you lose one.

You can learn TTA in one play; the rules are logical and nearly perfectly integrated; As with any game of depth, there's a skill curve. You have to know the cards and when they come out.

Some very basic, general strategy tips if you're new:

1) Before taking any card, ask yourself "am I going to be able to put this in play any time soon?" A hand at your civil action limit can be very cramping.

2) Technologies and resources are dependent on each other. Having the Air Force tech won't help you if you lack the resources to build one or a population to man it. And conversely, you can have tons of resources with nothing useful to build. And, oh, your people want to (gasp) be happy. Occasionally things will fall your way where one thing will get way ahead of another, but don't overlook any one area of development. --  Find alternatives to compensate for short term weaknesses (action cards.)

3) Be aware of your opponent(s) at all times. TTA is NOT multiplayer solitaire.


TTA is my favorite meaty game for 2 or 3 players. 4-p works and is fun, but things are a little too much out of your control and there's too much downtime if you're playing live.

Just the right amount of luck. Just the right amount of bluffing. Just the best civ/economy game out there.

This is a 10 on BGO, and a 9 live -- fiddlyish and upkeepy (a new word.) A small price to pay for awesomeness. :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Through the Ages is a very intriguing game.  It has a lot of depth, with lots of choices and possible strategies.  It's also very fiddly so you have to not mind moving lots of little pieces around as you make each move to mark having taken an action, moving a person, spending resources, etc.  After every game I find myself thinking about what I could have done differently and coming up with new strategies.  There's not a lot of interaction aside from occasional raids etc. so there can be a substantial amount of downtime, although I find that I have to watch what my opponents are doing quite carefully to help them avoid making mistakes (the fiddliness) and vice versa so that helps.  The theme is quite weak so it's not clear what country you are and there is no asymmetry at all between the players.  It is missing the spatial aspect of civilization games, which I miss, but it's already plenty complicated.  So overall very fun but just shy of "best ever" category for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
== Super short version of comment

It's fun.  Buy it.


== Short version of comment

* It's fun.

* You have to think.

* Randomness does not dominate the gameplay.  You can plan ahead and react to the cards as they appear.

* Your mistakes will be punished. (Not "Age of Steam" punished, but you'll feel the pain of making stupid moves.)



== Long version of comment

I missed out on this when it was released at Essen 2006.  Instead of hitting eBay, I waited patiently for the reprint.  For a year, I read everything that I could find on the game, multiple times.  I was pretty anxious for it, but I was worried that I was building it up too much in my mind, and figured I'd be let down.

It was everything I hoped for and then some.  

The reprint itself has some production issues which are supposed to be fixed at some point.  I'm not disappointed that I picked this one up though.  The reprint as-is is very playable.

As for the game, you have to maintain a balance between production, science, culture, and military.   If you overproduce, corruption prevents you from hoarding resources.  If you don't build up your science, you can't pay for upgrades.  If you don't produce culture (i.e. victory points) you can't win.  If you don't keep up with your military, your opponent can punch you in the face via aggressions, or in some cases just outright win via certain wars.

Of course, you don't have anything close to resembling the number of actions and resources that you need to pull all of this off.  It's a juggling act where you're trying to squeeze in just one more ball than everyone else.

The upgrades that you're competing for enter the game via a Dutch auction.  They start out expensive, and drop in price until someone buys them or they are removed from the game.  This mechanic is brilliant.  If you absolutely need a certain card you can probably get it, but it will cost you most of a turn to do so.

You start the game with 4 civil actions, which you use for the majority of things that you do in the game.  You also get 2 military actions for building troops and wreaking havoc.  There are several cards that will increase one or both of these action pools.  The thing that I really like about the game design is that simply pumping these up isn't sufficient to create a snowball effect.  Yes, more actions are better than fewer, but if you don't have the resource production to back those action up you'll be wasting a lot of time.

The leaders and the wonders are all unique, although there is overlap between a lot of their abilities.  Wonders have a sufficiently high opportunity cost that you really feel like you've earned them once they are built.  Leaders are very cheap to acquire, but you are strictly limited on many you can draw and play.

Military is an arms race.  If you keep up with your opponents you're probably fine.  If you let someone get way ahead, the pain train is likely to show up soon.  There are aggressions which let one player try to attack another.  It's a simple comparison of military strength, with the option of sacrificing troops for a temporary boost (and the subsequent shrinking of power after those troops disappear).  If the attacker wins, the text on the aggresion card occurs.  These take the form of stealing goods, stealing science, blowing up buildings, killing leaders, etc.

Unlike aggresions, wars can backfire on the attacker.  They can, however, be far more devastating.  Rather than simply deciding on win/lose, the amount by which you win or lose also matters.  If you have a huge military lead, wars can really hurt your enemies.

There are also colonies which can give you some nice bonuses, but at the expense of your military troops.  It's an agonizing choice sometimes to attempt to win a colony, knowing that afterwards you're going to be a sitting duck until you can build your military back up.

Fair warning for those who hate downtime -- there is some here because each player-turn is taken in its entirety.  You should be thinking and planning when it's not your turn though, which will speed things up.  My last two full games (2-players) took two hours each.  (Both were called with a few turns to play, because they were blow-outs.  Figure another 15 minutes each if we were play to completion.)

If you're just starting out, and you have any gaming experience at all, I suggest starting with the advanced game.  Use the simple game as a solitaire exercise for learning the basic rules.  Make sure that you read the rules a couple of times before trying to teach anyone.  The rulebook is a terrible reference guide, so you really want to know these rules cold before you start.

After you've read the rules twice, go read Helen Holzgrafe's excellent rules summary and errata list.  It'll likely point out a couple of rules that you missed.
http://www.boardgamegeek.com/file/info/30465


Overall, the game is a ton of fun.  I love civ games, and this is the best that I've played so far.  I've only played Advanced Civ against a computer.  Maybe I'd like that one more than TtA, but who the hell knows, since it's impossible to get a group to play it.  I can actually get TtA to the table and knock out a couple games in an evening.

This game doesn't get played very often because it's a major time commitment.

RATING: N/A
x, 1
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Utterly horrible game. How something so mind-numbingly tedious can end up as one of the highest rated games of all time, is beyond understanding. The game is at least 3-4 times too long for its own good, the downtime is awful, gameplay itself is utterly tedious, with repetitive shuffling back and forth of little wooden discs again and again and again and again. A game for spreadsheet fans, who like lots and lots and lots of micromanagement.

If one played only the first era, the game would even be tolerable as a sort of run of the mill engine-building eurogame, but add in the other eras and it becomes a drawn-out torture session where you sloooowly build up your engine while waiting and hoping for something - anything! - to put you out of your misery.

The total shame of the whole thing is that many of the engine-building mechanisms are actually quite clever: Management of population, resources, innovation (?) points, government types giving different amounts of actions, and the drafting of both generic and unique cards are all nice mechanisms in principle. But repeat it for 6+ hours, adding in 10 minutes (at least) of downtime with absolutely nothing to do between each of your turns, and it becomes unbearable. This is a game that could have used a developer's hand in streamlining the whole thing - ya know, cut away all the fiddly bits and expose the presumably interesting decisions underneath. As it is, whatever decision-making and thematic feel the game may have, it is completely buried beneath bookkeeping.

And don't even get me started on the awful conflict system which actively encourages attacking the weakest player at all times. As bad as "hit the leader" effects may be, they pale in comparison with "hit the person who's behind" effects. Yikes!

I can solemnly promise never to play the full game with four players again (a 1-era game with fewer players is not out of the question, though). I am sorry to say this, but this whole tedious exercise in micromanagement must rank as one of my worst gaming experiences in years.

RATING: 8.5
Epic civilization building game with everything you could possibly want from such a game minus the map.

What does it model? Warfare (including armies which are stronger than the sum of their parts), raids, colonization, technology, upgrading, obsolescence, leaders, wonders, resource gathering (food and ore), corruption, happiness, population limited by food, culture, advanced government systems (theology, communism, republic, etc.) and trade pacts.

This loses a half-point (or more) because of its length. I guess it's necessary if you want to include all of the above but based on the subjective rating, I don't "always want to play it" since I can only do so on days I don't work and there are only two days in the weekend so...

RATING: 10
I went from "want to play" to ordering the game after having a chance to play TTA twice on consecutive days.  I initially pegged it as an 8, as the second game I played was the "advanced game", which was OK but left me wanting to finish the game, so it left a (slightly) sour taste in my mouth.  Rating would be a 6 for the so called "advanced" game, and a 9 for the real thing.

Just long enough, just involved enough, just enough interaction for a not-quite epic scale Civilization game.  Military can hurt you, but keeping up is something anyone can do, just a matter of diverting resources.  Easy to learn with logical progressions, and optimal play isn't something that will go by rote - the way others play affects what your optimal play is.

The result is the perfect bowl of porridge.

RATING: 10
2011-08-21

Initial Rating 9.5 (April 2011)

I´m a big fan of civilization games so I had to play this but I had my reservations. I didn’t think it was possible to create a good civilization game without a board (it´s a card game) but Vlaada pulled it off, he created a GREAT game and it´s currently in Top 10 of favorite games. Vlaada is now officially one of my favorite game designers.

This is the first game in the top ratings that totally deserve its spot (as I think the top three are overrated). It has lots of tough decisions, offers pure strategy with little luck and it has an epic feel as you go through the game. On the downside (for some people :D) it has a long playtime, even more if you play with 4 players (I believe there is a long downtime with 4 players) and it has somewhat complex rules.

In conclusion it is a great civilization game and a true gamer´s game. I recommend it without any reservations and can´t wait to play it again.

Current Rating: 9.5
[hr]
2011-09-16

Through the Ages is now my second favorite game ever (only surpassed by Dungeon Twister). I’m playing more and more online because when I play face to face I feel the game can be very fiddly with all the components and all the indicators you have to manually adjust, also it takes a long time to play it (4hours + or even more if you have analysis paralysis prone friends). Still love it and I would never say no to a TtA game :D. 

The perfect 10 for me a true gamer´s game.

Current Rating: 10.0
[hr]
2013-04-09

After 38 games I still continue to love TtA. When I read the rules they said that this is not a war game, so in my few first games I didn’t paid much attention to this and I was utterly destroyed by players with a better military. Nowadays, my games always feature an arms race fo some sort, so I’m beginning to feel that all my games play (more or less) in the same fashion. What I´m saying is that having a high military is VERY important, perhaps the most important aspect of the game. 

Still I always want to play it (preferably with an expansion or two to spice things up) and still continues to be a 10 in my book.

Current Rating: 10.0

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Played at BGG.con  1 Basic game, 3 Advanced games.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
What a tight design.  Resources are extremely limited, and there never seem to be enough actions available to develop exactly as you'd like.  Amazingly, "Civ without a map" works, as the military mechanics appropriately stimulate the growth of armies without bogging the game down in tactics.  (I love tactics elsewhere, but here they'd just needlessly complicate things.)

Downtime can be an issue with slow players, as the game forces a lot of micromanagement.  Plays best with 3, where the multiplayer dynamic is still in effect but the downtime is less pronounced than in 4 player.  Also plays very well with 2.  I suspect I'd prefer TTA best with four quick players.  However, usually with 4 players the game overstays its welcome; it really wants to be completed in 4 hours, and doesn't drill quite down in detail to where I'd want to see a 6-8 hour game.

I've seen too many games decided by who gets to pull Napoleon/Air Forces.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I don't really know what to say about this one. I really expected to love it but it didn't quite scratch the itch like I expected it would. If it were shorter and a little less "fussy" then it would get more plays but it wouldn't be the same game by any means. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
would love to try the 3rd edition and it's the one I'm after.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Just finished my third totally miserable game of Through the Ages, life is to short to play again. Card timing is everything in this game, if the right card does not come up at a time that is beneficial to you  or the wrong one does then you have no control over your game, all you can do it sit and go through the motions, the painfully slow motions, until the end.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
2015-04-28

Rating: 9,5

After several plays on BGA, I have to reduce TtA's rating.  Although I still enjoy this game and I will never say no to it, I'm gettin the sensation than the military aspect of the game is slightly overpowered.

There had been games in which I wasn't able to do anything against a military escalation, and several times the game was reduced to a military race in which cultural and science generation didn't matter at all.

I hope that game designers correct these issues on the announced reissue.


2015-04-02

Initial rating: 10,0
TtA was the first "serious" game that I played.  At the time a couple of friends bought it, we hadn't play anything more complex than Settlers of Catan.

At first we played the simple mode a few times and then moved on to the Advanced game, however we weren't able to complete a Full game.

A year later we started on sunday morning and finished it at 6:00 p.m., and it was a very good experience.  However we played with a home rule, no one can be attacked more than once each round in order to equilibrate the game.

TtA is so much entertaining because you need to try to balance all the aspects of your civilization, but you never will be fully equilibrated so in the game you need to think ahead and try to follow a general long-term strategy but at the same time you musn't neglect short-term playing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a great civilisation game that takes quite some time to play. The game requires players to invest at least 2-3/4/5 hours of their  time in order to complete a "full" game. I, however, do not feel time passing while playing this game. Like the (dead) Ikea clock in my room, time seems to stand still when you're assassinating Shakespeare and threatening Newton with plunder.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
- This is an amazing game with massive scope, however it takes ages to teach and play.
- The newer version is definitely recommended over the older version as they've streamlined it a little and massively improved the aesthetics.
- The way production and upkeep works is really interesting. You have to balance your mining+farming with science, culture and wonders. It's one of those games where you want to do everything, but you can only do half of it (or less) like Great Western Trail.
- Would not recommend with >3 players. 
- I think I prefer 3 players to 2. The way the military works, it can be easy for one player to pick on another and maintain an advantage over them. With >2 players, attacking a player can leave you open to attack, hence the game becomes more about the threat of attack and maintaining a defense force rather than an attacking force.

RATING: N/A
[b][url=https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/213164/golden-geek-awards-2007-and-nominees-are]2007 Golden Geek Nominee[/url][/b]

Through the Ages is a civilization building game. Each player attempts to build the best civilization through careful resource management, discovering new technologies, electing the right leaders, building wonders and maintaining a strong military. Weakness in any area can be exploited by your opponents. The game takes place throughout the ages beginning in the age of antiquity and ending in the modern age.

Victory is achieved by the player whose nation has the most culture at the end of the modern age.

Players: 2, 3, 4
Time: 240 min
Mechanics: [property=2001][/property], [property=2012][/property], [property=2041][/property], [property=2040][/property]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
2nd ed./3rd printing.  A card-driven, empire-building, civilization game (w/o a map), where choosing and optimizing cards in an attempt to balance resources, people, and research is most critical.  Currently trying to find a happy medium between my son's propensity towards an aggressive military and my own preference in developing a sound economic engine.  Rating is for 2-player games, though sometimes I'm lucky enough to play an occasional 3-player.  I'm sure my rating will increase with more familiarity. 8.5

UPDATE:  Though there strangly is no area map giving this civilization game an abstract feel, the ebb and flow of supply and demand simply works and works very well... for me anyway.  The enclosed game rules are somewhat ambiguous, however, the available player aids (ddmits, gunslinger311, and jerkules) are most helpful.  9.5  

UPDATE:  Can't help myself, it plays admirably with two... 10!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Although the components are sub-par, I'm not discounting the game for that as I think that ratings should be intended for the design, not the production. The components are at least functional. The design, on the other hand, is exceptional. I have a preference for games with many options that can be combined for creative gameplay. The way this game combines many complicated elements with a number of smooth central mechanics is most impressive. 

I have discounted a couple of excellent games (Caylus and Puerto Rico) because of the apparent uselessness of some of the options. While this game does have some cards that are significantly weaker than others, they can still be an advantage with a complementary card combination, and there are so many options to choose from, that it mitigates any potential design weakness.

While there are ways to get around if you fall behind in other departments, falling behind militarily can end your game early. I think as long as everyone understands this, it won't be too much of an issue, but it's a hard lesson for newbies. Also, I think this is true to history as well.

UPDATE: Sold this. Excited to get the new version. If it truly plays better, I'll probably knock this version a point or two and make the new one a 10.

UPDATE: And I did. The new version is better, but still giving this version props scoring it a "9".

RATING: 10
Gran juego de civilizaciones, que se puede jugar en unas 3-4 horas.

Las mecánicas de producción/hambre y consumo/corrupción engranan perféctamente, haciendo el principio de la partida que tu desarrollo sea lento y tengas que llevar cuidado con la sublevación (y con la maldita corrupción).

Las acciones políticas mediante las cartas militares le dan al juego un poco más de sensación de civilización (conquista de territorios, agresiones,...) y que no se descuide el aspecto militar.
[color=green]
LAST PLAY: 2010
[/color][color=blue]
Great Civilization's game, playing time is around 3-4 hours.

Production/Starvation and Consumption/Corruption mechanics work perfectly, your progress will be slow at the beginning and you will have to put an eye on uprising (and corruption).

Using military cards for taking policies actions will give the game a little bit more of Civilization's flavour (conquering territories, attacks,...) and will increase the civilization's strength.[/color]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Finally settled on this rating after about 15 plays or so (mostly with Advanced, twice with Full Game rules).  Positives:  has a nice feel for a Civ-building game, the card row and action points mechanisms work quite well.  From the gameplay aspect, this game is on a par with the best Civ-building games out there.  On the negative side, play time is a big issue, particularly with four players, since you add cards to the deck but remove fewer cards each turn with more players.  The components are the main reason the game can't earn a 9 or 10 in my book, as the beads are downright fiddly and the player mats are too small.  A chart tracking each player's level for each of the relevant items with a dividing line would have worked just as well and been less confusing.  However, once you get  past the fiddly bits, this is a fairly solid game.   
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The very best Civ game. Little box, big price but worth it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
OK, I really can't see the fuss here.  None of the basic mechanisms appeal:
1. Card drafting from a row is boring.  It was dull in St. Petersburg and is actually duller here.
2. Pushing bits on and off cards is really tedious, clunky and dull.   No trading mechanic.
3. Theme is very thin - its all about min-maxing various combos of 'stuff' to win points.  That's fine in a 45 minute game but here its just dull.  Lots of micro decisions.  Ick.  Sacrifices mega-theme with micro-theme, destroying a sense of 'epic-ness' which I look for in civ games. This is a game where you 'manage' your civilization rather than 'rule' your civilization. I would much rather be a king than a bureaucrat.  So, I really found the game ... dull.  I guess I can see why some might like it but its just not my kind of game.
Update: since writing the above I have played Phoenicia, which seems to me to be a very similar game to TTA - micromanagement via pushing bits of stuff around cardboard with a similar mechanism of gaining improvements (drafting cards with declining values is a close approximation to an auction).  The two games gave me the same bored reaction but at least Pheonicia is short.
---------------------
Update.  Played a couple of more times now and raised rating from 4 to 6, but I think that's where it stays.  The game is interesting up to a point, but its ponderous with tons of downtime.  I would NOT play this with more than two players - my rating of 6 is for two players only and I can't imagine it would go up for more players.
---------------------
Another update.  Stays at 6, but may go back down again.  Last game I got my highest score yet (180-ish) and did not build a single urban building - only built Iron, Irrigation and four wonders.  That's just really lame.  TTA has all of these 'options' in the game which in reality never ever get used.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
And here I thought Agricola was fiddly, lol. The game is well laid out, but there is a fair bit of accounting to be done on each turn. In our 4 player game, scoring culture points when seeding the future events deck was often forgotten. We had to go back and figure that out a few times. Some icons and comments on the individual player boards would help clarify a number of things. 

While the round tokens are unique, there is a reason games use cubes instead! And these bits are small to boot.

We intended to play all 3 ages, but decided to stop after the 2nd age when the game was clocking about 5 and a half hours. It would have been interesting to see how the game progressed, but we were getting tired by 2am. Maybe next time.

Overall fun experience with an epic feel.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.2


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Rating a seven after three plays. Through the Ages is a long and heavy game in which you are constantly trying to balance, improve, and specialize the strengths of an entire civilization over the course of four ages. If you want micromanagement in a game, TtA beats them all. The government you have (despotism, monarchy, etc.) determines the number of civil and military actions you get to take on your turn. You can use these actions to expand your population, build new production buildings (mines/farms), build new urban buildings, etc. The urban buildings might boost your civilization's scientific capabilities, or "culture" (raw points), or overall happiness (necessary for larger and larger populations). You also have to participate in a perpetual arms race, lest you become a target of opportunity (unfortunately, there is a built-in "bash the loser" mechanic in the game that can be hard to recover from if you slip into last). The leader only gets bashed if he has a weak military..., but if you invest a lot in the military, you're usually not leading in culture. 

The cynic in me wants to tag this as "Upgrade: the game." Certainly the large number of moving parts lets you feel like a magician at times, squeezing every optimal advance out of your turn. But over the course of 4-5 hours, it's too much of the same: an hour ago, my military was sufficient, now it isn't, better invest in new units, etc. As a result, the game is alternately thrilling and tedious. I always feel gorged on it when I'm done.

Update: I have not played this in quite a while, but I suspect my rating is actually more like a six at best. I should give it another try. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

RATING: 7.5
In the full game military strength is far more important, probably too much so. A strong civilization can gain a lot of resources and victory points by beating up on weaker civilizations. Unfortunately there is luck in being able to build your military, especially in whether a good tactics card comes out for you. These cards give additional strength based on your formations. Still the civilization building aspects of the game are really well done so it definitely offers some enjoyable play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Just recently purchased and have only played two of the "simple Games" so far.  However, after such limited experience with the game, I can already see it's HUGE potential!  This game is amazing.  Almost everything is accounted for as far as controlling a Civilization.  It's beautiful.  
    The only draw back, as has already been pointed out elsewhere on the geek is that the number of bits that come with the game are inadequate.  I mean, you need 6 coloured cubes for each player to keep track of your various scores.  The game comes with 5?!?!? WTF?  And also the scoring track jumps from 80 to 100 in ten steps (that must represent the time travel element?).  All in all they are minor little points, and I already knew they were there from doing some research here on the geek, but annoying none the less.  When you put down $130NZ$ you expect perfection.     
   As far as the game play goes, I believe they HAVE achieved perfection!  It's just seamless. The rule book is intimidating but once you start to get stuck in, it all makes pretty basic sense really.  You just have to get your head around the fact that the cards in front of you are not buildings, they represent the technology your Civ. has developed to allow you to build those buildings.  Make sense??    
   I believe, after a few more plays and experiencing the Advanced and Full games, my rating for this will increase.

RATING: 9
I love the theme, and the nature of building your empire. The art, however, is terrible and is in desperate need of a redesign for their next printing.

Playing it feels like building and expanding on your own personal empire, and while your options seem vast on each turn - trying to figure out what actions would best suit your civilization at the time is fun and interesting. Despite it's long length, I would even prefer that the game lasted longer; whether it's due to an inherent game feature, or just due to my own excitement, it seems to end long before I'm ready to give up.

RATING: 7.6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
War can be so devastating that I have to downgrade to 6/10. They take away the possibility to neglect military even a little bit in favour of other developments. A 132 point shift by a single war is too much.
---
When it's your turn to use your actions, TTA is approaching the perfect game. But then the turns of the other players start. At first you try to follow their actions. But at some time early in the game you just stop trying to understand why they only pay that amount of iron or what civilization advances they build. Better trust your fellows to be reliable and not making mistakes when taking into account all applicable modificators or fiddling around with the many small parts. Small mistakes can easily make a big difference. You just start hoping that it's your turn soon but that can take 10 minutes in a four-player game.
With the big criticisms out of the way, building up your own civilization is a fascinating challenge of micromanaging multiple dimensions of resources, production and requirements.  All players of the classic PC Civilisation game will experience pure bliss of nostalgia. In sum, I'm torn on this game. Rarely have I seen a game with pros and cons as spread as here. Ideally, this should be played online in a turn-based modus with rules enforcement. As a social boardgame experience I have to be in the right mood.
One prerogative in TTA: never be the civilization with the weakest military.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Currently the favorite 2p game for both the wife and I.  We love the epic sweep, the adventure, the building. The genius of the design continues to amaze and surprise me.  

Strikes a great and thematic balance between chaos and luck vs. control. It manages to be deep and thinky but not too taxing since you can't plan your moves out with exact precision too far in advance, just the broad strokes.  I love how combat and colonization work (whether or not you should sacrifice units is a tough decision!).  You can produce the currencies of the game (actions, science, food, rocks, happiness and workers) in many different ways (technologies + workers, special technologies, leaders, wonders, government and colonies). It is extremely enjoyable and difficult to get the balance right.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Clunky.

Flawed deeply - bad production, misprints, scoring tracks centimeters from cards which must be moved en masse, mechanics that require players to shoot for efficiency but leave them unavoidably punished for doing so due to unpredicable events.  Has direct conflict that is both frustrating and unsatisfying.  First playthrough with reasonable explanation still left over six independent "Oh, I didn't know about THAT rule" situations that were extremely harmful.

This game is a relic of the Avalon Hill days: poorly organized rules, overcomplicated, too long, without sufficient depth to pay for all of its sins.

Skip unless you're a true Civ fanboy.

RATING: 9
A plethora of interesting paths to develop one's civ. Hard learning curve on the first try; however, it speeds up a lot on subsequent plays. Get someone to teach you. I actually rate the online implementation at 9.5 - it surpasses the board game in numerous ways.

RATING: 8.5

The game also seems to lend itself well to the creation of home rules or configuration.  The wife and I are considering experimenting by basically expanding the simple game as a two player by just adding more civil ages.


Update: Tried the advanced game.  I really like this, although the lack of a map does still feel a bit weird.  I still like this game, but I do worry a bit that I might just end up getting Civ and playing that when I'm in the mood for civ games.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Epic card-driven civilisation-building game with some complexity. Spans the ages from Antiquity to Modernity. The challenge is to acquire a collection of cards that work well together while simultaneously building a balanced economy that can support continued expansion. Hunger, worker contentment, and corruption are integrated into the core mechanisms of happiness, science, military strength, and culture. There is some military conflict, but it is abstracted and about resources rather than territory.

RATING: 10
Shame on me for ever rating this anything less than a 10.  Brilliant.  Complex and thematic.  It does suffer from experience-biased outcomes (newer players will have a tough time competing) but if you have a group of similar experienced players this game will shine.  I will keep my original comments below when I initially gave this game a 6. 

Played this once at Gamestorm 2011 late at night.  There is definitely a steep learning curve w/ experienced players having a significant advantage and the game was not very forgiving of early "mistakes" (similar to how I felt about Clash of Cultures).  Ultimately I left the game feeling like it was a "rich get richer" game with strong military dominating other cultures and with too many cards along the line of "leader of category X get Y benefit while last of category X takes Z penalty).  Civilization games are one of my top two genres however so I am intrigued to try this again with friends and see how it plays a second time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
TtA: ASoC is a kind of tableau builder, but like Le Havre it has a bunch of stuff going on to flesh out, colour and complicate the core efficiency engine. It really feels like a Civilization-style game though the map is completely abstracted away.

After two 2-player games I'm giving it a 7. It seems many negative reactions to the game are related to bad experiences with 4-player games, but I would definitely like to try it with three.

Concerns include whether experience will lower playing times (it will easily take three hours with two players) and mitigate snowball effects from early mistakes or fluke events (such as falling into a population hole and being forced to neglect the military to catch up economically). Possibly the answer is to just play until it's obvious who's going to win, but it seems a little anticlimactic.

I have no issues with the components of the third edition. Play with drafted cards open and separate from your hand of military cards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

After many online plays I lowered my rating from a 10 to an 8.  While a great game it has a single but important flaw.  There is no penalty for losing an aggression.  There should be.

Accounting 201. It's OK, and I need to finish a game before I can decide for sure how I feel about it, but so far I'm less than charmed. 

Pluses: lots of cards, no single strategy, when things go right it feels like you just climbed Everest. The player interaction is fun. It is perfectly balanced indeed.

Minuses: the rest of the time it just feels like climbing Everest. Too long. "Snap" is perfectly balanced too; doesn't make it fun. You could play this in Excel and it wouldn't change a whole lot. Too much annoying procedural arithmetic.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Updated after solo play of full game.  I loved the old Civilization and Sid Meier's computer game.  This is the boardgame that captures the feel of those old games in a fraction of the time.

Initial rating based on solo play of simple and advanced games.

Challenging game to learn.  It pretty much is a board game version of Sid Meier's Civilization computer game with everything, including happiness and corruption based on your whole civ, not each city.  The march of time is captured by the mechanic of removing cards from the left side of the board each player turn, which requires careful planning of limited actions.  There is a lot to like in this game, and it will take many plays to figure out which strategies are successful (and that may depend on the order cards become available).

   
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Recommended for those craving grand strategy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A few more plays, and I'm still lukewarm on it. I think I want it to be good, but there's just so much that can go wrong that doesn't feel entirely within your control that I'm not sure that it is.

I think my main problem is that three random military cards a turn just isn't enough to get a good selection of those available, and with the pasting you can suffer if your military isn't up to scratch, that level of randomness just isn't good enough for a game of this length. I wonder if there was ever drafting for military cards too - it'd seem to make a good deal of sense.

---------------------------------------------------
Only one play so far, but the game seems interesting. I like the way you have a pool of resources and population that can be increased to help corruption or food consumption. It is very unintuitive though, and I'm not sure I appreciated having to spend a 4 hour learning game to realise how to even begin to play properly.

The other diappointment is that what you do in the first two ages doesn't matter too much; it's all just setting up infrastructure ready for age III. It feels much more like an economic engine game than a civ game. I'd much prefer if there was the chance to score equal amounts of culture in every age, so you have to concentrate on it for the entire game rather than just building it all at the end.

RATING: 10

RATING: 10
Sid Meier's Civilization computer game comes to wargames! This is a great game for four players that simulates different civilizations trying to be the first to gain new discoveries, inventions, ideologies, and religions. It forces players to invest in both civilian and military technology; those who ignore the latter will suffer greatly. It is also a long game, about 4-hours in length. TTA has now become my second favorite Civ-type game. Only 7 Ages beats it out. Recommended.

RATING: 7
No llegamos a terminar 1 partida por tiempo.

Tienes que ir desarrollando tu civilización con mejor sistema de gobierno (que te puede dar más acciones civiles y/o militares, así como más cartas en la mano y más cantidad de trabajadores por recursos), mejores formas de recolectar recursos (alimentos y piedras), cultura, ciencia, potencial militar (para poder atacar, defenderte o ganar los eventos), construir maravillas y obtener líderes que te darán ventajas.

Lo malo es que es un juego muy largo, pero me gustó el juego. Las cosas que puedes hacer son realmente escasas para lo que quisieras, porque siempre al mismo tiempo que quieres ir jugando lo que has conseguido en turnos anteriores, también quieres coger nuevas cartas y muchas veces faltan recursos para construirlo todo.

A pesar de ser tan largo, no me importaría jugarlo de nuevo y terminar una partida. Y eso dice mucho del juego, ya que no me suelen gustar juegos de tanta duración.

RATING: 8
Really mixed feelings on this one. It has nice and simple mechanics that evoke the feel of running a civilization. The big problem is that C:TTA is too gamey. You can win the game by making a combo that will work for several turns giving you a huge advantage in victory points. This has nothing to do with managing your resources well. You might be great at minimizing corruption, making your citizens happy, building army, but you will still fail if you don't build churches and some of the wonders.

EDIT: After playing some more I see that above problems disappear in full game. Rating up.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I'm not very good at it but so far, this is the best game I've ever played.  I have  the 3rd Fred edition, the 2nd Rebel edition, the 2nd Mindok edition, and the 4th Iello edition. Out of about 40 plays I don't think I've ever won with the same card combination twice.  I've used about 80% of the cards (buildings, units, govts, wonders).  There are so many things to think about every turn.  It's easy to miss something.  While I do like maps, I also like the minimalistic aspect of this game as it fits easily on my small table.  This is a game of grand scale; you are building a civ from ground up.  If you are good at gambling on probabilities, you will do very well in this game and win more than your fair share.  I typically play once a week due to time constraints.  It's a 3 or 4 hour game with 3 or 4 respectively.  Sometimes, 3 players is only 2 and a half hours though.  If you experience AP, stay far away from this game as it can turn into an 8 hour snoozefest.

RATING: 10
Excellent epic complex card-driven civilisation game. A whole range of concepts have been nicely integrated into the main mechanisms: happiness, corruption, revolutions, colonization, military conflict, culture, important or remarkable leaders, ... Resources and technology points are more important than food to progress with your civilisation (other civilisation games tend to have a more acute shortage of food). The game components are rather tiny and should have been bigger. *** 22 Feb 2007: Simple game with three newbies took a bit more than three hours, including explanation, but ended rather abruptly. As indicated in the rules, the simple game should only be played to learn the basic game mechanisms. *** 24 Feb 2007: Full game with three players, of which two newbies, lasted almost nine hours. Should go faster with more experience, but nevertheless downtime between turns might be an issue. Winning thanks to fast food chains was rather pleasant! *** 25 Feb 2007: Advanced game with three players (again two newbies) - 5 hours. Just as with the simple game, the game ended too fast. There were still a whole lot of things to do and the Age III cards looked tempting. *** 14 March 2007: Full game with two players - 5 hours. *** 12 January 2008: Full game with three players - 5 hours. *** 20 September 2008: Simple game with three players. *** 25 April 2009: Full game with three players - 7 or 8 hours. *** Conclusion: the full game has definitely my preference! *** 2013: started online playing ...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.4
The best board game I have ever had the pleasure of playing. Fun, interactive, and challenging without being cutthroat. It is the one game I always want to play and one of the few games I constantly have a hankering for. I cherish this game and think it is a must own for any board game lover.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The game is much like computer Civilization. There is no map to move your units, but game concepts like research, production, population grown, happiness, corruption or even revolution are similar. It you are the Civilization fan, you will see the connection clearly.

It is very demanding game. Game flow is like an avalanche. In the first rounds you slowly build your empire. Minor mistakes made at the beginning reveals catastrophically later. But the game gives you a chance to adjust your development to cards which come to play. So at the end, if you lose, you usually have a feeling that if you had done better, you would have won.

The idea of civic cards coming visible with higher cost at the beginning and lower at the end is great. It makes randomizes much less in the area of gathering civic cards. The game has many other little but great and original features like corruption, workers or technologies.

TtA has also several drawbacks. The biggest of them is a randomization with military cards. It is impossible to get particular military card type for sure, you must be lucky. So if you have a strong military you may be unable to attack anyone  because you didn't draw a suitable card. Also the distribution of end-game scoring events (which are about 30 to 50% of total scoring) is totally random. Another drawback is that the game is very hard to beginners. There are two simplified game versions but both of them are broken from the advanced player perspective. Sometimes I have a feeling that it can turn too complex at all...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Elaborate system, however:

- Almost no interaction (like wars, trade, etc.), plays more like several parallel solitaire games

- Designed to harass the player who is already behind so that there is almost no chance to get back into play if you are losing

RATING: 1
Played once, with the beautiful overlays that keep the chits in place. In short the game takes forever and although not stated as a rule, it is required that you expend most of your achievements into military, especially from era 2 onward.
The game takes forever, it's constant administration, not bad in itself but not good either. Your "civ" will always consist of just a few cards like an upgraded library or a silly wonder that does almost nothing.
You beget cards from an action selection tray, seen that on many other games like concordia, suburbia. Players that have previous experience like knowing you MUST get Genghis Khan at any price, and bombers, will crush you. For seven hours. 
Have a great time!
The only (+) I can find is it is not very expensive (like 35 bucks) and does not take much shelf space. Requires quite a big table when playing btw.

RATING: 6
30 minutes of fun packed into 6 hours of play.  Developing your civilization through the ages is fun but games are way too long to really be worth it.  Additionally, you can usually tell who's going to win after a couple of hour, making the rest of the game tedious at best, and often frustrating for the losers to be.  To play this correctly, half the players have to be willing to retire from play early as their civilization gets dominated, leaving them waiting for the others to finish their (overly long) game.  I've played this with very different groups with similar outcomes.  Everyone is walking a razor edge of keeping up on the military and if anyone gets outpaced, they are done for.  Attrition is very sudden & monolithic, low forgiveness, significant reinforcing loops (winner keeps getting ahead, looser keeps falling further behind).  It could be OK but is hard to accept with such a time investment.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Most likely the best civilization building boardgame around.  While some complain about the small plastic bubbles used for resources, civic actions, military actions, and citizens, I didn't find it to be an issue.  The game definitely has a good bit of book-keeping but isn't fiddly in the sense of some games.  This really reminds me much of Civilization the computer game in boardgame form.  You do not want to get behind in the arms race nor the scientific research ability as both seem central to doing well.  Resource management seems to be at the center of the game as you seek to put together card combinations in technology, wonders, leaders, and buildings.  Yes, the game will go on for quite a while but I didn't find myself unengaged often although I doubt I would ever play with 4 players.  My biggest issue with the game is that luck of the draw can set you back at times, but with as many cards as this game holds, hopefully this is mitigated over time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A Euro-engine game on Civilization... a Czech production.  It is sad to see the new edition had all the famous names removed due to copyright issue, e.g Elvis and Sid Meier.  Nonetheless, it still gives you a great historical feel with the other great names like Julius Caesar, Leonardo da Vinci.  I played the basic game only once but it gave me a good impression.  It is sometime hard to know what are you doing on the path to victory and what are the others doing, unless you have a clear and determined mind.  With the resources growing with the buildings, your kingdom expands with your subjects within the allowable actions number constrained by the form of government.  The basic game sees no advantage to advance your military might as you cannot threaten others with it to get something in exchange of peace.  On the other hand, it is best to advance science (lab) and culture (drama) to keep your people happy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Requires a lot of thought from the beginning on.  Beginners should have enough to think about with the Simplified version, at least for their first game (even seasoned players): 13 cards to look at and combine with one's tableau, plus the opponent's cards…

The flow of time is palpable; this creates a sense of urgency.  "This leader looks good, should I take it before it disappears, which might come fast?".  Zipping through time is also a nice experience, which can be contrasted to that of some other engine-building games (Race for the Galaxy, Caylus Magna Carta, Agricola).  Plus, the perspective of moving forward in time gives some motivation for playing longer--as does feeling that your civilization is not as complete as you wanted it to be!

Some mechanisms similar to some other games: some cards that you buy (Wonders, Leaders) give you various advantages (as in Race for the Galaxy), some cards that you own produce (as in Race for the Galaxy, and Caylus Magna Carta), you need to consume resources regularly (food, in Through the Ages, as in Agricola).

The handling of tokens is a little fiddly (heavier than in Agricola), but the good rule book makes the procedure quite clear. It quickly becomes second nature, though. Plus, token movements are limited: that each player has its own set of tokens and that they stay in his playing area.

It is useful to understand that the "Science" level represents a _potential_ for technological discoveries, and as such, that it can be "used up" (one cannot do research and use it to discover an infinite number of things).

Graphics are rigid and really not world class; by far not as polished as those from Race for the Galaxy, Blue Moon, Caylus Magna Carta,...  The board quality and card quality is OK; the board is very shiny and mine is slightly warped.  One of the decks is hard to extract from the inner plastic box because of its shape.

I liked the events in the Simple game: they are bonuses, it's Christmas time!

After 1–2 plays, I'm not sure it's a game "I always want to play" yet. It has this potential, but its sheer length, coupled with the fact that it is quite close to a Euro (at least the Simple game: resource management, full information) prevent me from loving it in the same way as I love Race (short and meaty), Claustrophobia (original, with exploration, special powers, theme,…), Magic (surprises, mechanics tied beautifully to the theme…), Agricola (not too long, with cards that make each game a little different). Through the Ages does not (yet?) seem to have this little spark that makes me love games and want to always play them.

The rules are quite precise and clear. However, they require too much memorization: many details are in the text and can be easily forgotten (we have a very limited working memory), which makes reading the rule not so easy. So, in practice, some sections might require a lot of back and forth checks, and some details might be missed easily. It would be useful if many details were first summarized and given in a simple to refer to overview (like: where are the new elements of the Advanced game compared to the Simple game).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Excelente juego de excelente temática: la historia de la civilización humana desde sus comienzos hasta la actualidad.
Un trabajo resuelto eficazmente en un juego de mecánica sencilla que permite ponerte en los huesos de algunos de los personajes más influyentes de la historia (líderes) mientras desarrollas tu civilización de diversas maneras (militarmente, científicamente, tecnológicamente) incluyendo la construcción de maravillas, para conseguir ser la mejor cultura del mundo.
Un juego que recuerda a Agrícola en la sensación que transmite de que parece faltarte tiempo y acciones civilies y militares para llevar a cabo todo lo que tienes en mente; pero mientras en Agrícola esa sensación es acuciante, en Through the ages tienes la esperanza de que lo que te ha faltado en una mejor gestión de tus recursos.

JUEGO BASICO

Escasa interacción en la variante más corta y simple del juego, y menos aún para 2 jugadores ya que la mayoría de cartas de tecnología necesarias para mejorar la civilización están por duplicado y ningún jugador, según las reglas del juego, puede tener 2 cartas iguales de tecnología en posesión; de este modo, es inviable intentar perjudicar a los jugadores rivales por este camino. En partidas de 3 o 4 jugadores el juego adquiere mayor tensión, ya que el jugador que adquiera tal o cuál carta de tecnología está evitando que otros jugadores la tengan, obligándoles a cerrar una vía de desarrollo de su civilización y haciéndoles pensar en otras alternativas. 

Notas a priori tras la 1ª partida del juego a 2 jugadores

Nota 1: Fundamental mirar y remirar la lista de 13 cartas civiles en cada momento, optimizando en lo posible el gasto de acciones civiles y militares.

Nota 2: Tener un ojo en los indicadores de fuerza, cultura y ciencia de los rivales debe ser una constante.

Nota 3: A priori,al principio de la partida parece más importante desarrollar una 3ª (e incluso 4ª) mina antes que una 3ª granja, ya que sin recursos los trabajadores inactivos no sirven para nada. La creación de granjas adicionales debe venir después.

Nota 4: La carta de acción "Work of Art" resulta muy útil, ya que permite aumentar la cuenta de Puntos de cultura en 5 ó 6 unidades de una tacada.

Nota 5: A la hora de construir una maravilla es preferible hacerlo en aquellas cuyos beneficios puedan ser un complemento a las habilidades del líder elegido, ya que las maravillas no son fáciles ni rápidas de construir.

Nota 6: El indicador de puntos de ciencia es vital para construir tanto las mejoras de las cartas de tecnología agrícola y mineras como la de las cartas de tecnología especiales y de gobierno; por lo tanto, tener algunos laboratorios debe ser algo fundamental también, si no al principio de la partida, una vez entrada la 4 o 5ª rondas, una vez las minas "extras" ya se han construido.

Nota 7: Las caras felices también son importantes, luego los templos también son importantes, pero quizá con 1/2 ya sea suficiente, ya que algunas de las maravillas permiten además aumentar la felicidad de la población de la civilización. 

Nota 8: La elección del líder debe ser bastante reflexionada ya que sólo puede tenerse 1 líder de cada era. En función de sus habilidades especiales debes basar el desarrollo de tu civilización; de esta manera llegarás más lejos en menos tiempo.
En función del líder elegido, darás preferencia a un aspecto ú otro de tu civilización, aunque no hay que olvidar que la mejor civilización es la mejor equilibrada.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.12
Comments entered on 23 Dec 2009:

Any game that bills itself as a civilization building game is going to get my attention. Like many others, I was concerned that this game would be weak because it lacked a map. That has turned out to be a completely unfounded worry. Through the Ages places an emphasis on building up an economic engine, developing technologies, and scoring points while not completing ignoring the aspect that conflict impacts the growth of an empire.

The first couple plays of this game was using the Basic and Advanced game versions. These are excellent to get a feel for the mechanics of the game, but to really see the luster and shine of this game, it needs to be played as a Full game with all three ages playing out. After several plays, certain strategies begin to present themselves for achieving victory, but because the card row plays out differently every game, a player must remain flexible to the changing circumstances.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Quite simply the best Civ game out there. Everything a civ game need is in the box: tech, worker/resource management, happiness of your population, military, leaders, wonders... It is the most "complete" game I own. 

I really like the Row of cards which ensure that no one will get all the same tech/upgrades. Sure you can get hose by this (especially if you cannot get a Farm/Mine upgrade Tech) but it ensures each game are different.

The Military aspect is cool too. If every one is at the same level nothing happens: like in real world! You have to maintain a military presence just so you won't get picked on.

The only fault of this game: it is easy to get behind the curve in every aspect of the game (Culture and ressources). When this happens there is almost no possibility of recovery. And for a game that long, being out of the game when there is still 1-2 hours to play is not that great :). 

Our Full game for 2 players clocks at 2h30. And it is probably the best 2h30 of gaming you can have.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Have not been able to play yet.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
For me it's just too long and dry. I feel like doing spread sheets, which can be fun sometimes, but Nations killed it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Finally played the FULL game, which is the way everyone should experience this game the first time. We called it with 1/3 of the 3rd deck left, as it was clear who would win.

I've played Civ and Advanced Civ before, and this definitely fits the bill as a card version of those, but I feel that unless you play it enough to know the game, the play time doesn't actually come in at any less than those games. It's supposed to be shorter, and with experience I'm certain it is. 

The question is, will I want to play this again, or even frequently?

Update:

Another play, and soon to see even more. It's been a long time coming getting it to the table, but since we've now got a following for it in our club I have no doubt that the plays for this one will rise.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
[microbadge=5]

[size=18][b]Best of 2006[/b][/size]

This game is amazing. I never thought I'd see a civilization game so perfectly rendered. The lack of map probably helps the game more than it hurts it, as the lack of geography helps control when conflict first emerges. The three levels of gameplay make it easy to teach the right players the correct level of difficulty, and the full game is a treasure trove of strategy, theme, and excitement.

My major complaint about the game is the horrible wooden discs you use to keep track of everything. They are too small and fiddly. 8 mm colored cubes would be vastly preferred, and I don't regret buying some to fix the components here.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Thanks to my 2009 Secret Santa I now have this in my collection!  Also, thanks to lorna's trip to Essen 2010, I also have the clear cubes, which improves the game alot for me (no more pencil erasers rolling around the table).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
A problem I have with playing the PC game Civilization online with other people is that games tend to last longer than a day or even two unless you restrict yourself to tiny maps that force combat from the get go, and then it becomes a race to eliminate players rather than allowing for all the various win conditions the game normally offers.

This game solves all of that. It is like playing PC Civilization vs. other people, except you can actually finish a game of it in under 4-8 hours! Still really long for a board game, but when that is what you want, there are few games finer than this.

I do think it very slightly loses out to the old Avalon Hill classic History of the World, though, where you get a little more narrative structure with a bit less grinding.

RATING: 10

RATING: 6
After repeated plays I have lowered my score on this one.  I enjoy the game but the aggression and wars make the game a real drag.  The game is too military centered.  Once you fall behind in military the game is over.  Sort of a arms race not a civ game.  Late in the game the only way to play is to advance yourself by beating down the weakest civ.  There is NO catch up in the game.  Once you fall behind you are done for.  If you fail to be able to grab an important card on your turn then your done for if you lose yellow tokens you are done for if you lose blue tokens you are done for and all of these can happen through no action you take.  Purely randomly.  So after repeated plays I have lowered my score based on the mean spirited feel this game has.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A very fun Civilization game that gives you a feel of the computer game without the map.  You use actions to build buildings, get leaders, build wonders, build military, etc.  

You use political actions to affect events in the future.  

Military is all important in this game and you cannot ignore it.  If you do, you lose.  

The games always play out differently depending on when certain cards come out.  But the game has a massive learning curve, it is "fiddly" and you are looking at about 1.5 hours per player if they are AP prone or it is your first few times playing.  Experience players could get it down to 1 hour per player, but that is after many plays.  

I like the game, it is great, but AP players need to stay away.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Everything that is said about downtime and play length problems with four players is true.  This is a game I would like to like on theme alone, so I might try this again with 2 or 3 players, but it doesn't really stand out enough from other euro-bland resource management games to justify its play time.

RATING: 5.9

The only real confusing thing is how the military operations work. All in all a fun civilization building experience. Be ready to dedicate several hours to this one though.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is a "heavy", interesting game with great interaction (via politics/aggression actins) and a good mix of strategy and tactical decisions, but overall a deeply strategic game.  

Once past the "simple" game, you find novel mechanics, interesting decisions, and great fun.  It really feels like you are building something...and with the political interaction, it is not solitaire (also interaction in the cards you pull from the board).  

It has been a while since I was this excited about a game.  It could very well end up being a 10, but I would need more plays to see if it stands the test of time.  However, I see TTA as a game I'd always want to play.  

Downsides: Play time - the game takes a while...if you want a faster game, you can play the "advanced" game and only two ages versus the full.  But, if you pull out TTA, it is likely the only game you will play that night.

By the 2nd game, when one player was done with actins and card draw, the next player set up and would begin his turn while the other did his housekeeping.  This kept the game moving along at a much faster pace (and reduced downtime).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Ok, do NOT play the simple game of this with the hopes of getting any sort of fulfilling experience.  It serves to teach the concepts of the full game only.  You can make some good solid choices and do poorly in the simple game.  It offers you cards that ONLY benefit long term play.  The simple game is NOT like the family version of Agricola, where you get a full game with some elements removed, and also teaches you the basics of the full.  In fact if you ever play the simple game of this, do NOT score it at the end.  Just chalk it up for learning concepts for the full game.  Just a warning.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
On the one hand, this seems like an interesting (mapless) civ game, but there are some issues that, when pared with the length, make it undesirable.  Primarily I have issues with the fact that the event cards mostly beat up on the weakest player, and reward the stronger/strongest player. 

It also seems like the kind of game that someone who really loves the Civ computer games would create, but it seems a bit fiddly (and long).

Playing 2 player online is a good experience.

--- 
Reevaluated after a few more plays with 3 players, this game has slipped a bit for me.  It's long and very tactical, but what kills me is the way the randomness, particularly of the military cards, can impact the game.

---
Okay, I am done with this game. Dropped to a 3 rating.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
2015-08 Traded in big trade, will play online or with friends

One of my very favorite games, but after playing online I don't want to go back. The counters are so fiddly and you spend too much time on the bookkeeping/counter tracking, when you could be strategizing. It's also so long that it's hard to bring to the table.

But online, all those issues disappear, especially if you're playing asynchronously. I love how the engine comes together, the sweep of time, and the variations introduced by the 2.0 and 3.0 versions (at least as implemented on BGO). 

I prefer playing with 4, but it works with 2 and 3, it's just a VERY different experience in both.

Played 3 times Table 1.0, countless BGO 2.0 and 3.0, BGA 1.0
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This game has somewhat nice atmosphere of civilization building. Governments, farms and mines, leaders, cultural buildings, armies, wars, colonizations, events... it includes almost all the factors which we can expect from a civ-game. But I don't think it is well constructed. It could be a very good game, but it is not.

1) It is almost solitary. Interactions are only aggresions and wars. But raising agression or declaring war is not so often a good choice. So there are just not enough interactions.

2) War and agression encourages players to gang upon the weakest. The weakest loses something(armies, points, populations, resources, etc.) and weakens again, resulting that it is hard for her or him to regain competant position after a couple of loss. It feels bitter.

1)   2) = The only form of direct interaction of this game is not so pleasant.

3) Much downtime. There is almost nothing to do during other players' turn. At least PoF last only 1 hour or so, but this game lasts 5-7 hours. If you play with 4, downtime almost kills. I may play 3-player game again, but never play 4-player game.

4) Some leaders too strong, some leaders too weak. They are not well-balanced.

5) Due to difficulties of upgrading technologies, anachronistic situations often occur, e.g. medieval cavalries with air forces.

6) Card-drafting mechanic. It is just arbitrary and abstract. Is there anything relevant to the historical development of civilizations in St.Petersburg-style card drafting? Why do technologies come out randomly, and why do their prices keep reduced? Moreover, its randomness with unblanced cards can hugely favor some lucky player.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
2014
650
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game is unique IMO as every player has to take into account plenty of aspects: military, industry, science, food, happiness, colonies and - last but not least - victory points. What is fine - as the ages progress you have opportunities to set back and improve the aspects you was lousy before (except colonies maybe). So - if you have absolutely no access to science before, you should go for substitutes like wonders or libraries or free science cards, eventually a card pops out that your science-satisfied rivals will not intend to get dearly, but that will be very valuable to you, so you have a nice chance to get it (except if someone plays destructively against you). Multiple ages almost guarantee that - if you want - you will eventually have opportunities to improve specific area, unlike many other games where you may never get a chance. Luck or lack of luck is what makes (at least this game) interesting and unique - you have no guarantee that you will get what you hope for. Then, at some point, you have to adapt your strategy, what is very interesting. 

There is a lot of balancing hidden, but not artificial, like say in [thing=2651]Power Grid[/thing]. There is also some brutal reality: weakest military civilization would be pondered by neighbors and events that take from weak and give to strong, scientific civ could quickly progress technology unraveling other areas, neglecting production or science may be difficult to catch up, etc. 

   Excellent game, being very close to reality, progressing your civ over many aspects is lots of fun, virtually no trade or negotiations make sure players sympathies and social skills are not included in the picture (not completely though - choice of aggression/war victims). Randomness is required and welcome here IMHO, but it will never win the game instead of you.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Rating is based on online play. I've never played in person, and don't really care to. I can see how fiddly this game is, and how prone to over-analysis and undo/redo turns. That would be excruciating in person over several hours.

Online, though, those drawbacks practically disappear, and what's left is a game with great theme, strategic arc, and game-to-game variability.

I'm also terrible at it!

RATING: 8
2/10 - after a few more plays, including 4p for the first time.  Still a 9.  The 3p is clearly the best, but 4p was fun too - biggest drawback is down time.  As for complexity, my hardcore 9-year old won in his second game, without any helps whatsoever.  Stick with it, the game is worth it.  I prefer one set of rules with an index, don't give me different games, bleah.

11/09 - after 15 plays - fantastic.  A classic.  Not a perfect game due to the mechanical aspects of the game - tiny cards, moving tiny bits all over the place, etc.

1/09 - after 4 or 5 plays it still feels new.  Each play is very different.  If you are a gamer, go straight to the full game.  This is maybe a little harder than something like Agricola, but still works pretty easily in the game itself.  As an avid SM's Civ series nut, this is the closest feeling board or card game in relation to the PC game series.  Truly epic, definitely works well.  Rating subject to change.

12/08 - Arrived at Christmas!!!!!  Awaiting replacement deck as mine was messed up - sad now.  Awesome customer service - decks complete - quick!

Have waited quite a while and now there is a reprint supposed to be available in Jan/Feb 08 (FunAgain).  It is $70 which is a bit steep, but if the quality of the components is decent (see threads - pictures of TtA) as DdJ describes then it is all good.  I am very, very much looking forward to this game.  For me, price comes down to how many hours I get out of something - my PC games (like Civ IV) shine in this area.  TtA sounds like the closest thing to Civ IV in cardboard and wood.

Still haven't pre-ordered (12/07).  I already have Agricola on pre-order.  I may have to wait and just buy this when it comes out early next year.  I can wait another six or eight weeks.

And now it is 2/08 and it is out.  And there are issues - not great quality parts, 80s but no 90s, the minor cube thingy.  I think this will continue to be a wait until there is an edition I feel fully satisfied with - or simply never.  It is amazing that on BGG people complain about how expensive Starcraft is vs. a game like TtA.  The value of the game is first and foremost the game, then the components.  I _know_ Starcraft is a great game.  I presume TtA is also.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
5 / 5 - Outstanding.

This is hard and heavy but grimly addictive. The intense nature of working out your turn means there's not as much table-talk as I'd like but there is some bluffing and there's just about enough interaction to keep this interesting. The theme is also engaging although it falls apart on close inspection, such as my uber-army of Napoleonic troops supported by jet fighters, but the sense of building up toward a greater goal is palpable. It's rare to find a game which manages to combine just enough theme and interaction with seriously heavy gameplay *and* potentially bottomless creative strategy - that's what sets this game apart from the crowd.

RATING: 9
best with 3
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I enjoy playing with the peaceful variant, and then adding the military strength to the point total at the end.

What I like:
- Lots of engine building and upgrading.
- Need to be fairly balanced in all areas to be most efficient.  You can feel the impact of areas that are weak or too strong.
- There's some direct conflict but it's not the main part of the game.
- Every action you take is important and usually you don't have wasted actions.
- Future events provide some long-term planning, but there is also tension in not knowing what future events your opponents have played.
- Rules were fairly intuitive and there were not a lot of little exceptions.

What I don't like:
- Long game length, especially with more players.
- Can have lots of downtime with more players.
- Lots of little pieces for bookkeeping.  Sometimes it's easy to forget if you've updated your counters.  We wrote a simple web interface to do most of the bookkeeping for us.
- Very unforgiving if you fail to establish a good engine by Age II
- Age III doesn't seem as interesting as the previous ages, because it's mostly about scoring lots of points. Perhaps the advanced game is a better enjoyment/time ratio for us.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Terribly laid out rulebook, but the full three age game is where it's at.

Through the Ages is a game which at first blush seems to have three or four main strategies, many of which are extremely luck dependent. As you delve into the experience, however, you begin to see the nuanced bits of tactics and strategy within the underlying architecture. I'm over 100 plays in and I'm still learning about ways to use particular cards in the game which I thought were useless cards when I first approached the design. A wonderful game to delve into for a good long time.

RATING: 10


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game is awesome.  It is both very strategic and low variance -- because you know *which* cards will come out, though you may not know when -- and tactical because you have to adjust to your opponent(s) play.  The only randomness really comes from drawing military cards but in exchange they provide bluffing opportunities.  There are a few downsides:  the military cards *can* screw you occasionally, the rulebook is awful, the setup is lengthy, and with a 1 hour per player game time good luck getting this to your gaming table.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
12/03/09 Obtained. I have the third/final printing, that corected some mistakes of the previous two. 
05/28/11 Played a three-player Simple Game. Overall I think Through the Ages looks good and plays smoothly. Though I do have a few small quibbles with a couple of the icons. I have sort of mixed feelings concerning the rule book. Oh, everything is in there. Its written to initially feed you only what you need to know for your first game. That's great for getting you into the game. But then when you want to move on to the Advanced or Full game its makes it hard go back and find some of the basic rules, as they are buried in between a huge amount of examples. My rating is provisional until I play the Advanced and Full games.
