RATING: 8
My '8' is a strong eight. The rating is based on one full advanced 4-player game which took 6.5h.

A good and borderline excellent game. I could see that 3-player game is the best. 4-player game dragged a bit and there was some downtime (noone of us had played before).

I expected a bit more fluid gameplay but I have to admit it managed to include all the important Civ game features.

Update 1.12.2008: - after 3-player game. Rating raised to '9'. Three player game is definite sweetspot and this time we played a couple of things correctly which improved some questionable aspects we encountered at our first game. Magnificent Civ-game. But I am hesitated to play this with any other player # than 3.

Update 2012: Rating dropped to '8'. Great game but now it has gotten relatively repetitive...

.mikko

RATING: 7
Interesting game based on one advanced game straight away (3.5 hours). On the negative side: fiddly bead management, slow, learning curve, very solitary playing and I was missing the element of trade which has been so crucial to development of civilizations through the ages. On the positive side: you are really building something up, lots of choices, an innovative mechanism, lots of cards, so lots of variation, well balanced, keeps you focused all the time. I will get more plays in and will judge again. Rating may go up or down.
Update: slightly downgraded after another play. It is a very good game, but I am just missing the fun factor. I am more critical about these longer games: it really has to be worth the time spent. Playing time is valuable and I might play it again, but there are many better ways to spend your gaming night. The solitary play, the lack of interaction and just not enough fun factor are my main problems. But it remains somewhat of a love-hate relationship with this game, as it is indeed special too. Any way, play it, it is worth judging yourself. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Another hit dead-center for me.  Wow, what a fun game to play.  You really get a sense of building a civilization.  One thing is for sure, attacking a neighboring civilization is not an easy task.  I really liked the overwhelming quantity of cards and their different interaction.  I can see this game growing on me :-)

Edit after 5 games : This is really a deep game.  After 5 games, I can really appreciate the quality of the gameplay.  Evidently, with all games this long, you NEED good partners, which I am very lucky to have.

Edit after 8 games : This goes up from 9 to 10.  This game grows on me.  The more I play it, the more I discover things interlocking together.  For a game this long, It's so good you can't be wrong.

Edit after 20 games : The more it goes, the more I see different strategies.  I am certain that this game will be a hit for me for many years to come...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a very interesting, very involving civ game. The mechanisms for balancing production against corruption and workers against happiness are simple, but cleverly executed, though the size of the tokens and their sheer number makes this slightly fiddly. The whole game is a little fiddly, given the number of cards and other components, but this is a minor problem for the experience. A larger problem is the play time, which is long when you look at the clock, but doesn't feel it when you play. I think I'd want to keep this to three players max just because of the sheer length of time it takes. The problem is more one of finding the time to play rather than thinking it runs long.

RATING: 7
In the past, I haven't been a huge fan of civilization-based games, but this one has a beautiful simplicity and elegance to it that makes it very enjoyable to play.  There's always so much to do and so few resources with which to do it.  There's so many different ways of getting points and your strategy is ever-changing based on the cards available and the strengths and weaknesses of your opponents.  I dislike direct attacking in any game I play, so I'm not wild about the war aspect of this game, but that's merely a personal preference and not a slight against the design in any way.  This is a long one, but definitely fun to play.

RATING: 4
Very epic in scope despite being a card-game. The whole "micromanage your empire" is a well-functioning and fun system of moving bits here and there to adapt to the circumstances. A bit tactical if you don't know the deck, but you will be seeing all the civil cards (which are the main drivers of your "resources", while the military-side is how you interact with your opponents) so if you know them all you know what to plan for - which will inform your overarching strategy much more than initial plays where you just smash together whatever happens to be available.

I liked it, and I can really see myself loving a computer adaptation (like on BGA) but I won't be loving the face-to-face game unless it speeds up a bit. At three hours with 3 or 4 players, and an hour and a half with 2 then I would like it - but I can't really see it happening without going through several plays that go well beyond that. A lot of it is simply the fiddly parts, moving small (way to small!) bits around and hoping you remembered to do each step correctly. The decisions are fine and take the time they take - though I'm not sure I like how it all scales up and up and up - perhaps I'd like it better if your civil actions especially kept to a rather flat 4-5 instead of scaling up to 9 or beyond. Anyway...

I like it (like I said) and I'll be happy to play it more but it won't reach the lofty heights for me.

RATING: 7.5
This is a great game, but it has some problems.  It's too long for what it is.  The artwork is largely missing, and what is there is not very good.  The theme doesn't come through terribly well.

But it's a great Euro card game.  It just suffers from it's own weight.  I'd love to play it again, but it's such a large time commitment that I don't see it being played often.

However, there appears to be a lot of flexibility in the design, and the mechanisms blend together very well.  It does give you a feeling of building something, which is great, but I don't necessarily feel like I'm building a civilization.

I really like it, but I feel I should like it more.  With that said, I'm looking forward to the next game.  And with that said, I'm hoping I can find another Civilization game that fits my needs better... Clash of Cultures? Fingers crossed!

Edit: I also picked up Nations as a direct replacement for this.

RATING: 9
Essen '06  Wow.  What a great game.  I think this may be the Civ-lite everybody searches for.  Played a full game in about 4.5 hours, and could probably finish a little before 4 hours.  Also includes options for shorter or friendlier games.  Components excellent considering the small company producing it. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is a great game once the learning curve has been overcome. Once all players are on even footing the game tells a wonderful story with each play. Civilizations grow, decline, get attacked, recover, and in the end, build some wonders and head off into the space age. It's a long game, but not so unforgiving that an early mistake dooms you to last place each time. And after 20+ plays now, I am still amazed at how well balanced everything is. You just don't have enough resources to build too much of any one unit or building; you must plan, diversify, and stay within your means. The game's length will keep many gamers away. But for gamers who can find time to both learn and appreciate this one, the game is a masterpiece.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
This game was intimidating the first time we played, and to be completely honest, every time since.  So far we have both managed not to run away from the gaming table screaming in distress though.  Fortunately, there are three versions of the game, basic, advanced and full.  We played the basic version 3-4 times before graduating to the advanced version.  Usually I am rearing to add complexity to our games, but in this instance I wasn't ready to try out the full game until we had played the advanced version 4-5 times.  It was great fun when we finally did.  When you read the directions, the main difference seems to be the addition of another age, but then you realize that losing two people from your population bank each age forces you to really adjust your focus to keeping workers happy and fed.  We both had stretches where we were completely unable to add new workers.  We have only used aggression once, and didn't attempt a war, but simply having the threat of war makes you motivated to not lose the arms race, kind of like the cold war.  We like that aggressiveness is not rewarded but complete weakness is punished.  Its quite a lot to manage to be successful, and the longer game makes it imperative that you grow in a balanced way and aren't stuck with mines or farms or urban building stuck back in antiquity.  The flow of cards is interesting and does give the feel of moving through time.  Playing the full game finally inspired us to upgrade our government, as before it seemed too big a sacrifice.  Yellow cards help when you have failed to sufficiently develop a resource, be it science, food or ore, but there can be long stretches without them and this starts to be less effective the deeper into the game you get.  The event cards and colonies add a whole other dimension, as having colonies can really help you, and it is a joy to expand your empire.  At the same time, you can feel some trepidation at triggering an event, as you may be weak militarily or have your stored food ravaged by rats.  Avoid the event cards though and you miss out on an easy way to rack up additional points.  Their is deep satisfaction in building a wonder, even if it a fast food chain that causes your whole civilization to become obese (presumably).  And if you go too long without a successful leader your society will just feel a little more aimless and lackluster.  Get the right blue technology cards and find yourself swept away in the whirl of progress.  Somehow most of our games end up close, and often one person will be way ahead only to see the other person storm from behind when we score the bonus points at the end.  No lead feels safe, and there are some ways to leverage your weakness, through waves of nationalism if you are week or sabotage if you are bitter at another nations success.  This is so much fun, and as long as it is, I always feel like I don't have enough time at the end as the game keeps on moving along.  Its imperative that you let the other person start their turn while you are clearing out your own turn though or the game starts to drag.  A lot of complex rules that we have occasionally messed up in the past, but I think we are finally getting the hang of this.  A ton of strategy and very fun even if it does make my head spin. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
A beast of game but it's rules are quite streamlined.  At it's root it's a card drafting / engine-building game with a strong civ-building theme. UPDATE: knocked down half a point -- I like this game but it's too damn fiddly and takes too damn long.  Our group decided to take it online which I'm looking forward to.  2010-11-05

UPDATE: playing online drastically improves the game.  Raised rating back up a point.  In fact I don't think I ever want to play this in person again.  2011-01-04

RATING: 9.75
I held off reviewing this until I had quite a few plays under the belt.  The designers have done a fantastic job of capturing the civ experience.   I think this would not be that great of a 4player game (maybe a 3 or 4 rating... at best.   I think the military aspect would end up with someone getting hosed and not having a good time at all), but 2 and 3 player works brilliantly.   At times, I wish there was a way to extend each of the ages with some added cards, but the game just functions so well that anything else might be a detriment... but it is fun to think about.    

Components could easily be better, but it works.  A set of wooden cubes gets rid of the beads.

*********** UPDATE 2009 **************

I have become more convinced that the 4 player game blows and will not be trying that again.  I also think 3 player is slightly better than 2 now.  

**************************************

2 player starting to fall decently behind 3 player.  while much better than 4 player, it is more susceptible to a perfect string of card availability for one player vs the other and can lead to a bit of a runaway.   

3 player is still awesome and one of the best gaming experiences to be found.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I see depth in this game. I love the thematic mechanisms. I understand its fans. I have a single play under my belt and my reaction is very mixed. The first hour was quite enjoyable, but then the downtime mounted, I fell behind in military strength and was repeatedly punished by event cards (no wars), my engine completely stalled out as my population was decimated. I passed entire turns to make tiny progressions in my output or to stick a finger in the dyke.

I want to like this game more, but the time commitment (our 4p game with 3 new players lasted over 6 hours), the consequences of early misplays/unfortunate happenstances, and the dramatic impact of skill differences might make this a non-starter. I plan to try a 2p online game with a similarly skilled opponent as my second play to gain some familiarity and hone my opinion (or at least prepare for the next, if any, live play).

My reticence to commit to another play makes it impossible to rate this higher than a 6, despite my instinct that the game is wonderfully developed.

UPDATE: After half a dozen plays, I'm liking this game less and less. There is no cost or downside to aggressors, so even one point of military supremacy allows players to pin down opponents and force them to choose between a harsh penalty or sacrificing military strength just to remain otherwise unscathed. You either take your lumps or increase the strength divide, which is all the more punishing when the wars occur. In my first play I ignored military. Later I thought I could balance military against economy and culture. Now I don't see any alternative to a pure military strategy. Why generate resources and earn points when you can just bully the other players and take theirs?

Once you fall behind in this game, you can never claw your way back. The leader is continually rewarded with free prizes. This game has ended a very short run with me and I don't see any replayability left. While I acknowledge that there must be *something* here, as it has such loyal fans and the designer is clearly quite clever, for me it's over.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
THROUGH THE EXCEL SPREADHSEET. This is an involving, complex game with many good points, but I found it difficult to perceive how well I was doing, and the fact that the game does not visually make it easy to see what is going on does not tally well with my preferences. If I am spending 4+ hours with a game, I would much rather play a war game than this, as I tend to need a map and a better overview of what is going on to grasp how a game is panning out. The small, fiddly bits, and the fact that the tracks are spread out and not as easy to read as they might be are both negatives for me. I'd try it again, but I don't think this is my kind of game - too much abstracted resource management, the theme doesn't always stick. It also lacks interactivity, and the four player game leaves too much of a gap between your turns. I play too fast and my opponents play too slow. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Played the basic (simplest version - only 1 age) once, the advanced (two ages) once, and the full game (three ages) once.

This is a ... complicated ... game.  There is a lot to balance, and a lot to explain.  However, the boards are extremely well designed, and once the rules are explained things fall into place and the game is relatively easy to keep track of if you focus.

Long story short, players are attempting to build their civilization by allocating population markers.  Players must track their food production and consumption, resource production, military power, happiness, scientific production, and cultural production simultaneously, all while deciding what new buildings to build and cards to take.  The board design makes this easier than it sounds.

Confusingly, when population makers are used to improve the civilization, they turn into buildings, farms, mines, or military units (depending on where they're used).  Also, the cards that say "Mine" are not actually mines; they're the _technology_ you need to build mines (which you actually build by paying resources and moving a yellow population marker onto the building).  However, once you understand those two items, the game is extremely easy to follow.

There are a lot of rules, and on our first game the simplest version of the game took us a few hours. 

The advanced version adds in a lot of complexity (if you don't keep your people happy they revolt, you can attack other players, etc.), and makes the game much more enjoyable.  However, if you're starting out, for the love of all that's good in the universe please start out with the simple version: the advanced would be insane.

The game feels like it should have a lot of replayability, since the order the technology cards comes out in dictates a lot of what's possible (and valuable) during the game.  

The full game (all three ages) takes a LONG time to play - our first game of that length was nearly 6 hours long.  It was a great 6 hours, and it was enthralling enough that I didn't realize it was taking that long, but it was still ... long.  But the game is best with all three ages, no doubt (as you have the full ability to upgrade technologies, and can really take different paths to victory).  

[Update: rating up to 8.5 after playing the advanced version]

And if I don't play each turn with perfectly efficiency I will lose.  And this doesn't even get into the components, with artwork I don't care for, player tableaus with spots for only about half of your cards, a gigantic scoring track that should be replaced by a scoring pad and pencil, those damn tiny dots to slide around, and the overall fiddliness of the game.  I can't ever imagine getting this played in full outside of BGO, and for that alone I don't understand its lofty ranking on BGG.

Pierwsza edycja - folia
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Military is definitely the game-winning strategy, and that's too bad.  You just can't win without it, and because it's so important, all else in the game pales in comparison.  Military wins events which net victory points, military wins colonies which give all-important extra token, military wins wars which can swing the game 40-60 points in a single turn (and often does).  Fall behind in military and you will probably lose.  You don't have to have the best military in the end, but chances are high that you'd better have the best military through a good chunk of the game, or you'll lose for sure.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Through the Ages is a decent game, and I can see why it is so appealing. I'd certainly play it again and would seriously consider purchasing a digital version that took care of the fiddly bookkeeping and had a strong AI.

However, as a game for my own collection, it doesn't really fit. A resource management and engine-building game at its core, Through the Ages does not, in my opinion, outdo [boardgame=31260][/boardgame], but takes twice as long for what I deem to be a similar experience. While it adds a layer of light conflict in, I'd rather go all out with [boardgame=9625][/boardgame] for a truly epic multi-player conflict game. Furthermore, [boardgame=62219][/boardgame], while nothing like Through the Ages, seems to mix these elements together in a more satisfying way for me. With only so much interest in 3+ hour games, Through the Ages is the odd man out.

In addition, although I am drawn to the civ theme, I don't really get the appeal of Christopher Columbus leading your civilization for 600 years while building the Taj Mahal and the Kremlin, among other goofy combinations. Not a big deal, but it's another hindrance to me diving into the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Now THIS is a game!  Yes, it is fiddly and there are a lot of things to keep track of after each turn (the various tracks, feeding, production/corruption, etc.).  Typically at the end of the game I have a headache, and I assume it's because my brain never stops working -- either I'm planning my next move or I'm making sure I didn't forget one of the fiddly end-of-turn steps.

But the game itself is fantastic.  Many paths to victory.  Meaningful, non-obvious decisions that never stop.  A feeling of satisfaction as you watch your civilization improve more and more with each passing turn.

Only downsides: I don't like all of the end-of-round maintenance that occurs, as there's enough to break my concentration and take me 'out of the game' for a minute.  And the game takes so long to play that I don't get to play it as much as I'd like.  But the game itself is wonderful.

Update: Lowered the rating.  I still love the game, but ultimately it's a bit too long & fiddly for my tastes now, so it's just not getting as much play as it used to.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
+BGO2, BGO3, czech and polish (P&P expansions) ?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of those rare games that actually delivers on all that it promises.

This is the premier civ building game in my opinion. The lack of a board only helps it to shine. Military may not hold as important a place as a conflict game, but it still plays an important enough role to require attention.

The technologies, wonders, scientific advancement and leaders are all present in great numbers and the game will never play the same twice due to player choices and card distribution.

The science element is a major winner for me and whilst some of the token movement and allocation may appear fiddly at first, it is fairly intuitive and only takes 1 play to fully grasp. Quite simply a game that mimicks a classic like Civ for the PC couldn't work without a little micro management.

My first game went for 7 hours. This will come down by about 2.5 hours with another play or two. Despite that I hardly noticed the time go by and my wife...yes my wife...(this is not sexist...rather Patty does not like games beyond 3 hours as a general rule)said the same.

One play and I had to own it. Truly awesome.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
9
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Available Zach 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This is a pretty good and interesting game.  However, it is a "heavy" (deep) game that takes at least 4 hours to play and can be brutally tough.  If you don't have a dedicated group that is willing to play this game at least 3 times within a 3 month time period, don't even bother with this game.  Because there is a LOT to digest, and playing it every once in a while is just a waste of time, since you won't grasp some of the game concepts and mechanisms.

Although it is a card driven game, the theme is decent.  A bit too long and tough.  This takes away from the fun factor, and limits how often it would be brought to the table, and ONLY for hard core gamers.

Update:
After 3 dozen plays of the 'FULL' game (online) my rating drops from 9 to 7.5.  Good game, but unforgiving for those who have fallen behind militarily (sometimes through no fault of their own).  Game has a luck/skill ratio that is not quite right for a heavier game of this length.  

Resigning from the game is a real option, bringing into question game balance.  It also makes for an unsatisfying gaming experience due to the lack of return on time invested.

Note: Best played online.

Update 2:  Another 500 (online) plays, and I'm obviously enjoying the game and coming back for more punishment.  Even with the above mentioned flaws, I gotta raise my rating back to a 8.5.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Here is a question never top ask me, because it ramps my GTP to infinity:
"Which one do you like more TTA or sidM Civ?"

Now I would still recommend SidM Civ. It's prettier (ameritrash, yes yes, FF does what it does best), the map and variation in it, it's combat is, well, kinda more fun and the various civ's add more flavor, though if you go "pro" with it, certain house rules needed to be added especially if you want it to last a bit longer (well like adding a variant such as - no technology victory etc.)

But if you want a game that is solid mechanically with no house rule requirement and no "this is civ/combo is way OP" comments, go TTA.

RATING: 10

Update:

Sam and his bro came over last night and we started our first ever Full Game version of Through the Ages.  OMG.  It took SIX AND A HALF HOURS!!!  :surprise:

Admittedly Sam's bro is not a 'gamer' like us, but he did well and came in second by the end of the game.  I was first, which may have affected my overall feeling of the game being absolutely brilliant.  Totally up my street.  And to be honest the difference in our two lead scores wasn't that great: 122 to 115 after all those hours of nail biting gaming, with poor Sam trailing at 85.  His own fault though, he started launching aggressions early on, which meant we all had to militarily escalate quickly.  At which point retribution came thick and fast!

Totally great game though, jumped to my current top spot even though right now I feel like I could lay down and die - they didn't leave until 2.45am...  :zombie:

RATING: 10
Played it ten times now and this has rightly become the holy grail of civilization builder games, in my opinion.  Simple mechanisms...a card game basically, no map and super fun to play.  The simple game is simple and quick, but the advanced and full games are what my rating is for.  The scope is wonderful and the game play is exciting and just about as good as it can get for me. Rules are in perfect English and very clear even though the game was designed in the Czech Republic.  Art work is fabulous and the quality of the box and contents and rules is very high.  Found at Essen in 2006 and helped the 2nd edition become a reality.  Now that I can play it easily on Board Game Arena, I like it even more.

RATING: 8
This game easily could be a 10. It may end up that way for me eventually. I've never seen a game that had so many checks and balances on everything. I genuinely feel like I'm managing a civilization with every move I take. This is mechanic design at it's finest. The game is long. But I find myself wishing the game was longer on occasion because I didn't get to unlock some technology, or hadn't finished building my wonder perhaps. I started playing Sid Meiers Civ games on the computer and wanted something that felt like that in a board game. Here it is. And it's shorter than a game of Civ. I have two questions, one big and one less important. Why does the game have to be this ugly to look at? And the big one, WHY WOULD YOU USE ROUND WOODEN MARKERS? Jesus...

RATING: 10
Through the Ages is a really remarkable game.  I really enjoy playing it, and I find that I can't stop thinking about it when I'm not playing it.  For me, it is a fantastic 2-player game to play at lunch at work.  My buddy and I can get through about an age a day, and at this speed the game is absolutely wonderful.  I really enjoy the engine building aspect of this game, trying to make my civilization as capable as I can.  I have yet to really flex my military muscle, but I feel that there's a lot of potential there too.

The game does have some downtime issues with more players, and it is fiddly as all hell.  The little round markers roll everywhere, which is not my favorite, but despite all this I still really love this game.  The fact that it plays really well with 2 and with 3, which are my two most common play group sizes, is a real bonus.  I'm very glad that I was able to get this game, and I think this is one that I'll enjoy playing for a long time.

RATING: 9
The modern civilization game. No board to conquer, no armies to battle against... lots of though calls and fun inside this little box. Probably increases its rating after the complete game.

Despite the 4 hours it takes to play, this game is awesome. This is the most difficult game I've played so far (as 21/05/2009), and it challenges me in a way I've never been challenged before for a game.  I would love to play this game every week. A solid 9, almost like a 10... if it wouldn't last for that much time. What I'm sure of, is this game is going right into my top 10.

07/07/2010: Not only this game has reached my top 10, but now it's one of my 3 favorites. The perfect 10.

04/03/2013: After playing many games (mostly online), I've decided that this is no longer a top 10 game. It all comes down to the better execution of the military strategy. If you don't plan ahead the military race, you will face an overwhelming force taking away your culture points.  I still think this is a great game, but it drove itself outside my hall of fame.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Best civilization building board game I have played. It has some flaws though and it is really unforgiving to new players. Free tip: make sure you do not have the lowest military! What I like about this game is that skill plays a huge part in it. The better player wins almost every single time. The problem with the game is that it rewards beating down already losing players. It's common to see everyone raid one player over and over again, without him being able to do anything about it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Players are drafting cards from a row. Some cards cost an action point to take, others take two action points, and some take three. You start the game with 4 action points (called civic actions). The cards start in the antiquity age, and go through ages I to III. You watch your civilization evolve in this time period. Cards consist of leaders, wonders or technologies. For instance, an antiquity leader is Moses, who helps your farming production. You draft cards, then play them according to their cost.So far so good, this sounds like St. Petersburg, you say. Each player also has a mat, with tokens which keep track of population and resources. Most cards generate VPs, technology, happiness, increase military strength, etc. Most cards don't generate abilities unless there is a worker on it. Workers can be produced on farms, and resources for the worker are generated on mines. It usually cost a number of resources to move a worker to a card. Now, one has to balance their workers, resources and happiness level. If a player does not have enough happiness, then workers revolt and a player will not produce resources. A player also has to pay a corruption cost for more resources they consume. So one has to watch out for not overproducing and finding an even balance.Now, thrown into this game is the military (dubbed the political action) phase. There is a military deck of cards, where players can draw cards. These cards consist of war/aggression cards (attacking your neighbour), event cards, defence cards or colonize cards. In the early ages, if you are stronger than your opponent, then you can attack them to gain resources, or permanently take away their resources. The event cards, benign at the very beginning, then favor the stronger military who gains something, and the weakest military usually loses something. **** I really like the drafting cards aspect of the game. I like thinking about the special powers and what you can do. However, the military part of the game, I dislike. It's not my type of game, since the weakest military player will get pounded. There is no mercy, since it is to the advantage of the stronger military to declare war or play aggression against a much weaker opponent, since victory is virtually assured. Thus, I have a love/hate feeling towards this game. I definitely have to be in the right frame of mind to play. The event cards each turn can feel random and can cause grief to the person who is the weakest. It also takes around 4-6 hrs to complete a game, and does not play well at all with 4 players. So I really like one aspect of the game, the civilization part, but I dislike the military aspect of the game. The military aspect doesn't suit my personality. But I suppose one can adapt. 

To be fair, this game plays best as an online implementation. Face to face, it takes a long time. It plays better online. Still, it seems you have to spend some effort on military, so it tends to limit the range of variety you can try. It's fairly impossible to ignore military completely, which would be a nice option to try, but you would get picked on. I've mainly played this as 3 player, and with another person potentially attacking you, then it can skew some games in favour of someone else. Sure, you say, build up your military, which you have to do, and it would be nice if there other options to that. It's a decent game, but not a top tier game for me. I like how the cards are phased so they come out in certain eras That has been designed well. But the attacking with military just isn't my style of game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Certainly takes a few plays to get to grips with, but right from the outset you can see the potential!  The rules are poorly written (up there with the worst!), ambiguous and wordy, but worth soldiering through.

The (major) downside is the time taken - particularly if you have people taking time mulling over decisions.

UPDATE: We've got faster so the game is up to a 10. It helps if you can trust your opponent to score whilst you have your go. You need to make sure you are planning as much as you can during your opponents turn. Otherwise the downtime is painful.

All my other games seems to pale into insignificance since we've started playing this! LOVE it!

RATING: 2
Seems very clever the first time you play it. However, further plays reveal that: 1) the cards play you, rather than the other way around; 2) military is far, far too important (but also swingy thanks to relying on random card draws - and borderline broken when someone who already has a slight edge then gets to take Napoleon before anyone else can), and 3) that the game is a little long and fiddly for what it is.

Emphatically replaced by superior reimplementation 'Nations'.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Staggeringly clever mechanics make the broad brush of history come to life in this game. Crucial are the early proper management of your mining and agricultural resources. 

The bloke who owned the game launched us newbs straight into the advanced game and seemed to enjoy himself, rubbing his chin and thinking while doling out advice here and there. I layed the foundations of my demise by sporting whizz bang scientific output in period 2 backed by only stone age mines. Snapping up the Gandhi leader card was all that saved me from annihilation.

War is cleverly simulated via cards, with the results of a campaign being, fittingly, economic plunder or the enemies' loss of cultural prestige.

Enjoy this satisfying epic with coffee. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
There is a subtle economy that underlies this game. Games like Puerto Rico, Agricola, RftG, Hansa Teutonica and Le Havre have obvious engines to build to grow your power. Generally, you need more actions to break open an advantage against an opponent. TTA is not as intuitive. Monarchy, for example, is a poor investment though it gives you that additional action advantage.

Winning in TTA is an exercise in bleeding a rock. The advantages you slowly gain are so subtle that they often cannot be fully comprehended until late in the game.

There does seem to be a few prevailing strategies, but the game remains deliciously tactical. Not a 10 because the time commitment is steep and I can't say I would want to play it always at any time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
Just me, or do the aggression cards seriously imbalance the game? In a game with this high of a reputation, it strikes me as very odd that players can tamper with each others' bits to the extent allowed by the cards -- effectively doubling one player's turn while setting the other's back by the same -- a triple advantage, all from luck of the draw. If there is a next time, I'll have to see if the no aggression variant might redeem this somewhat stinker. And what is up with the incredibly tiny rectangles in the score track? How many times, when sliding the cards left, do the score markers move left as well?

RATING: 2
3 player game, from start to finish with rules explanation took 7 hours, that alone dooms this game for me. I would rather play two or three other meaty games in the same amount of time it takes to play this one. Hence the rating. The rules are much more complex than that of an average gamer's game, and there's lots of downtime. Can't really plan your actions until it is your turn. There are a lot of different cards, which makes it very diffcult to see the game as a whole initially, but ensure replayability. If you don't mind the above, and willing to invest the time, than it is an interesting system.

RATING: 7

It lacks a sort of epic 'feel' I'd expect from a game about the rise of a civilization, there's no 'drama' in it. That having been said, it's good at what it does, and has a decent amount of interaction and some good opportunities for conflict. My other main problem tends to be 'runaway leader' syndrome, it can be impossible to recover if you've taken a beating. Experience may win out over that issue, and I'm certainly willing to play a few more times to see if that's the case.

RATING: 9
A great civilization game. There's some maintenance overhead but otherwise the game runs quite smoothly, and feels a lot shorter than it is. Too long with four, great with two, and at its best with three.

The new American edition has serious production quality issues. The materials used in cards and the box are of typical Chinese bad quality. Usability has been downgraded as well: The player pieces are cylinders (!) and worst of all, the two game boards have been merged, meaning that you are continuously knocking around the scoring tokens every time you handle the cards. Also, putting the choking hazard sign on the top cover is absolutely ridiculous.

RATING: 6
I wanted to like this game but after one play I just cannot. If there ever was a fiddly game this is it: very large number of small cards with text on them and tiny pieces that are moved from one place to another. On their turns players need to go through several new cards and ponder whether they suit their purposes. Fiddlines is not the only thing wrong with the game. It takes a huge amount of time for what it is. It is also very linear and there is nothing to do when it is not your turn. There are no negotiations and no player interactions to speak of. I found it even hard to follow what others were doing on their turn. The downtime really killed this game for me. However, the scope of the game is most impressive and I have to admit that the game is rather well designed so I can see others enjoying it. What I am trying to say is this is not my cup of coffee. Though, I am ready to give it another go someday. Hopefully it works better for me then.

RATING: 7
I originally rated this a "9" after a few plays, but it has quickly dropped in my esteem.

I almost feel like the designers tried too hard to make the game balanced.  That is, there are too many counterbalances to over-expansion, in the form of corruption, starvation, etc.  After a while it starts to feel very fiddly and a little too much like book-keeping.  I often find myself asking, "shouldn't some sort of computer be doing all this end of turn stuff?"  I also wish that there was more player interaction, other than military actions and taking cards from the line.  

That said, there are still a lot of things I like about this game, and I'd be happy to play it again with experienced players.  I just don't feel like teaching it to anyone new anymore.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
In Through the Ages players fight for the biggest amount of culture produced since the dawn of organized civilization, going through all ages until today during a few hours. Civil and military events appear, as well as important figures in history and key technological or intellectual developments.

As a game in itself, it is supposed to be not only the ultimate distillation of the civilization genre (due to its stripped-down, card-driven system for marking both events and developments) but also a game in which the worker placement mechanic gets pushed to its very limit: counters measure a huge range of variables including achieving wonders, building all sorts of infrastructure, establishing military or government models and last but not least different types of resources. To add the right amount of luck, cards are drafted from a line.

The end result is as dense as the two previous paragraphs: a game that manages to be compact within its scope but still offer a huge amount of information to deal with. Its learning curve is not particularly steep (it takes a simple game to know how to move forward) but very long: there are loads of possible combinations of cards, loads of different strategies to try out, loads of possible choices even during a single turn... Through the Ages is no light fare at all, nor something to be played just once every half a year - to fully appreciate all the intricacies in its design, it demands continued, full immersion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Very good mechanics. Very good setting. Quite good graphics. Interesting and innovative mechanics. There is a war system and there are many ways to try to stop the winner, but everything without reducing the game to a "all against him".

Only some minor problems: 
- that damned little round tokens which go around everywhere, 
- THE SCORE TRACK WHICH IS SMALLER THAN THE SCORE TOKENS
- very intricate to explain to new players, which act as punching balls for the first 10 games

However, its 2-4 hours flow smoothly and without losing time or having to wait too much between turns.

UPDATE AFTER MORE THAT 200 face-to-face games and more than 100 online games: the game is even more interesting than before. Now its only drawback are players whose strategy is war-war-war-and-nothing-else who can turn it into a draw-the-right-tactic game... but experienced players learn how to deal with them!

UPDATE AFTER A COUPLE OF YEARS: new edition has solved the first two problems. Its only single problem now remains that I need an entire afternoon to explain it to a new player, only having him able to follow the rules without any competitive strategy.

RATING: 9
Really, my only negative comments to this wonderful game are that it takes a while between turns (play with 3) and that the little bits are really fiddly. Those things are nothing to how fun it is. Build your civ up, decide which paths of victory to take, watch so that your opponents don't become too powerful militarily, and hope that someone doesn't take that card you REALLY want!

With further plays, I have encountered an issue. There are wild swings with certain cards and with winning or losing a war. I addition, there are end game cards that are really overpowered.  One game I led 2nd place by 30 points with 2 turns left and ended up in LAST in a 4 player game!!

That said, the game is so fun to play I can only deduct a half point for it's drawbacks and still consider it one of the best games of all time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
03/2010:
Amazing, absolutely amazing! 

I know one should be careful with superlatives, but the moment I'm writing these lines I feel that TtA might be the best game I have played so far.

UPDATE 05/2010:
I realized that I frequently miss some player interaction, especially after having played FFG's Civilization. The way it is, I'm actually more in love with that civilization building theme than with the game play. 
I highly admire the streamlined implementation of the complex relationships between resources, population, happiness, military etc into simple mechanisms. TtA is a master piece. It feels wonderful to play that game, yet I just think it could be better SOMEHOW. 

Another point: with 4 players, downtime really becomes an issue. I would say it's best with 3. 

Rating dropped by 1.

In all honesty: The game is filled with things I avoid. If it wasn't for the outstandinly immersed Civilization theme, that game would hardly be a 6 in my book. 

HOUSE RULES CURRENTLY UNDER CONSIDERATION
- 2 political actions per turn
- pacts may be negotiated
- pacts may be cancelled for free after agressions and/or wars between the respective civilizations
- in case of agressions and/or wars, third civilizations may support one side via bonus cards if they sacrifice at least one unit. Third civilizations may be bribed to give support (resources, technologies, food)
- military row

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Holy crap is this game ever amazing.  I know, I know - I sound like a fanboy - but in this case it's true.  If you like economic engine / snowball type games, this is very nearly the pinnacle of the genre, giving you a massive sandbox in which to play.

While the key requirements the game throws at you are constant for all players (keep your people fed and happy, keep your military competent and keep your production as large and efficient as possible), the ways the civs develop will diverge sharply thanks to the types of Leaders those civs have and what kinds of Wonders the civs build.  Add to that the variety of tech upgrades you can invest in and the random nature of how the techs become available and you have a game with tremendous replayability - I don't see a single 'killer combo' which neuters all others yet, although I haven't played the game often enough to be sure.

There is also just enough randomness in the game - although it's randomness the players have a say in - to keep players off-balance and having to prepare for the unexpected.  Single-minded pursuits of victory points will often leave a player stuck as some unforseen event wreaks havoc with carefully-laid plans.

I've played the game several times, including 3+ Full Games now, and don't see wanting to stop playing anytime soon. Upped my rating to a 10 - it's that good.

Update: I've played 10+ times now and no end in sight for my enjoyment of this game. One of my 5 favourite games of all time.

RATING: N/A
A great game which has a lot to offer.
Variety of cards and card appearance makes for replayability.

There is a lot to manage, different resources that need to be balanced or you will suffer the consequences from your neighbours.

Military strength is a must, which does not appeal to me.
Actually is a race of who can handle the best army, the rest of the game is just to support it. Ignore your army strength and you're out.

Cons:
I just don't see the theme anywhere.
The playtime is too long. Absurd.
A long steep learning curve. Not worth the time.

RATING: 9.75

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
"Non-spatial civ game which is still fun without pvp attacks (Peaceful Variant). I really like it, but we need to get faster, since I can't justify spending 6 hours on it very often."

What I like:
- The civ theme
- Cool mechanisms (sliding cards; resource/worker banks)
- Good variety; interesting decisions; not total brain-burner; very deep
- Has some "restrain the leader" mechanisms
- "Simple" game is a very nice introduction

What I don't like:
- Too long for my tastes
- The "peaceful variant" is good, but feels incomplete
- There are a few pointlessly complex rules (like what cards you can/can't use the turn you draft them)

I'm surprised how much I like this game. First, because it is longer and heavier than I usually enjoy. Second, because I have strongly disliked every other Vlaada game I have tried. This game avoids his bad design traits (pointless complexity, and randomness you can't mitigate). I tried playing online, and it's much harder to see the whole game and notice what you should be working on, and to see the end of each age approaching.

After watching Rahdo's runthrough, I was able to teach the simple game (while reading the rulebook). Our 2p learning game ("Simple") took 2.5 hours, which wasn't bad at all. Next we played 2p "Full", which took 6.5 hours.

From a complexity standpoint, I put it on par with Eclipse or Agricola...about a 3.3. But it seems to be quite a bit deeper than either of those, with more varied strategies, so I could see a net weight of perhaps 3.5 or so. 

EDIT: Downgrading rating from 7 to 4, because the peaceful variant is not that satisfying (especially given the length), and I would never play with the full military rules in place.

RATING: 8
Love the mechanics and there are a lot of things to manage. My first play was at four with three new players, so there was a lot of down time and we had to end it after the second age. Managing workers, buildings, happiness, food and resources (amongst others) which are all integrated and linked in some way, provide for a lot of thought on each turn. Very little interaction with the exception of pacts and wars, but you still have to watch others especially for the strength status and other levels, which can get to be a little much as so much can change from turn to turn. Gets repetitive near the end and there are a lot of cube to manage back and fourth.

Da rigiocare un venerdì sera, quando l'orologio non impone di terminare la partita.

RATING: 8
I really like this civilization game, it feels a little like the Civilization computer game, and a little like Phoenicia (but without auctions and runaway leaders).  There are a ton of interesting decisions regarding how to allocate your resources and population, and often you're faced with decisions about what direction you need to take your civilization, because you can't do it all.  The aggression cards seems a little bit tough on players that are struggling to afford a military force.  One downside is that the game really takes a long time, and the other players have nothing to do while it's not their turn.  Maybe best as a two-player affair.

(5+ plays)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Love this game sooooo much. Some of the components are a bit fiddly though [looking at you wooden discs things] and keeping track of all the information flowing at you can get a bit crazy. Fantastic game with 2 and 3 but tends to bog down too much with 4. The cards provide quite a bit of choices, especially the leaders and the wonders. Keeping a balance of Culture, Science and Military is quite the challenge. Getting a few extra civil actions can make quite the difference. Also, get the Upgrade pack for components. Makes a HUGE difference in this actually getting to the table for me. Much less fiddly even though it's basically the same thing.

I have two big complaints about the game. One, is that Military can become problematic and I feel like often, it's the way to win the game. And Two, I don't like how various keywords are interchangeable and not really well defined. For example, lose a population is one I constantly have to look up. Do you physically lose a yellow token, do you destroy a building, do you slide an available worker down to your general population bank? I think words need to be bolded and clarified.

Extras: Upgrade Pack
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.2
One of the best Civilization Games out there. It trades the map for time, so it can be played up to 4 hours without sacrificing almost any micromanagement; economy, culture, warfare, resource management, it's all there! Offering 3 different playing levels (Simple/Advanced/Full) is really a plus for someone who wants to learn the game. I would probably enjoy different conditions as well, instead of having only the "Time" victory condition, i.e., highest score at a predetermined time, but that's for another game.

RATING: 10
Excellent game! the best game ever.
Waiting for new edition!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is probably the finest civilization building game out there. And it's a card game.

I read somewhere that Vlaada spent 100 years or so developing and perfecting this masterpiece and it kind of shows. Everything is extremely clever. I think the resource management in particular is nothing less than brilliant. You really feel the need to develop new technologies and put them to use. Brute force inefficient soviet-like economies are doomed to be defeated and forgotten. Corruption is a bitch. Managing tech, resources, happiness and population while at the same time keeping a strong army to defend your civilization or crush your enemies is not an easy task but it sure is a gratifying one.

I heard some complaints about the military and how it supposedly was overpowered but I whole heartedly disagree. The military is what shakes things and allows the great seeping and gamechanging moves, thus keeping Through the Ages from being a boring economic snowball engine game. 

Maintaining an effective army will harm your ecnomomic growth, but if you don't have one your opponents will make you pay a very high price. Finding the right balance between an adequate army and a powerful economy is key.

Through the Ages does take a long time (around 3h with 2 players, 4h with 3) but every single minute is worth it and time just flies.

Some components are flawed, the quality of the cards could be better but who cares?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Quite a lot of cards...
I've played only the advanced game to the end of II-era. That was 3 hours with rules explanation, so I guess I won't be playing the full game. 

Anyways, there sure is an awful lot of things to do and not enough resources for that. The only thing I disapprove in this game is the military and it's weird and often unrewarding role.
Otherwise, this game is quite masterfully balanced, given the great number of variables. There is always a shortage of something, I guarantee you...

The optimum player number is definitely 3, since then the downtime is just fine and nothing too relevant is removed from game. Well, this is playable enough with 2 players too, but I won't even consider playing with 4.

All in all, quite ok. 

Edit: more plays were needed for me to really appreciate this. The rating rose from 7 to 9. Great game when played with minimal downtime! Full game was played under 3 hours with 3 players. Now that's the lenght I like!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I really like the Civilisation computer game series. It isn't going to be easy recreating the experience of a solitaire computer game that lasts a month in a multiplayer board game that lasts an evening.
Through the Ages is a very good attempt. I can accept the compromises - no map, a weak tech tree and a very abstract military combat - but I still feel like I've played a civ game. Part of this is that even though this is a victory point game - so a lucky card can make a difference of a few points, which could change the ranking in a close game, but a good score is primarily the result of good play throughout the game and not just luck.
Also, there is very little hidden information - just the political card draw - so I like playing this solitaire: I set up a four player game and play each of the players myself.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
A very good game - but the rules are really rather awful.  They're fine in places, but dreadful in other places.  (I think it's partially down to poor translation, partially down to inadequate proofreading when updating the game for the new release.)

A complex game, with a lot to remember.  Once you've "got it" then it flows well and quite quickly.  Haven't played it many times yet, but it seems well balanced and well thought out.  The components are a bit too small for my taste (big hands...) and the board and card manufacturing quality is poor.

The flaws, unfortunately, turn what could be a great game into merely a good game.

RATING: 7
This game is too much like an exercice in accounting with an abacus.

This game is probably too long and repetitive for what it offers (at least to me). Too much micromanagement and not enough interaction for the length. It's much a matter of playing against the game than against other players and luck takes a non negligible part. I don’t find this game to be very exciting and I’m not convinced it has a lot of depth. Lot of decisions are no-brainers, few agonizing. Although I can play it from time to time.

PS: This game has been supersesed by Rise of Empires.

RATING: 10
RATING IS FOR THE FULL GAME ONLY.

I will not play Advanced. Simple is a waste of time. This game is really only balanced for the Full version.

What a fantastic implementation of the Sid Meier's Civ series into cardboard format! You are juggling 17 different balls meanwhile trying to prevent your opponents from getting killer combinations like Michelangelo/Basilica or Napolean/Air Forces. I want to play this game more than anything else at the moment, which is why I have it rated 10. This I'm sure has to do with the fact that it's 4 hours long and very difficult to get to the table as a result. However, for all the downtime/AP whiners out there, I played a 4p Full game of this in 4 hours, 10 minutes (not including setup and takedown) so I know it can be done in a (semi)reasonable time!

RATING: 7
This is the ultimate Euro. Build A to get B to use to get C, etc. Interesting but long. I like the game but it can punish a player for missing something small. There are so many A-B-C and X-Y-Z mechanisms in the game that in every game I have played one player has messed up by missing something minor. It can be very difficult to recover i.e. the game is somewhat unforgiving. Great design, very challenging but not as much fun as some simpler Empire building games (Conquest of Paradise for example.)

RATING: 9.6
AMAZING!!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Game is a ton of fun. Next to Dominant Species, my favorite game. Lots of meaty player choices. Only complaints are the game is longer with more people, and you really can't play with newbies without taking the time to do a simple game first. There are a few bits I don't like (late game, you can have tons of actions but nothing to do with them if you aren't extremely careful with your choices), but overall, I really like the game.

Comparable in complexity to Dominant Species, but a lot more intuitive. The game play weight is 4 instead of 3 because you get stuck with some extremely difficult mutually exclusive decisions later on, plus there are a number of mechanics you need to remember to balance and sometimes do math several turns ahead.

That all said, much as I love the game, I wouldn't really recommend buying it. It's tough to jump into the full game (or the medium game) with newbies, and even among my dedicated gaming group, I have trouble getting people to play this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
A two to three hour experience (with three experienced players) that feels like an hour.
There's a lot of game to explore here.  The order that the cards come out each age will make each game different.  Players are almost always wishing that they had 'one more action.'  The very real decisions about whether to use extra actions to grab that critical card at three actions and not expand that lab or hope it's still there next turn are frequent and enjoyable.

RATING: 10
A dozen plays advanced and full game rules - takes a partial game to learn the mechanics. Often worth restarting at that point if you have a mix of veterans and noobs. The rules are different during the first three turns so a careful reading is needed to catch all the details. The game pace moves along suprisingly quickly but it is still a long, enjoyable, game. Reminds me of Sid Meier's Civ (computer game). 

Would benefit from a larger individual player mat that the cards were tucked around so the marker beads did not have to be picked up or slid across card edges.

I'm working out a variant that allows for simultaneious play during the civil actions phase to greatly speed play.

RATING: 9
Excellent civilization building game.  Between the different wonders, different emphasis through buildings and leaders, the randomness of the technologies and other cards, I feel that each player can customize their civilizations without feeling forced into a particular path or like a carbon copy of someone else's.

It would have been nice to have an actual map exploration mechanic, but we can't get everything in one game.
Also, for all the different things you can do, at the end of the game, all that matters is how much culture you have, rather than having perhaps having different end goals for victory.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Excellent game mechanics with a very well integrated theme. Great replay-ability.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This compares will the original Civilization game. It is a good resource management game. 
 
With the indirect scoring mechanism - get culture points - however to do so you need to build your economy to get resources to build buildings to get points... The decision tree is huge.
Having to make the most of your limited action points coupled with resource penalties if you try to accumulate too much drives much of the game angst.
An abstracted military mitigates losing the geographic element of most Civ style games. 
The card drafting mechanism is an excellent replacement for the card element of Cive, and is a addition to provide difficult choices for the players.

I see a lot of re-playability in the game. 

You can have downtime especially later in the game as the number of choice open for each player. While you can preplan your move you have to wait and check the card draft to see how that impacts your move.

Add in events (both good and bad) you have a very rich game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A massive Civ game with tons of stuff involved!  Love the scaling of the game, but it always feels like 1-2 people get left behind early and have a tough time catching up.  Coming in around 4 hours each time I've played, this is also a time hog, especially if you're one of the aforementioned people.  Overall, I feel that this game is excellent, but seems to be missing some intangibles that could really push this to a "9" or "10" rating for me.  Some of the leaders seem a bit overpowered too, so perhaps some mild modification of their abilities would help make this game more balanced.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.5
I've played this numerous times and it just gets better and better. Requires quite a bit of balancing in terms of all your resources and very challenging. I think the only negative qualm I have is its game length which very long, but the time does go by fairly quickly once you get used to the game mechanics. It took me a few games before I got the hang of everything and I think it's a difficult game to teach, but a very rewarding game. I've played both the on-line and real life versions. The on-line version is very forgiving in that it lets you 'test out' different scenarios before committing your actions. I've easily played over 100 games, but I am no longer recording my on-line plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
Preliminary rating 7, may improve with further plays; suffers a little from all the details I played wrong on the first play that screwed up the game, otherwise would probably be 8 to 8.5.  Very "meaty" game with a large number of options to consider, few obvious best choices.  I love resource collection and management games with power acquisition (i.e. building something gives you additional abilities), and this game has more of it than just about any game I know.  Decent player interaction with a lot of great game mechanics, though I thought the effect of my sucessful war against another player was FAR out of proportion to the effort required (FIFTY VP swing!), and I might like the game better with all war and agression cards removed (but that would make a lot of the technologies completely useless, and maybe this incident was unusual). Love to try it again when I have a LOT of time to devote to it. (Rating raised to 7.8 after merely thinking about the game; not even needing to play it again.)

RATING: 6
Epic game - and I haven't played the full version yet! I keep making the same mistakes, neglecting science and not building enough mines, as I only play this once every six months or so. But by the end I'm enthusiastic about it and looking forward to playing it again - in another six months time.

It all works very well as a civ building game without mind blowing amounts of book keeping - although by the end of a game the large amounts of bonuses and card effects reminds of of Race to the Galaxy on steroids. Not one for a breezy game with the family.

UPDATE: It is now gathering dust on the shelf and when I see people playing it at Cons I just can't bring myself to play - too resource heavy, which is perhaps my least favourite theme/mechanic. Had to sell it.

RATING: 10
(Updated...years later and over 25 games in): Wow, did this game hold up. Have since moved on to 2nd edition, but both are fantastic. Must own for any civ builder fan.

I don't usually slap a 10 on a game after just one play, but this was board gaming nirvana. The mechanics are much simpler than you would expect once you're familiar with the flow, but the variety of strategic options are astonishing. The downtime was minimal with two players--this might be more of an issue with more, and I can expect the game to add at least 1 hour per player.

RATING: 9
This is a rich and complex game, very satisfying for those willing to put in the time to learn and play it. Very "fiddly" in the sense of having a lot of simple arithmetic and bead-push accounting to do, and a lot of rules to keep track of, but well worth the effort! My rating has gone up with more plays, and this has become one of our very favorite games, especially since it is so good for two players.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
The first part of the game, age A and I, is the most interesting. After that the end game really hinges on how well of an age A or I that you have had.

The latter age technologies are cool but difficult to employ. So, there effect on the game is minimal.

The strong military and strong science strategy seems to be the only way to win, since there really is not much else that is produced except culture.

The resource and food production need to be optimized or the player will be set back probably fatally set back.

Once you are behind there is no way to catch up against a competent opponent.

The events and conflicts reward players who are already ahead and do give the trailing players a second chance.

In all too much optimization is required. I always felt that I was threading the needle rather than building and advancing a civilization. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
My wife's favorite game. If only it wasn't so long. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Bought because I couldn't get Claustrophobia. Sadly I should have been more patient.  Gets better with more plays though is a bit of a brain burner.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I was interested in this until I saw the ridiculous price and heard about the awful components in the American edition. Finally bought the much cheaper German version in 2009.

As it turns out, the hype seems deserved: although quite complex, this is a fun game to play. Agonizing choices to be made each turn as you try to build up (and defend) your civ: a very good game.

Not a fan of the (German) rules: lots of important information that should be placed close together is actually spread over the 3 rule sets. Also, the base game is not for play, just to teach you a few of the basics. Better to go straight to the advanced or (in my case) the full game.

Solved the rules issues by (as I usually do) summarizing the entire game down to 2 illustrated A4 pages.

Initial rating of 8 upgraded to 9 after second play.

...And back down to 7. I'm deducting 2 points due to its ridiculous length, meaning it won't get to the table a lot, if at all anymore. There are now other games that have taken its place (Nations, Clash of cultures). Perhaps the new version planned by CGE will remedy this, but we will see.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Just as I'd feared, this is simply the boring parts of the Civ PC game - the parts I automate - turned into a long, fiddly board game.

There's no real thematic heft, no narrative, and little interaction. This is a spreadsheet euro through and through. Le Havre does the mini-maxing engine thing without all the fiddly barrel shuffling and in 1/4th the time.

It's baffling that a pure euro which doesn't meet basic standards in elegance and balance should earn such acclaim. Who knew there was such a market for the clunky bits of a PC game ported into a clumsily produced board game.

RATING: 8.1
An excellent and enjoyable game.

One of the best games in existence.

The only weak areas in its design are
the following:

1 I would have preferred a map as part
of the game to give it a more strategic feel.
2 There is no catch up mechanism in
the game. If one falls behind militarily
one becomes a safe target and tends
to fall even further behind.
3 There is not enough interaction in
the game such as perhaps bidding
for cards instead of simply buying
them.

All in all , however, this is an excellent
game, much more deserving to be rated 
number one than: Twilight Struggle.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
My physical copy of TtA goes unplayed most of the time, unfortunately - my wife really disliked the game (which I didn't expect; admittedly at the time I didn't realise how important the military aspect of the game would turn out to be, but her main objections are about the whole game system), and while no-one else I've played it with has had such a bad reaction, no-one has been interested enough to want to regularly spend 4-5 hours playing this game. It gets an occasional Sunday outing (we have "all-day" games days once a month on a Sunday). But thankfully, I get to play almost all the time on BGO (although now I play the new version), so I can, I think, give some considered views on this game.

This is, with no exaggeration, simply one of the best games ever designed. Civilisations rapidly begin to diverge based on the cards they pick up - and there is great tension in trying to keep up adequate levels of production in food, resources, and science, as well as gain enough actions to have effective turns, while not falling too far behind in production of the all-important culture (that is, VPs), and most of all not falling behind militarily. Because this game, while not allowing an easy way to win by military means alone (except in 2-player, my least favourite form of the game), will see you being absolutely crushed if you can't keep you army at least roughly as strong as other players'. This is what puts many players off the game, but is at the heart of much of the tension which makes it so great.

There are other fantastic features too - my personal favourite is probably the seeding of events. Like many games, events are turned up randomly at intervals and can potentially affect all players - but in this game, each player chooses some of the events which will happen, and has some control also over when they happen, leading to many strategic and tactical choices. Vlaada Chvatil is one of my favourite designers, and his designs cover an enormous variety of different types of game - but TtA is still, in my opinion, his greatest game.

Of course, this is about to be superseded by the new version, with some significant rules changes, major changes to some cards, and some superb-looking art (which just shows up the poor quality of the art and components in the Eagle edition of the original game even more). Since I so rarely get to play TtA physically, I have resigned myself to the fact that it would be a waste of money to buy it, but I am very sad about this. At least get to play the new version on BGO (and it is, indeed, even better than the original).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Love Civ-themed games and this one is the best there is.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I imagine when I finally play a Full Game (instead of Simple or Advanced) this will become a 10.

RATING: 5.5
It's clear to me that there are many false choices in the game; there appear to be many options when, in fact, there are few.  Get your science up and focus on military.  It's that simple.  It's fun to explore the different paths, but after a few hundred plays, it comes down to 'get your military up and plan for war with the leader.'  As a result, luck of the draw is worse than it initially may appear. 

It scales well though the 2-player (2 - 2.5 hrs) is very different than 4-player (4+ hrs).

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Joguei apenas a versão avançada, não ainda a Full. E não sei se vou jogá-la.

O jogo é curtíssimo de recursos. No TTA light, felicidade e exércitos não eram problema. Fica fácil fazer engines de comida e de produção gigantescos, para bombar a civilização de cultura e ciência e construir wonders adoidado. Nessa versão o buraco é bem mais embaixo. Se você não alegrar sua população enquanto cresce, sua civ entra em guerra civil. E se não acompanhar o crescimento militar dos outros, toma porrada turno sim e o outro também. Consequentemente, tudo fica muito apertado. Num jogo de 4h30, nossas civs não avançaram tanto.
Isso para mim é um problema. Não curti passar 4h30 sofrendo quase sem conseguir evoluir. Claro que com o tempo o seu desempenho melhora. Mas o jogo full vai durar mais 2h. Será que vale se martirizar 6h em pelo menos mais umas 3 partidas pra conseguir jogar direito? Não acho.

Independente disso, tem que elogiar o sistema que o Vlaada criou pro jogo. Complexo mas totalmente intuitivo, e muito bem calculado pra continuar deixando o jogo apertado não importa em que era você esteja.

Voltando aos problemas: me pareceu que já na primeira metade do jogo, é possível ficar fora da disputa pela vitória (tanto que existe um mecanismo de desistência, em que o jogador abandona o jogo no meio). Achei que fosse acontecer comigo, mas todo mundo fez besteiras em sequência e eu consegui me reerguer, por isso o jogo acabou razoavelmente equilibrado. Mas se num jogo de 6h, se alguém não tiver sua engine funcionando razoavelmente na primeira metade, está fora da briga. Pior que isso, não vai poder nem jogar seu joguinho solo tentando perder com honra, porque sua engine não vai conseguir suportar um bom poderio militar, ou seja, você vai tomar rasteira da galera o tempo todo.

A parte militar foi outra coisa que não curti muito. As rasteiras são razoavelmente frequentes e podem ser bem pesadas. Entra num nível de furação de olho que eu não curto. O seu adversário pode roubar cartas, destruir prédios, roubar recursos, e isso é muito frustrante. Não sei ainda exatamente por que, mas as rasteiras do El Grande, do Dominant Species e do Agrícola, por exemplo, me frustram bem menos do que as agressões do TTA e de jogos de combate como Eclipse e wargames em geral.

Outro problema do jogo é o downtime. Como os jogadores fazem todas as suas ações na sua vez, acontece às vezes de vc ficar 20 minutos só esperando sua hora de jogar. E conforme o jogo avança e você ganha mais opções e mais ações, só piora.

Resumindo: admiro o TTA, definitivamente não é um jogo qualquer. Mas não é pra mim.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.3
(+) Nice engine building aspects. Feeling of growth and accomplishment -> a very big plus!
(+) Original mechanism with 'future' events
(+) Most will say the cards are ugly, but I kind of like them :)
(+) Different options: simplified game, advanced game, full game
(+) Some mechanics of this game inspired a whole lot younger boardgames later on. Through the Ages can be considered as the father of many other nice games.
(+) Real differentiation and stories emerge while playing. Many different ways to play the game.

(-) Kind of fidly: lots of small bits and tokens, some fidly rules you have to remember and a maybe not so elegant mechanism which dictates to take actions with small white disks
(-) Quite some downtime as you have to wait for opponents to finish their entire game turn

Note: Military might will probably not win you the game, but if your strength does not keep up with the competition, many events, agression cards and wars might crush you. This is not a military game, unless one or more players neglect their military power. It is really important to make this clear to new players.

Approx gametime advanced game: +- 45 - 50 min / player
Approx gametime full game: +- 65 - 75 min / player

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.9
My rating is for playing this online, when the computer handles all the fiddliness, and you do your turn whenever it comes up so the length of the game doesn't really matter. Playing this live, I'd probably rate this slightly lower. That doesn't take away the fact that this is a really, really good game though. I really like the way all the systems are entwined with each other. At first it was hard to see the exact value of things, but you quickly learn not to neglect any parts of your government.

Even online, this game isn't quite a 10, though. Turns are extremely tactical, and I enjoy trying to make due with what is available to you while keeping an eye on the future. However, due to the luck of the draw you can get thoroughly stuck if what you desperately need simply isn't available in any of your turns. You can't really afford to ignore any of the resources, but sometimes the game will deny them from you just by the luck of the draw. I've had games where I simply couldn't upgrade my food, some where I couldn't upgrade my science, some where I couldn't upgrade my resources, and others where trying to upgrade military is a chore. If you don't have those upgrades available on your turns for a large chunk of the game, it's not going to go well for you.

Another thing I'm not a huge fan of is the way the game encourages players to beat on the player with the weakest military, and not the player with the most culture (points). This often leaves someone who is already not doing well getting hammered over and over. Not a very enjoyable experience.
