=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
it would be a 10 if it had a map.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
   OK, four plays with a range from 2 to 4 players. This is a downtime feast. For the two players version, that could be tolerated, but I just cannot conceive a civ-like themed game with only two civs, thats of course a personal taste.

   For a game as long as it is (ours last game took 4 hours for 3 players), players can get fast behind the curve by making a mistake (or just a newbie player to the game), and stand possibly 2+ hours knowing you just cant win and falling behind more and more, is no fun. And worse, most game events just punish the players who are already doing poorly. One can argue, that if a player makes mistakes, should be punished, but well, I play games for fun, and being or seeing a spectator for a long time doesn't fit my concept of fun.

   For a such long game, the card drawing randomness kills any long term strategy planning. You are just playing the cards that are available when your turn comes up, because next one these will be entirely different. That's usually not a problem for me with much shorter games, but with this game I find myself for the last part of the game doing exactly the same as before, again and again, without really seeing the gameplay evolving, other than seeing the numbers in the cards growing up.

   The military aspect of the game, simply doesn't work, not even thematically. There is no real risk in aggressions, and that makes it a no choice to attack the players that militarily gets behind (many times just because of luck in early stages), and he will lose even if he fends off the aggression, because he will be forced to sacrifice one or more units (that cost resources of course). So when one player attacks another, the only question is if the attacker will get some benefit from it or not. Wars are somewhat different (the aggressor takes some risk), the defender can prepare, but in practice it doesn't change nothing, because no one will attack if there is a chance to lose. In a four players game, if someone gets only a bit behind in military power, he can easily get crunched and pushed out of the game. I think this problem arises fundamentally from the fact that there is very little hidden info involved in aggression, only defend/colonization cards, so it gets clear who can beat whom. It feels rather strange to me that in a game where the card distribution and timing along the slider, gives the game so much randomness and unpredictability, the only real interaction between players is so predictable.

   The final score events, makes things worse because as most events, will only help the stronger civs, so those just pull a player ahead when he is already ahead (I'm not talking here about a leading player getting more benefit from the events than the rest of the players, but cards being completely useless if the player who draws them it not ahead, and playing event cards scores points so... you can imagine the rest). There is a horrible random factor there, in the timing of the game, because if you get them early in the age you can prepare and exploit them, but in the last turns of the game its pure luck to draw a card that will bonus yourself (or one that would have benefited another one had he drawn it). Some cards can make a huge difference between two given players (easily >12-14 VPs), so depending on who draws them, the score varies greatly, just of pure luck. In all my games the winner was exclusively determined because of who draw what third age events (and some broken Wonders). You can improve your position to draw more cards, but in the last age all players who still can win, will draw the maximum. I faithfully recommend to explain the third age scoring event cards to newbies before the start, to give them a chance.

   And last, if you take apart wars/aggressions (and those mostly will happen only against the weakest who can't win) and relatively the last age score events, this is a heavy "solitaire-multiplayer" game for most of its length. There is about near zero interaction between players, I know many players like those types of games, so that's a matter of taste. Also, if you are going to try the game, it's no complex at all. This is an economic building eurogame with a twist, and while there is some heavy micromanagement, a few awkward exceptions and a really bad and unnecessarily long rulebook, the gameplay is mostly straight.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
I like the concept, but...

Significant downtime, and it is the kind of downtime that does not lend itself to planning out your turn.

I feel like it takes to long for what it is.

A computer version of this would be better as it would take care of the accounting for you.

If you lose a battle early on you will sit out the next 3+ hours while the rest of the players pick your carcass and I say this as one of the 'pickers' and not the 'carcass' but certainly not fun for the carcass. In short there are few if any catch up mechanisms.  This is probably good for some game groups but I just feel sorry for the person that sits there for 3 or 4 hours with no hope of winning. I have won 3 of the 4 games of this I have played and I must admit if I didn't play it again I wouldn't be sad.

There are at least 100 other games I would rather play..

Traded.

RATING: 8.5
I am a sucker for civ games, and this is one of the best.  Our trio of experienced gamers jumped right into the full game, taught by one who had played before. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Everything good from Civ games, without the boring parts and dicerolling. Excellent! 

Edit: After more than 10 games, I still want to play again as much as after the first game. The variation between games is immense, even if you play every game with the same strategy they will all be different in big and important ways. Every turn is a small step where you have to prioritize. Most of the time you would like to take every single option there is very much. You are always in charge, but the game gives you different choices every time. Simply superb. 

Edit again: Played 45-50 times now. All previous comments stand, best game I ever played.

Edit 2012: After 80-100 games it started to be less interesting to me.

RATING: 5
Definitely a play before you buy.  I had planned to get this based on the high BGG rank, but after getting a chance to play it, it fell completely flat for us and quickly removed from my wishlist. Very fiddly, constantly moving around little discs, I kept feeling this would be better as a computer game - the tactile aspect of holding small cards and moving small discs adds nothing to the game.  And it doesn't have the great theme of other well-ranked fiddly games that I don't like much (Arkham Horror, BSG).  There is more theme than 7 Wonders, but you definitely don't get the feeling of building a civilization like you do in the Civ computer game. I also don't like the solitaire aspect of resource production inherent in the game - i.e. your resources available next turn are almost completely dependent on how much you decide to not spend this turn and whether you invest in more resource production now - this puzzle-like math calculation is just boring, and is very different from the resource management calculations for games like Agricola where you are grabbing resources produced by a common pool and trying to determine if the other players are going to grab what you want.
2nd play with Advanced Game: no change in my rating - I would call it an interesting game, but not a fun one to physically play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Rating based on the four-player advanced game. I didn't particularly like how the military side worked but that may change if playing with the Wars offered by the full game. It was probably a mistake to play it with more than three the first time. I also missed viewing the ebb and flow of rising and declining civs and that is my biggest gripe. I don't see that this element would ever satisfactorily show itself.

Maybe I'll get a chance to play with three and the rating will go up a little.

Update: Rating lifted to 8. Played the full game with 4 online and it worked much better with the Wars. I still would like to play with 3 face-to-face.

Update: 02/16/16 - Rating this a 9 now. After playing some more and playing other games over the years that are trying to do similar things I see the brilliance of this design. I see the ebb and flow now in the seeding of the future events, the construction of wonders, and the advance of technology. I used to try to find this feeling with the leaders which are attached to multiple time periods within the same age and while I still think it feels weird this was not the portion of the game to which the designer was pinning that feel of the flow of history. It doesn't bother me as much anymore as I'd rather have real historical figures rather than nameless archetypes.

RATING: 8
Aside from the length, I think this may be the most captivating Civ game I've played.  There is a steep learning curve that most players will overcome after a single play.  I love games where you have to agonize of actions and this one adds tight resource management woes as well.  Military, Culture, or tech, take your pick, there seem to be several strategies for each.  It's games like this (because of length) that make me wish there was a comprehensive online venue (similar to online poker rooms) where waiting for your turn wasn't so agonizing. 
Minor quams:  The round resource disks are a bit of a pain, and some of the graphics are not very intutive.
Over all, great game!

RATING: 8.5
This has got everything I enjoy in a good engine building euro. The first few turns feel like a uphill battle as you get your engine running. Every turn, you have more choices than you know what to do with, which forces you to make some painful ones. You never quite feel like you have enough of anything that you need. The game ends just as soon as you feel like you were making headway. Great game all around, hampered only slightly by the randomness of the available cards.

Rating dropped by half a point because new version is slightly preferable now.

RATING: 7
I love empire building and civ-games, but I couldn't bring myself to give a better rating.
PROS:
Great replayability (Absence of a map increases replayability)
Immersive, really feels like your building an empire
Constantly wanting to do more than you can
CONS:
Long (2-3h for a simple game, 4-5h for a advanced game and 6-7h for a full game)
Lots of downtime (you really can't do anything when it's not your turn, made worse by events that happen at the beginning of your turn, most of the time making all your planning obsolete.)
Too little player interaction
Brutal and merciless if you fall behind, comeback is very difficult (not a good thing in a game this long)

RATING: 10
There is a distinct pleasure and sense of accomplishment fostered by this game, as every turn sees your civilization facing numerous potential paths into the future, and every civilization quickly becomes unique. At the same time, these possibilities are limited by the increasingly fragile infrastructure of goods and population that each player must manage. The game really becomes an exercise in reaction - that is, constantly refining and adjusting your strategy as the myriad of available options begin to disappear, or when your opponents' actions force you to reevaluate your civilization.

It's also pretty darn boring. 

I admire people trying to simulate the richness of history, but sadly it usually just turns into formulas and very selective looks at the world. The elegance of Civilization is a far, far better guiding light than this.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great game, but takes its time. Especially if the players take forever to do their turns.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Very fiddly, but nice if you've got the time. The rules are straight forward enough - thank goodness for some of the examples to straighten some of the wording out. There are an excellent number of choices where you can choose your path, but at the same time keep up with the other players and be ready for certain events. I really like the combat mechanism for its simplicity and clever functionality. Combat/colonisation weakening the attacker and burning up their resources to rebuild encourages players to pick and choose the conflicts they can afford to lose and those they can't.

Speeds up considerably with further play. Downtime is more a problem with the players and their familiarity with the rules than with the game system. Not recommended with more than three players unless all the players are very familiar with the rules, then it can move along at a nice clip with downtime not an issue. Plan your turn, move your pieces and don't fuss about and take back pieces and try other alternatives. What's done is done - move on, next turn. If you know the rules and can't get the Advanced Game out of the way in under three hours then you're savouring the moment too much and playing too slowly. The Full Game requires only a little more time, but it rewards you with a third age that you enter with your civilisation engine already in full swing. The third age tends to go by quickly as players should have a lot of actions by then to really move through the deck.

With the changing nature of each game (boy, there are a lot of cards!), I'll want to play this a lot more than I have the time to. After a few games I've bumped this up in the ratings. One of those games that gets better and better with further plays. That said, unfortunately in a four player game player elimination is a strong possibility. Opponents don't usually gang up on the leader so much as the weak player. Three hits in a round and you can find you've burnt up you defensive cards and your spare troops. Another three hits the next round and you might as well call it a day. Usually it's not until the third age, so at least an eliminated player doesn't have to wait around too long as the third age flies by quick. If you play with the lower aggression variant (where a player can only be hit once in a round), then it solves this little issue and makes it socially acceptable again with four players. Screw that though - with experienced players, if you're in that position you probably weren't careful enough or paying attention.

My main criticism with the game is not a criticism of the game so much as a criticism of how losing players use wars as a hail mary when all is lost. It's a king making problem. Let's say you have a three player game and player A is way behind in points. So Player A declares war on player B and sacrifice all his/her military units with a turn to go. Invariably in a close game amongst the other players Player B must respond in kind and sacrifice all his/her units. Player A makes maybe a couple of points, if any. Player C reaps the rewards and crushes the weakened Player B. All player A has done is effectively handed the game to Player C, and it could have so easily been Player C that Player A decided to go all kamikaze on. So, is the game at fault for allowing such activity. Not really, but on the other hand it would have been simple for the game to have a rule to reduce the frequency of such moves. Maybe at least saying a player must have a higher military strength at the time he/she declares a war against an opponent. Personally I don't let it worry me, but on the other hand I've been on the winning end of such a scenario. Even without attacking one of the weakened players the Impact cards can hand you a rather hollow victory.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Heavy Euro of resource and card management that is probably too long and too fiddly for what it delivers at the end, and with a lot of downtime between turns.  Besides, it feels way too abstract for a civilization game, so another setting could have been a better choice for its background.  The lack of a map is another minus in its record.  I like it less with every play.

RATING: 9
The rating system here needs to be rewritten. An 8 is "I'll probably suggest it and never turn down a game." This game is clearly better than an 8 but it takes SO LONG TO PLAY I am quite likely to refuse it unless I have the stamina and lots of free time. This is an excellent civilization game. The only thing that's lacking, at least in a "traditional civ game" sense, is an area-control map with which to play pieces. You won't miss it. Instead, the game abstracts territory and combat, focusing all its energy on empire management, invention and utilization of workers. It's bloody marvelous. Time flies while you play this. And then it's nine hours later and it's dark out and your significant other at home is pissed.

In all fairness it shouldn't take nine hours, but we had three players who'd never played before.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is computer Civilization in boardgame format.  That means, amongst its addictiveness and sweep of all history, a mega time commitment for its full play.  Other than the ridiculous time needed it's a fantastic game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Such a great game for me. I love seeing my civilization grow. Some people find the resource management fiddly but I just love all the difficult choices this provides like: "I would love to build this wonder, but do I have the manpower to build it in reasonable time?!". I also enjoy how your military is important, but not overwhelmingly powerful.  This game is just a winner for me.

RATING: 6
[based on one Simple game]
After hearing about this game through The Usual Suspects in NYC, I was leery about all the fussiness.  I have to say I was a pleasantly surprised.  Sure, it's a pain in the patootie to move those miniscule little wood shavings around, and some of the interface comes off a bit clunky.  I have to admit that nearly everything else about the game seems well-considered, thematically sound, and not as optimized and "on-rails" as I thought it might be.  It "sticks to my ribs", and I found myself thinking about the game for a few hours after we had moved on.  The only thing keeping me from picking it up right away is the expense, though there is always the Chitkicker discount...

RATING: 8
Fiddly, but an awesome civilization game. If you are willing to forgo a map, one of the best civilization games I've played. The card drafting mechanic gives a great deal of variability between games, and forces you to make tough choices constantly.

You have to worry about military before the beginning of age 3, or your opponent will tear you in half.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
For me, this is without a doubt the best board-game ever devised.

I've played it on the excellent BGO site many times. It's a marvelous design - not so much a simulation of the development of civilization but more like an impressionist painting of the same. Balance amongst the various aspects of development is stressed, you need to expand your food production to grow your population, you need to keep them happy, you need to improve your output of resources in order to build stuff, and you need to improve your science output to advance up the tech tree. Above all, if you neglect the military your efforts elsewhere can be crushed by an aggressor. So many ways to win - so many choices to make each turn. 

I can't recommend this too highly although the time commitment means it will be played online far more often than face to face. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Sin duda uno de los mejores juegos que he jugado nunca. Absolutamente inmersivo en el juego, debes estar atento a todo, cada partida es diferente y su profundidad es tremenda. Obra maestra del diseño de juegos de mesa.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Wow, so many different mechanisms are well-implemented and integrated into the game. I see traces of Saint Petersburg, In the Year of the Dragon, and a very punishing economic system. I love how the cards really further the theme. Conveys the sense that you're doing something epic despite there being no board. My rating will probably go up eventually, but I'm not ready to love this game yet, because the game language and upkeep is so complex, that I can only worry about myself, and hence can't spare any brain cells for player interaction, so it's felt pretty solitaire to me, which is a big no-no. I'm sure this will go up, once I can crunch through the decisions more efficiently and stop screwing up. The Future-Current Events system is very cool, and the 2-worker penalty at the end of an Age is such a subtle mechanism, both in terms of theme and in terms of how it seems so harmless, before you realize, upon encountering it, that it's probably the worst possible thing that happens at the end of an Age.

4+3

RATING: 10
I've played once, though we didn't make it all the way through, but I can't wait to play again. This game looks to have a lot of replayability since every game is so very different. With a few more plays this score may go up.

With a few more plays under my belt, I have to give this one a solid 10. My only problem now is finding enough people interested in a 4 to 5 hour game to play it anywhere near as much as I'm jonesin' to.

Having played this game with 2,3,and 4 players a number of times, I've decided this is the best game I've ever played. There are more paths to victory and more sublteties in this one than I've seen in any other game.

RATING: 7
Once I read the description of this game, I really had no doubts that it would be a game that I would enjoy.  Unfortunately, I'm really not that good at it.  Though I like it, I likely won't ever get to play it enough so that I do become go.  No problem, though.

I have to state that the Basic and Advanced game really serve no purpose other than getting you up to speed to play the full game.  In the first, the game ends just when things start to get interesting.  The second is not so bad, but is clearly truncated--and feels that way.

Still, building up your civ is loads of fun.  Just like in the computer game, I tend to play with blinders, which is fun while you are doing it, but hinders you in the long run.  Despite recognizing this flaw in my play, I am unable to adapt appropriately.  Oh well.  [01/18/2008]

RATING: N/A
Through the Ages: A Story of Civilization -- 

Note to self:  If you're once again considering getting this, remember that [b]many[/b] comments say the following:
• It lasts far too long.
• It's far too physically fiddly.
• It has far too many exceptions to its many rules.
• It offers almost no player interaction.
• It doesn't allow the players to do anything when it's not their turn.

Play Francis Tresham's [thing=177]Advanced Civilization[/thing] instead.  This is also long, but it succeeds in so many ways.

Competitive
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Sold original edition (I was made an offer I couldn't refuse) and picked up FRED reprint.

Fun, if fiddly (and long) card game. Essentially a cube/resource management Euro. You buy cards and use action points to either buy more cards, develop farms, mine, build wonders, upgrade your army etc.

You churn through three ages of events, characters, buildings etc and at the end, the player with the most culture points (VPs) wins. The cards are fun and full of flavour and there's alot to think about. However, the downtime with a full complement of players is fairly long.

Probably better as a two-player game (though you lose the fun of agression/wars against other players).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
I love civilization building games and this is one of the best. At first I thought the cards were unbalanced, but there are plenty of ways to win. In fact, the huge variety of options and strategies leads to great replay value and an intense gaming experience. I also like the little thematic details, like religous improvements providing more happy faces, but no more culture. The only downside of this game is that it can drag a bit when you are losing with no chance of recovery. I like to play two-player with my wife. Neither of us takes long to move and we can start over as soon as it's clear one of us will probably win.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
All time fav.  Played once face to face and then immediately jumped into league games that were running at the time on Boardgaming-online.com.  Was a great way to learn by jumping right in and was instantly hooked.  The game has so much going on that even very late into my plays there was still things to learn and improve on.  

Love so much of this game, the card drafting from the card row and figuring out when things should be paid for extra civil actions.  When generally weaker leaders/cards can be used.  Especially like the political card play and tension of being in the lead of military to no suffer from events and knowing when it is more safe to play events when you aren't in the lead.  

Biggest issue in the game is downtime especially at 4 players and also how annoying moving the pieces can be.  Would play it face to face anytime, but due to length and my game group at the time it was hard to get it to the table.  Luckily online is absolutley perfect for this game.  The game shines even more being able to easily view the discard pile and have the computer take care of all the minutiae of the rules and moving pieces around.  Online the game is pretty much 11/10 for me.

Play breakdown:

Face to Face: 4

Online:  
Normal -- 94 (1 of which peaceful variant)
Global -- 100 (6 peaceful)
Czech  -- 4
Span.  -- 1

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[2011-04-23]
A BGG jelenleg negyedik legjobb játéka, átlagos játékidejének 4 óra van megjelölve, de nem ijesztett el, a sok pozitív kritika mindenképpen kipróbálásra sarkallt. A játék átvitte a lécet. Tényleg nagyon hosszú, még kétszemélyes játék esetén is, de élvezet minden perce. Fantasztikusan kitalált játékról van szó, amiben tényleg fejlődik a játszók civilizációja, amely teljesen különböző módokon tehetők meg. Egy-egy kis hiba egyáltalán nem jelenti a játék végét, bőven van esély a korrigálásra. A játékszabály elsőre nehéznek tűnhet, de játék közben kiderül, hogy abszolút nem túl bonyolult. Nagyon jó játékról van szó tehát, ami korokon átívelő civilizációfejlesztésről szól. Talán 4 játékos esetén hosszúra nyúlhat, 2 játékos esetén az egymással való kooperáció marad ki, így talán egyértelműen 3 főnél jön ki igazán a játék teljessége. Mindenképp pozitív a többfajta játékmód is. Tetszett, hogy nincs túlbonyolítva többfajta nyersanyaggal, egyszerűen csak étel és fejlesztés van. A hosszú játékidő miatt most nincs még ingerem 9-est adni neki, de talán további játékok alkalmával elérheti.

[2011-11-26]
A teljes játék után sem tudok emelni a pontszámon és nem feltétlenül a játékidő miatt. Bár hárman több, mint 5 órás volt, hanem a szerencsefaktor miatt. Sajnos egy ilyen komoly játékban elég nagynak érzem, igaz a hosszú játékmenet ezen kompenzál. Marad a pontszám.

RATING: 8
This is a really weighty euro that leaves you with many hard decisions to make at all times. Not for a casual gaming group but awesome with 3-4 good gamers. Still good as a two player also, though some options are missing with this player count. Takes 3-6 hours to play so best if you can play over two nights, leaving it set up. It sometimes seems to run a bit long: that's the only downside to this really good game.

I like this game a lot but without a map it leaves a bit to be desired thematically when considering it as a civ-building game.

I hate the stupid small tic tac playing pieces that come with it so I bought some awesome cubes from geekstopgames.com for it.

A lot of fun so far.  I've played several Basic games and a couple of Advanced games.
Update: I've played several full version games now.  Definitely the best way to play.  Very tough to find the time though.  A 3 player game where everyone knows the rules takes us about 5 hours.  A 4 player game goes about 6 hours.  Note that a 4 player advanced game where there are one or two new players can also go about 5.5 to 6 hours.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
French.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is the Trapped In The Closet of the "Build a Better Engine" systems.  Long and overly involved, repetitive, absurdly self-justifying and bulky.  Unlike R Kelly's bloated "masterpiece", Through the Ages works well and is damn entertaining. Engine games have now become the new Area Control, but if you want the big one, this is it (although arguably Antiquity is neck and neck).  

I think that the most important thing to remember about this game is that it is a card game.  It takes some serious cojones to make an 8 hour card game. San Juan just looks trifling compared to this.   I'm amazed at how smooth all the cards interact with each other, none of them stand out as being game breakers, nor overly useless.  

Perhaps what makes this so gripping is that you want to do so many things, yet you are constantly faced with new challenges managing your civ.  There is a wonderful hand management and planning aspect of the game that I really get into. You really need to balance everything out. 

Even though I really enjoy playing it doesn't mean it is a perfect game.  I'm frustrated by the fact that you can't just spend a civil action to discard a card from your hand. The penalty of losing two actions should be enough, yet there are no rules that help you get duds out, which can bring your civ to a stand still.  

I have to say, while funny, the Sid Meier card really cheapens the experience.

All in all, though, pretty brilliant.  I expect the rating to go up with more plays.

Update: This just isn't a short game, so it doesn't hit the table as often as it should. I go back and forth trying to decide whether it is best with two or three.  If you only do up to Era II with quick players then three players, Era III I prefer two.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
I wish this played faster; I'd be willing to pull it out more often. Does an excellent job of simulating the development of a civilization in the time available. Every turn is full of difficult choices. Some have criticized this for being too luck-driven; I haven't played it enough to perceive this as a problem yet.

Update: several plays later, I don't think luck is very important at all, but knowing the cards certainly is. Unlike RftG, the decisions you make early don't lock you into a strategy that you're stuck with whether the cards show up or not. Switching strategies isn't free, but it's not a game-breaker, either.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is quite a fun resource management card game with some opportunity for aggressive skullduggery and killer combos.  Like most Euros, you want to do more More MORE on your turn, but are limited by several levels of resource requirements.  For example, to build a technology of any sort, you must first spend one or more of your precious civil actions to obtain the card from the display, play another civil action AND science points to play the card out of your hand, and then spend resource tokens to place a worker on the building, which then begins providing its benefit.  Oh, yeah.  The worker must have been previously produced from your population pool by spending food.  So, um, there's a lot of plates to juggle, and you have several cards on the display, active in your civilization, and in your hand to consider buying/upgrading/building, while still making sure that you aren't being passed militarily.  Because that would be bad.  I've only played with 3, and it's quite a delightful 2.5 hours.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3
Through the Ages is an optimization game with lots of fiddly bookkeeping, the bulk of which is done by shuffling cheap round wooden pieces back and forth across the board, except when they roll off the table, which they do. There's too much downtime and almost no interaction. Pursuing a military strategy may change that. I will never know. It seems less like a civilization game than a spreadsheet, and it goes on and on and on. There are gamers for whom this game was designed. I'm not one of them. One learning game was more than enough.

RATING: 10
Always fun to play, winning or losing.  The mechanics are really satisfying and it's a great use of a rainy day.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
There are 3 levels of game options - the Simple game, designed to learn the basic flow of the game and played from Antiquity to Early age; the Advanced game, which adds several additional rules like military attacks, territorial colonization, political actions; and the Full game, which likely adds even more. We were all new to it and decided to play the Simple game. 

Rules - The simplest (and still accurate/effective) thing is to say this: it is Sid Meier's Civilization computer game brought to board/card form (without much of the micromanagement)! If you were a fan of those games (I played I and II to death; haven't played III and IV) you ought to love this! 

Not quite a 10: I'm concerned that there's too much emphasis (more than I'd like, anyway) on the military. That's totally in line with the computer game, but may be a turnoff for some in our game group (we may have to try the peaceful variant).

--------
Update: after hundreds of plays, mostly online, I have to go ahead and bump this up to a 10. The military thing is still true (the updated version of the game fixes) but you [i]can[/i] just play a peaceful variant instead. This is, by far, the best civilization game I have played so far!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
It seems to be a universally accepted truth that Through the Ages: A Story of Civilization is the ultimate civilization building board game. At the moment, it is ranked the second best board game of all time here on BGG. 

The game is a card game in which players are continuously working to get the best cards (which represents anything from armies to colonies to the great wonders of the world and philosophers that has changed the way of human thinking) for their civilization. 

Armies are then used to attack other players, while colonies produce goods and philosophers and leaders can give players different abilities and/or ways to break the rules of the game. All this is done in order to achieve culture, and at the end of the game, the players with the most culture wins.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

There is: military, governments, religion, wonders, science, raids, wars, colonizing, all in a neat card drafting mechanic.   Oh, it is good.  The ameritrasher in me wants a map with armies, capitols and colonies, but if you can get by the dry feeling layout, the magic emerges in the cards.    It may be a little long, especially with four players, but it is worth savoring.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I got to play the (currently) number 1 ranked game on BGG, Through the Ages. I don't really see why it is rated so high. It is a good game but has many issues for me. 
The random way the tech comes out gives a tactical feel but all the cards will come out so you can be strategic. Sounds great right? Well, to make sure there is a chance to get every aspect of the abstraction there are a lot of cards to get through in each age. This makes the﻿ game to long. It also still has the problem if losing the tech you want to another player. While normally I would like that kind of interaction, the economy is such that you have focus on prepping yourself for the tech to show up. When it doesn't it really can stall your progress.
Next is the combat. Combat is a bit to much of a focus as there are constantly things coming up that are almost always good for the stronger player. For the direct player attacks there is no incentive to go after the stronger leader so players pick on the weaker player simply because it is an easier/safer way to improve themselves. You also can't see the combat coming like you can with a Civ game on a map.
The economy is interesting but Eclipse dose it similarly in a much less fiddly way.
I do want to play it again but I would never okay the full game or with more than 3 players. It has gotten me more interested in Nations.﻿
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I really like this game so far. A nice civilization game that doesn't take too long.

RATING: 8

RATING: 6
A couple months ago I started a game of Through the Ages online. It just finished on Friday. I didn't win, but I wasn't crushed although I easily could have been. I stumbled into a powerful combo that kept my point engine on pace with the leader even as complete lack of experience left me struggling behind the curve in all other aspects of the game. I can see that it's a good game, but as fiddly and long as it is, it seems way too dependent on the order the cards are dealt. I'm going to make some comparisons to Puerto Rico because in my opinion, TtA is a heck of a lot more like PR than any "civilization" game.

Like PR, there are buildings/advances that are always good and some that are very situational and others that are underpowered. TtA is probably "flatter" in that regard than PR (PR has some buildings that just suck and a handful that, without at least one, you can't beat a good player). In both games, it takes some experience to understand the value of things. With so many more cards, it will take longer to do this in TtA.

In both games, tempo is controlled by the players and other player's actions are going to control you. In TtA, you're also being controlled by the order of the card draw. There are lots of cards. And lots of "good" combos. Almost all the cards are going to come out, but depending on random luck, the cards you want might be out of your reach when they come up and/or gone before you get to grab them. This adds a lot more replayability but also a lot more luck (which for me, is a bad thing in a 5 hour game). To make matters worse the big end-game bonus point cards (that can be 15% or more of your points-- per card) are drawn secretly with the military cards. The ones that have synergy with the point engine you created will probably not even be drawn by you (anyone could draw them and they might never be drawn). Instead, you might get a handful of crap that has no use to you while some other scrub lucks into a 50% bonus to his score. It reminded me of The Game of Life (The version with the ridiculous $50K - $1M life tiles that make the already useless game completely pointless.)

I see nothing in TtA that should make it compete with a "real" civ game. I'm glad I own Clash of Cultures. Expect me to be evangelizing for the foreseeable future.

TtA feels more like a VERY LONG game of 7 wonders. You "build" your empire with cards representing various "engine pieces" and try to manipulate the cards your enemies have access to while putting together the most powerful combos you have access to. Thinking of it that way, 7 wonders is a masterpiece* -- it's the very essence of an epic strategy game distilled down to 20 minutes and 21 deliberate decisions. There's really not anything more to TtA than that except a Vlaada math puzzle accompanying each decision and a [usually] free option to pick on the player that is probably already in last place. *Note that this comment is not meant to be a dig on 7 wonders. Its a great game for which my opinion has only been raised by my exposure to TtA.

I want to play TtA again, but wow, I don't think it deserves the lofty position it holds. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Tremendo. Tremendo. Quiero más!!!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Brilliant monster of a game with fairly simple rules: the complexity and interest is in the dynamics and the "data" (to use Donald X. Vaccarino's divisions). On the other hand, it's highly abstracted -- civilization qua spreadsheet -- and there's a lot of fiddliness and too much downtime with more players. It's definitely not one to get out with slow friends.

It's the kind of game where I don't like to use the word "strategy", which seems like a bombastic description for the kind of constrained micro-optimizations you get to make, within the serious constraints imposed by the system. The requirement not to ignore the military lest war cut you down to size is realistic but limiting, and irritatingly dependent on drawing the correct cards in order to initiate aggression. The lack of interesting interactions with other players is especially sad -- no trading, no negotiation (unless in an extralegal tabletalk sense), just comparing one player's subtotal in column A with the other's.

But, seemingly despite itself, it's an engaging, deep game, with a good arc and a strong feeling of progress.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
1 play, with 4 players.  I had not played this before, but everyone else had played several times before.  I agree with the polls in that this is likely better with 2 or 3 players.  It was dreadfully long and the down time between turns was too much for me.

I didn't like that you are strongly encouraged to pick on the weakest military person at all times with the military cards.  There is no reward for going after a stronger opponent and no downside to picking someone weaker.  This leads to "let's all gang up on the person in last" which is what happened to me, as it was my first game and I didn't grasp everything until about half way through.  That's something I strongly dislike in any board game.  Another player said this had happened to him before, so I don't think this experience was a fluke.

The second half of the game was brutal for me, because I had clearly missed some of the civilization areas that didn't seem to serve a purpose early on.  If you don't know this ahead of time, you're pretty much boned half way through the second age and especially by the third.  That's my fault, and I can forgive the first time learning experience, but I wouldn't plan on being able to catch up once your in last, especially with the gang-up factor from lacking in military.  You can't discard from your hand, so I was sitting there with cards that I planned poorly and there was NOTHING I could do about it!  I spent the second half of the game only using about half my civil actions because there was nothing left I could do.  Talk about unforgiving!  It definitely seems like the kind of game where the person in last is going to stay in last most of the game.  There's even a rule in the manual for how to quit honorably.  The mere existence of that rule tells me a lot about the game itself.

Also I didn't get any of the "bonus defense/colonization" cards until more than half way through.  Not a single one.  That seemed to have a dramatic bonus effect for those that did get these cards.

I'd play it again to give it a better shake, but definitely not with four people.  I don't think I'd ever enjoy this game enough to play for that amount of time again.  Even discounting the first time factor, I had enough problems with it to form the opinion that this this game wasn't designed very well.  Another silly thing: the cubes are way too large to fit in ANY of the scoring tracks.  How is this overlooked during play testing?

I don't think I had a worst first time play with a highly-ranked game since Brass, which is a terrible mis-mash of rules that don't make sense, shoe-horned loosely into a theme.

RATING: 7.5
[FRED Distribution 08 2nd (first printing) edition with fix pack] {Civilization; drafting, action-point, fighting, development, bidding; scalable} {Basic 6.5, Advanced 7.5, Full 7.5} Through the Ages is basically an Euro game with a civilization theme.  Players are essentially building a scoring engine with heavy resources management.  It is great that its theme and its mechanics integrate seamlessly and player could actually 'immerse' into the game.  TtA is multifaceted but I am concerned that possible strategies are driven by the card draw, even though a player have good flexibility to adjust his actions in the game. 

The basic game is good for beginners to learn the game, but it's too short with limited interaction and tactical decisions.  The Advanced and Full game are the only way to enjoy this game fully.

The production quality is only average.  The wooden discs are too small.  Cards and player boards are small, too.  There should be illustration for the pact cards.  I am disappointed with the production errors of the FRED edition, even though they release a fix kit.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Now this is a fantastic civilization game! It's essentially a card game with a board for book- and scorekeeping, but this is no run-of-the-mill card game. Holy sh... this is awesome! Players build their civs through three ages with the leaders of previous eras dying off with each new age. Tech trees are tracked with cards and small glass beads identify those cards that are currently active. Players must feed their populations, uncover brilliant innovations, discover new territories , build monuments, plan for possible military action, maintain the overall happiness of your people and more.

Until very familiar with the rules, plan on at least 1.5 hours playing time per player. My first game was with 3 players (myself the only newbie, using the full rules) and it took around 4 hours. My second game with 3 (first time for the other 2) took about 5.5 hours.

And while very thematic, this is a game of efficiency and engine-building, not tactical conquest. War and the threat of general aggression are part of the equation, but not the primary focus. Politics and economics, science and art... each plays an equally important role in the growth of your civilization. Just plain "wow".

Last played : May 2010

RATING: 6.3

I think this is too long for what the game offers.
Upgraded my rating to 7 nevertheless, after having seen the full impact of the game in Age III.

Another update after more plays on boardgamearena:
There is a lot of randomness in drawing the right military cards at the right time. You can spend many turns being the strongest military but never drawing an aggression or war card.

RATING: 5
UPDATE 10-13-10: Tried it again. I find it difficult to find anything bad to say about the game when it's actually my turn. Well, okay it's fiddly as hell -- that's one bad thing. But the systems are well-thought-out and there are some neat ideas here.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Wow...I wouldn't have thought this game could have been designed.  Beautiful, impressive game.  Really fabulous port of Sid Meier's Civ to boardgame form.

A couple of points of issue:  first, I'm not sure the leader mechanic works as well as I'd like.  It seems like Napoleon and James Cook have an disproportionate impact on the game relative to the cost to obtain and play them, but maybe that's just a function of the combinations I've seen.

Second, the military mechanisms are kind of orthogonal to the main play, which feels "right" but also creates some of the usual multiplayer issues which you hope to avoid in a long game--e.g. a nation has to pick which opponent to strip 40 culture from in a war.

Third, many of the late-game wonders don't seem to offer returns equal to their costs.  15 rocks to get a 1-off 10 culture seems pretty weak except in the very last turn.  It seems a bit of a shame that so many of these fly by and are never seriously considered.

But these are all nits.  The game is a marvel.  One of the best "epic" boardgames I've ever played.

RATING: 9
This game is really great.  There's only about 8-10 turns per age so you definitely don't have time to do everything you want to.  The pace of each individual turn does seem a little slow and every turn there are tough decisions about what to do and what to wait to do.  
I was expecting to dislike the military conflict in the game, but I think it's a great part of the game, it's mostly a deterrent and an arms race rather than a means of winning. I assume that the dynamic changes in the full game with the addition of wars, but I still don't expect that many wars to get played.
Michelangelo does seem a bit strong in the advanced game.  Yes he was drafted for extra actions, yes you miss out on an age two leader, and on some other great benefit from a different age one leader, but even with only 2 happy faces, if you keep him until the end of the game it's 2-4 actions for ~18-34 points.  As an opponent I really don't think I can make up even 18 points in 4 actions. 2008/06/13

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Uhhh, what a game! So many choices, so many possibilities. I played TtA more than 100 times and I'm not bored at all. The game is not heavy, but rather very deep, and a novice probably has no chances to win. But, personally, I have a huge pleasure of each play, even if I'm loosing. The feeling that I'm building the whole civilisation is impressive. Wonder, leaders, technologies - the PC original game (by Sid Meier) was perfect, but Chvatil made a huge job creating something even better: now, I can enjoy the game with my friends, not with a computer. The game is clearly more tactical than strategic: during each move, you need to consider your position once more time and adapt to the current situation (cards, opponents). 

I see two main things that made this game so delicious: the perfect system of many complicated elements that create the game and, secondly, the theme. I don't like typical euro-games (buy some cubes, move them from a card to another card, change your cubes to more powerful cubes of different colour), but in TtA you can feel how your civilisation is evolving, growing, breathing...

The queen of games.

Number of plays: about 124.

RATING: 9.5
Played this game one time and found found it an absolute joy! Keeps the brain constantly churning and it constantly gave me a fun buzz when I'd spot possible card combos and ways to play better and more efficiently the next time around. The game is kept tense by the need to keep up on the military track while you also need to keep an eye on your general strategy.

Currently the only thing preventing this from getting a 10 from me would be the components, which could have been higher quality material(and have larger graphics/tokens) given the price of the game
and the various tracks on the main board could have more readable graphics (why don't all the tiles on the tracks have numbers on them, for instance). This is a minor flaw, though given how fun this game is for me. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
THEME. I found this to be insanely pretentious to think that people would want to play this for 8 hours, which is my best guess on time but I only joined in after this game started. One has to either fool oneself into thinking this has any connection to history or you just love this bean counter stuff. 
EROGONOMICS: You move little markers to keep track of your military your culture and your economy or something. which is the kind of thing that drives me daft but I guess it's acceptable for this sort of thing. The cards are really too many to keep track of and most of them seemed to be useless but maybe I just didnt get it.
STRATEGY: I guess there must be some. You should innquire before you begin a game as to whether warfare is on the agenda [RED FLAG HERE] 

NARRATIVE: THere must be some although it felt so damn abstract to me I didnt buy whatever it was. Da Vinci emerging as your own nations' version of Napoleon is cute in a way. 
DRAMA: Again almost devoid of drama in a game about world history! 
BRAIN ENGAGE: You do this for 8 hours so you can imagine if this is not your cup of tea this will be awful. Obviously some people like doing this, it's like these are people left over from the 70s or 80s who actually still play games like this. If they enjoy it then God bless them. It's not for me. I think it bears repeating if you like this all day monster game stuff, you probably will like it as the play is pretty seamless and I did not recall many rules issues.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
As with other games of the same designer: I really find that it has amazing ideas but also some important issues.

Bad things:

- The game is heavy, the rulebook is really horribly organized and different skilled players can't really play together.

- Most important problem: A player can (by the rules) abandon the game when someone attacks him. At the end, this provokes that this player (usually a player that would lose anyway) has to arbitrary decide the winner of the game.

- The game is very aggressive. I mean, if you're losing, you get attacked and attacked and attacked. No fun in that.

- It's a really strategic game, but luck may be a key factor. It isn't strange to see a player lose because he simply didn't draw any good tactic.

All in all, it is a really novel game, very different from anything else. If you can forgive the obvious design issues it has, it is an amazing game. However, you may also hate it for its issues.

K: 9 -> 6 (czas rozgrywki)

I love thinking what to do this time. So many different paths to take. While you have to do a bit of everything to develop your civilization, you can still focus on something. I seem to like games where I get to decide what to get for myself, in this case what cards to pick up from the board.

RATING: 5.5
Hey, it is very much like the classic Sid Meier game Civ - but on your table. Lots of the same conundrums - balancing keeping your people fed while trying to maximize technology and advancements. Of course, you can't get it all and in fact, you barely get any of it.

After nine plays, I'm dropping my rating - a lot. This is a fun game as I described, but it has a serious rich-get-richer mechanism and zero way for you to catch up. Once you fall behind, you are not going to win and likely to get beat up on the rest of the way. That's not so bad in a short game, but this is not a short game.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I liked so much about the game.  The tableau building was satisfying, the resource management was well done, and I liked how elegantly the cubes were used to represent people and resources.  As with all civilization games, military and science are critical, and it does both nicely.  There are definitely advantages to pursuing military, but you can't get wiped out if you don't.  Science is also pretty interesting, even though there isn't really a tech tree.  

One of my favorite aspects was the event stack.  Each turn you can play an event, but it goes face down into the "future events" stack, then you instead play a card from the current events.  When the current events run out, the future events get shuffled and become the current events.  So, you have influence on which events come out, but it is a delayed effect and you never know when exactly it will trigger.

Everything about the game is really well designed and implemented.  Vlaada just continues to amaze me with his depth.  Now, I just need to try out the new version!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I have quickly fallen in love with this game.  Long?  Yeah, I suppose, but it is so deep with intertwined parts I overlook the length of play.

This has become my absolute favorite game.  I got it in a BGG trade and am so glad I did.

RATING: 9
I know it shouldn't, but wars are bothering me in this game. I really like the civilization aspect of this game: raise your culture, give people food and happiness, build better temples, theatres and advance technologically. But there's always someone on the table who doesn't think this is the best part of the game; instead he starts a full-scale war and bombards me into oblivion since you can't do both, civ-building and building an army. And this makes me dislike the game.

I really want to like this game and I like everything else about it, other than warfare, but I've been disappointed game after game. And this is a even bigger problem with more than two players since the other players can continue his building and has time to enlarge his army and defence while I'm being whacked. Considering this is a two-hour (or three) effort, it's frustrating.

Maybe I should try the "no wars" -variant.

Edit: This hasn't seen any plays in two years. Problem might be that I prefer this with two players and as a two-player this is a tad long. I sold my copy to a man who needed it more desperately than I did. 

Edit: I've been thinking this a game A LOT recently, it's got a stellar civ building mechanic. I'll be getting it again. And this time I will play only with Peaceful Variant. No wars or aggressions anymore.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Longish and fiddly in some respects, this is still a riveting game. There is some downtime, but if players work at it, it CAN move fairly briskly. I wouldn't play with more than three players. Have played the two-age game several time, both as a two-player and three-player game. While these have been pretty long games, I've ended each one thinking that my development 'engine' was just getting set up, and each time I was curious how my setup would have performed in the third age of the full game. Gotta try that. Meanwhile, for the advanced game, my rating is an 8 with room for adjustment once I have a chance to play the full game. So far, I'd rate this as the best civilization-building game yet designed .. and there have been a lot of attempts. Update: Have now played the full game, and rating remains a solid 8. Often play the "peaceful" variant when playing with my wife, who enjoys building her civ but doesn't dig the conflict. There's still plenty of interaction and incentive to have a strong army even in the peaceful variant. Update ... continuted play tells me that this is a very tough game to master. I remain challenged and interested. Rating now a 9, and possibly headed to 10.

RATING: 10
TTA is everything I was hoping it would be. Great euro/resource management game that also is a civ game. Plays great in non-combat mode, which is how my wife and I play.

Even though the game has no map, etc. I still feel like I'm building a civilization that spans the ages. I guess I have a good imagination.

I wish the playing time were shorter, to better fit my lifestyle. However, that won't keep me from playing. Great, great game.

Interestingly, for me this game has the "just one more turn" addictiveness, like the PC game.

RATING: 8
Played 4 times now. Two simple games and two advanced games. While this is a very fiddly game with the bits and the removing of cards from the card display and then shifting the remainder down, the game is a streamlined version of Civilization that probably cannot get much better. Lots of food for thought in this game as many tactical decisions present themselves as one cannot always follow a full-on pre-conceived game strategy since the cards can pass through the board very quickly. Definitely interested in seeing how the full game plays out, but until we can get the 3-player advanced game down to 3 hours, we will be sticking with the advanced. I purchased the game at Funagain's fall 2009 sale for $36, but that is probably still too much for what you get in the box. Sure, the game is solid, but it commands too high of a premium for what one gets.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
A thoroughly impressive design in which the numerous components somehow flow together seamlessly.   The best economic engine (or, in this case, cultural engine) game that I've tried, largely because every aspect makes perfect sense within the civilization theme, and often in very clever ways (i.e., corruption).  Maybe the best strategy game I've tried for 3 players.

There are a few negatives, though: the rulebook is terrible for anyone who wants to start off with the full game and is not useful for referencing specific rules; the tiny round tokens are finnicky to handle; it's sometimes easy to miss changing your sliders, so almost constant audits are necessary; the game can take a really long time with more than 2 players, especially if any lack experience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Probably the most preliminary rating I've ever given as I'm just through one session of the simple game. True, there is lots of calculating in this game. True, it is multiplayer solitaire. But it feels right! It feels like a building up a civilization. The cards match, the mechanics are great. It took me a long time before I got a chance of playing this, hopefully the next level won't take that long.  

Finally we got the advanced game in. Do your math! Since it is so much on the math, I hate to say that TtA won't exceed a 7.5 for me. And that's with a lot of benevolence, since I like the feel of the game.

RATING: 9
A big crazy beautiful beast!  We've now tackled the full game -- subsequent plays should be a little faster.  Right now this requires a very dedicated group and a LOT of time.

But in truth, doesn't matter.  It does what a good Civ game should: makes time vanish in the blink of an eye and makes you sad to win, because now it's over.  We've just started to get to know each other, so maybe I'm still in the infatuation stage, but I love everything about this game.

Edit: OK, time matters.  If you screw up and find yourself out of contention, playing it out is frustrating.  The "leaving honorably" rule goes against my sense of gamer etiquette.

Further edit: With experienced players this is now very doable at a pace of about one hour per player.  I've done a 2p game in under two hours and that qualifies it for a ratings bump.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Probably one of my favorite games. Long play time (approx. 4 hours) and lack of winning be damned. Every time I play, I feel like I've learned something new, and if not for the alcohol I could probably win a game of this (or at least not come last).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

2-4
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
It can be hard to remember a lot of the smaller rules all the time, but a good game when you want to play something with some real weight. Building up your civilization throughout the game feels really rewarding. Plays great with 2 players.

Update: I never get to play this because of the length and the amount of time it takes to re-learn it every game, so I'm glad that we now have Nations. Nations is basically just a streamlined version of TtA that makes the rules much simpler and the gameplay more fluid. Will be selling this in favor or Nations.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game is one of a very few games of its length where I can look down at the board and look up right after and three hours have passed. There's a certain momentum to play - each move impels you to make certain others, and the consequences of your actions are long-lasting. Like Agricola, you feel like you never have time to do everything you want to do. And like Agricola, the sense of accomplishment is very satisfying.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I want this game! 

UPDATE:: I have this game! My only concern is that it will collect dust as most of those I game with are intimidated by a lengthy game. I wish I could change their ways so they understood that great satisfaction comes from a game with depth, and that often means a bit of length.

UPDATE: Played my first game yesterday. I had to meet up with a stranger! He wasn't the greatest teacher ever, but we worked through it and fortunately, I had spent a lot of time trying to figure out the rules myself. The only issue was that I had planned for the simple game and he wouldn't play it. He wanted to play the full game--we compromised by playing the advanced game. So I had no idea how military worked or political actions worked. It took me the better part of the game--scratch that--the whole game to figure it out. I probably still don't totally understand what was going on. This is a deep game and it takes a while to understand it. But I can see how playing it a few more times will get me hooked. I'll hold off on rating it until I get at least one more session.

UPDATE: I got my second play with my wife last week. She really struggles with learning long, complex games. She was a sport to try, but I definitely call my effort a failed one. :( However, I've become very familiar with the online interface at boardgaming-online.com. So I've been able to get my fix there. The game is brilliant. I sum it up with one word: hard. It's hard to build your civilization. It's hard to balance your strategies. It's hard to become weak in any aspect of the game. It's hard to imagine a game of this complexity come together so well. But most of all, it's hard to stop playing. If you have the abundant time, the proper opponent, the desire for complexity, and the money to spend on this game, get it and love it.

I'm finally giving it a rating after a lot of time and patience spent in getting to a place where I can give it a proper analysis: 9.5. Its length and difficulty to learn are the only things keeping it from a perfect 10.

UPDATE: I've bumped my rating from 9.5 to a 9. Lately, I'm noticing that the two-player game is rarely close. By about the middle of Age III, I can usually see who's going to come out on top and it's rare that the difference is less than 50 points.

I've now played 16 games online. Usually, I don't count online plays in my playcount, but this game is so long that I think I'm justified to do so. Plus, it still feels like a boardgame. The site has done an excellent job with the interface.

I've only played one three-player game and it finished much closer. I'm in the process of two others now, and they both seem more balanced also. So I'm beginning to think that the three-player game is better than the two-player game. I'll update upon more 3P games.

UPDATE: Now up to 25 in my playcount and the majority of the last 10 or so have been three-player. I'm bumping it back up to a 9.5 because of the positive interaction added to the game solely from the pact cards. In a two-player game, the only interaction is aggressive interaction. The pact cards add a twist of brilliance. They're probably my favorite aspect of the game currently.

What I've noticed about TtA is that the more I play it, the more I want to dig and discover...and I can see the well is far from dry. It is brilliant.

UPDATE: This is my current favorite game. And it has been for several months now. It just doesn't get old. It's the most satisfying gaming experience I know. It is my precious. I'm bumping my rating up to a 9.75. It's going to take a very good game to dethrone this one. And my guess is if it happens, it will probably be from the same designer. Vlaada is king.

::UPDATE::
10/14/13 - Still my favorite game after approximately 180 games. It's just so deep and delicious. I wish all gamers (especially my wife) knew how to play this game so I could play it with everyone. It's currently rated a 9.8. If my wife liked it, I'd rate it the perfect 10.

[COLOR=#FFFFFF]TAGS: favorites, civ-building, city building, card row, long, epic, resource management, thin rectangle box, complex, 2-4 players, action-point allowance, economic, hand management, conflict[/COLOR]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The game is very well designed and the mechanisms all interact very very nicely.

Overall the rule set is quite minimal and the depth to complexity ratio is quite good, you get a lot of game to chew on without needing to focus a lot on looking up rules.

The only downside is the length of the game, it is quite long.  Even if you played at a rabid pace I can't see a 2 player game getting finished in much under 2.5 hours and with 3-4 player you are probably pushing 4-4+ hours for the full game.  

You can speed up the game with an assembly line like structure for the maintenance round but that can also make the experienced feel rushed.  Due to this and due to the fact that this game definitely results in players "rolling back" their half completed turns frequently it is probably best played on an App...and that makes me sad to admit.

The new version gets a slight bump over the old, the components are nicer, the play is slightly streamlined, the Military aspect is tamed slightly and the cards have 10+ years of balance, however the box footprint is at least doubled...which may irk some.

In short very good game, but can be quite long and fiddly.  I'd probably never shoot down a 3 player game of this but it might also be hard to find the other 2 players considering the time commitment.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
An epic civilization game.

This game's sense of accomplishment is great, and the interaction is also stellar thanks to the arms race which is very well implemented. The core economy is fun and deep though also a bit fiddly. There are tough decisions, and both strategy and tactics play a big role. Luck is minimum (only card draw) and overall, the best player will win with rare exceptions.

There is only one major flaw to this game, and that is downtime. In practice, I suggest this game with exactly 3 players, unless you have a highly trained group of 4. Even with 3, downtime is an issue, though not so big.

I'd rate this game higher but for the downtime. Still, it's a very enjoyable experience.

Update: Having played Nations, a clearly superior game that scratches the exact same itches in my opinion, my desire to play Through the Ages has greatly diminished and my updated rating reflects just that.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I've tried Through the Ages four times so far, twice with 2 players, once with 3 players, and once with 4 players, and it's a game that I really want to like.  Actually it's a game that I really want to love.  I could see it being my favorite game of all-time in a parallel universe.  In a universe where I only owned a few games and played Through the Ages a lot and was able to both explore its depth/replayability and get past its fiddlyness.  But unfortunately I don't live in that universe and I'm stuck evaluating Through the Ages based on my experiences with it up until this point, which have been lukewarm at best.  As a huge fan of Sid Meier's Civilization computer games, I wanted to fall in love with this board game, which shares so much in common with those computer games (especially because the designer of Through the Ages, Vladimir Chvatil, came up with the brilliant idea of doing away with the map in a civilization game to make it playable in a reasonable amount of time, which isn't an idea that I could have possibly conceived as working before trying it out in practice).  However, I just didn't love the experience, and found it too fiddly, the cards potentially unbalanced, and the downtime between turns to be excruciating.  I'd probably be willing to give it another chance and play it for a fourth time, but for now I'm happy to cross it off my list of games to consider purchasing.

Received as gift: Christmas 2009

RATING: 9
M
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[thing=25613][/thing] is a civilization game that is basically made of cards and some tokens. The games takes you from Age A, I, II and III, making your civilization pass through leaders, new political orders, technologies and developments regarding: farms, mines, arena, labs, libraries, temples, theaters and military - these are general names, don't take them to the letter (like, journalism is a library development, cavalry and infantry are of the same level give the same bonus, and such). The winner is the player with the most culture by the end of the game, but during the game you will have to manage other things as well: food, resources, army, hapiness, population and ideas (is with ideas that you "discover" new techs, new political orders, enhanced military units, and so on). Everything is important, and you can use them in different ways to achieve the same goal (more culture).

A player turn has two phases: event phase and action phase. In the event phase you can start wars, agressions and treaties towards the others civilizations, and also you can play events, that will trigger latter, and thus you can prepare for it. In the action phase you use the avaiable actions to increase population, discover techs, put people to work, build wonders, put a leader in play, and other things.

The game doesn't fell as a civilization game to me. Maybe I'm too visual person, but the lack of a board, miniatures, or tokens representing the armies, the new colonies, take away the sense of place, distance, size and quantity. I can't see and army closing in. I don't attack a given place, I just... attack the whole civilization, not a region, nor an important city. [thing=25613][/thing] is way more abstract than I like my civilization games.

Also, more often than not, the game will be basically an arms race, in which the players try to build the biggest military might in order to beat someone else. And, as the game works, many times the one to be crushed won't be the leader. Will be the one with the weakest army, and this can (or can't) be the leader, but it won't matter all that much. And, then, things can go to the "bullying" side, because, if someone attacks you, and you defend (using cards and sacrificing units), you open your civilization for an attack of the next player, and again, for the next (considering a 4 players games, in wich the next player after you attacks you), with you getting weaker everytime (and, thus, making even better to attack you). I really do not like this aspect of the game.

So, [thing=25613][/thing] is a solid game, for sure, but not one that fits right with me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The "simple" game: Obviously for learners. It does play fast and isn't very fiddly. Interaction is nearly nonexistent though. You buy cards from a market, but the market refreshes so quickly (no stagnation problem here!) that it lessens the feeling that you're actually drawing from a common pool. While painless, managing your civ/economy is not particularly interesting.

...The full/advanced game is a different beast. It took awhile for the flow of the turns to feel natural (the player aid is quite helpful) but eventually TtA gave me the same "just one more turn" feeling that Graenaland did; I may need to look closely at Chvatil's other games.

It [i]is[/i] basically another economic bottleneck/snowball game (which I initially found annoying), but as in Graenaland there's a varying menu of things to do on a given turn, and you can't do all of them, they have different effects, more than one way of doing things seems like it may work, and the variation in options doesn't feel arbitrary or unexpected or chaotic.

The player interaction is a bit odd. The card market functions very well but doesn't feel like the heart of the game (moving bits around on the player boards does) and doesn't feel like a major source of interaction (partly because of the speed of regeneration of the market and partly because it usually doesn't seem worth it to buy any but the cheapest cards).

The interaction largely comes from the literal arms race of the "strength" metric (like a complicated version of what 7 Wonders has). A player lagging in strength can get beat up badly with no consolation prize. The main thing that moderates this is that strength is also used as a bidding currency to get territories, so that a strong player will probably try to convert as much strength advantage as he can into the territories and their perks.

TtA has even less of a sense of "location" than 7 Wonders. I'm quite OK with not having a map (mostly because maps tend to bring their own annoying issues in multiplayer games), but I feel like the game would feel a bit less abstract if there had been some nod to the fact that civilizations don't just all start out next to each other.

...Having now played a "full" game (all three ages) I have a couple extra thoughts. I'm disappointed that (despite being a civ-themed game) the game doesn't really have a different feel from age to age. The numbers get bigger but the gameplay doesn't feel qualitatively different. I think this makes the game feel too long and less "epic."

Secondly, I can't wrap my mind around how the player interaction is supposed to work. You can play cards to add to your defense but not to your offense, meaning your inherent strength needs to be substantially superior to your prey's to attack them. But it seemed to me that it was generally far too expensive to build a large military.

The whole package [i.e. after playing a game] leaves me with the unpleasant feeling of "that was pretty interesting to play, but I don't want to play it again for some time." (I think I had the same feeling from Graenaland actually, except I like that one a bit better.) I could see this being fun with a solitaire variant, if someone has made one.

...Revisiting: Actually, the MPS logistics puzzle of managing the bottlenecks of your economy seems to be the most interesting part of the game. The uncertainties of the card market and the player interaction might even be net detriments to the game's quality, though I could well be wrong about that (meaning: surely these forms of interference add interest to the logistics, and reduce calculability, as beyond your current turn you can't be sure what will happen).

Lautapelit's Nations is actually quite different. The MPS economic logistics are much simpler and you don't have a set of uninterrupted moves to juggle at one time. The player interaction is central to the interest and needs to carry the game.

Another noteworthy mechanism of TtA is the event seeding, where the game bribes you to schedule events to occur at some random point in the future. It's an interesting middle ground between giving players direct control over firing off events (which is typically unthematic) and having the events occur at random (which can be too capricious in a strategy game).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
The game mechanic is interesting but the components are too small for my liking. 

There are various areas which the players have to manage. I like the idea of being able to use the number of actions to obtain cards. The cost of obtaining the cards will get cheaper if they are not taken by players. There are trade off between paying a higher cost for a desired card (e.g. leader, technologies, military, wonder etc) or waiting for the cost to reduce but risk losing it to the opponents. 

Players constantly need to strike a balance between the food, resources and technology required for upgrading in their race for the most culture points.
