=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
A fiddly but interesting stab at a Civ game that keeps things manageable by removing the board and replacing it with card drafting for a common focus and interaction source.

The designer successfully dealt with one of the major problems with Civ games, beat-on-the-(perceived)-leader via military.

Unfortunately, his solution often results in beat-on-the-loser being the correct ploy, where the loser sometimes has ignored military too long (I'm ok with beat on the loser in this case), but all too often has simply been unlucky in the order of how cards appeared.

Further, if this happens (which is over half the time in our group, which may be aggressive), it's typically only 1/3 of the way in the game and it results in one player being completely out of the running.  From then on, the correct tactic is often to keep on whomping on this poor player.  

It ain't pretty watching people apologize to someone -- who is just playing to keep the game going -- before they beat him up another time.

Any game that encourages beat-on-the-loser as a central tactic is not for me. I don't enjoy either side of that. Bleah!

(I don't know whether the new edition has addressed this problem or not.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

loooooooooong game. but good.

Has the flaw that since there are fewer upgrade cards in each age for mines than there are players, a player can get stuck behind by missing the 1st age iorn mine and is really out of luck if the coal mine, 2nd age, appears late in the age.  Making a player continue with little chance of doing well just for this reason seems like a bad idea.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Initial rating/feeling after one game (short game): 6. Oh man this game is fiddly...

updated rating after second (full) game: 6-->7. It has its good parts, for sure. However, in the end, it feels quite abstracted and restrictive. I'm not sure I like the randomness related to the events and card when combined with very restrictive mechanics (like that there is very little you can do, if you don't have say enough materials or food). For example, I don't think it is very intuitive that if you happen to end in a situation where you produce too much food, it will eat you alive as you cannot produce hardly any metal (due to corruption)... to cure the mess, you need to do quite convoluted steps. There isn't too much flexibility in the game, which I kind of miss (for such a long and complicated game, where it is easy to screw yourself and the luck plays its part too). And of course its long and complicated game with lots of rules and details you need to remember.

But despite my ramblings, obviously it is good and clever game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is THE civilization game and is proof that not all civilization games require a map!

The story arc is beautiful, and the gameplay is fantastic. It's an engine builder with resource and card management. Changing strategies on the fly can be difficult but it's something that I personally don't mind and find thematic.

2 players is arguably a little wonky due to the strong emphasis on military (although I admit that I'm always trying to get away with as little military as possible). I'm definitely looking forward to playing it with 3 players which hopefully alleviates the issues.

I upgraded the components immediately with the cubes that you can purchase from the Geekstore and can only begin to imagine how painful it would be to play with little cylinders which roll straight off the table!

Waiting for the updated version so I can add this back into my collection!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

There's a little bit of luck involved with what cards are available and what's drawn which keeps the game fresh. Ultimately, your destiny is chosen by you.

RATING: 7
Essen 06 Radar.  This is a great game with a really good sense of development.  I played the advanced (but not full) game.  Some card combinations might be overly powerful, but I hope it gets a few teaks before the rumored full production run (finger crossed).  My opinion of the game is higher than my rating would indicate simply because the length would prevent me from wanting to play it too often.  I haven't played Civilization, so Parthenon is actually the closest relative to this game that I have played.  They both have a similar feeling of growth and progression, but while Parthenon is very symmetrical and growth is more limited, the selection of cards makes this much more free form and open ended.  That also means is has the potential to be unbalanced, but that didn't happen in our game.

RATING: 7

This one emphasizes a need for a bit of everything with a loss in momentum if any one area is overlooked for too long.  This causes much of early game specialization to be focused on allowing a player to ignore that area for a little while rather than fully develop it to its maximum first.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game fell far off from my expectations. Unnecessarily complex and aggressions that completely obliterate others. I sometimes get hate feelings toward games on my first plays but this one really took the prize. However, there is some weird pull of the good kind here, mostly from the complex mechanics. But these complex mechanics make me not want to play it any other way than on the computer due to the massive bookkeeping hassle.

The obligatory comparison to Nations is unavoidable, this game is a lot more versatile but also a lot more complex, where Nations is streamlined and "friendly", TtA is brutal and user-hostile.

+/-Versatile and good game mechanics that are sadly a bit complex and the overall design is user-hostile in that there are too many tiny different fiddly rules to keep in mind.

-Military, impossible to rise once you start taking a beating every turn. This is among the worst implementation of wars I have seen in any game. Here you actually lose and you never rise because others can simply keep milking the weakest unless they start wanting to sabotage their competition instead of the easy prey, however that would leave them open to failing their aggressions, so kicking the decked one is the best choice mostly. Going with the non-aggro version might be more my cup of tea, but after a try with this I don't see this solving all the problems either.

RATING: 9.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Very good civilisation game, long, quiet complex and involving. A lot of similarities with Nations (that came out later but I played earlier and much more than TTA), so of I compare them. 
I give the edge to Nations, because I love the asymetric factions and the streamlined resource management (fewer fiddly moving parts); nations also has an excellent handicap mechanism to allow playing with new players without crushing them. I also feel than nations is more replayable and has more diversity (in terms of wonders, leaders, etc.), I would love to try with the expansion.

[+] Solid engine building game, frustrating in a good way (you never have enough either actions, or resources, or science, etc. to do everything you want), the military aspects can be intimidating but it's hard to really crush someone (unless multiple player gang on the leader, which could happen, best to stay in second place as long as you can ;)), I like that all events are triggered at the end, it creates a big points swing but you can plan for part of it (the ones you contributed);
[-] very fiddly with moving blue resources back and forth, loooong game (the shorter versions are not worth playing), the randomness of the military cards (can be frustrating to be the strongest nation and draw a bunch of defense cards, or the opposite) maybe having them in a second card row would be better (bought with military actions);  I like the Pacts but there are too few of them, same for military tactics, it's cool but so dependant of the card draw

got in MathTrade nov16
sold feb17

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Very good looking "civ-light" game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Civ without a map sounds like heresy, but this works well.  This game is really the spiritual descendant of Civilization series for the PC, much more than a spiritual descendant of Tresham's [gameid=71] board game of the 80s.  

It's very well designed.  Every time you think you have your civilization functioning like a well oiled machine, it springs a leak and you realize that you have to improve your agriculture [i]right now[/i], or that your science levels are woefully low, or some other thing you didn't notice.  Sometimes you run into some really odd anachronisms, such as Leonardo da Vinci leading a theocracy, but for the most part it gels well.  

There's one big flaw, one that I just can't forgive, even after nearly 20 plays.  The Age III military strategy tends to swing the game wildly.  It turns something that's been a fun little game of developing your culture and science into a brutal militaristic punishing game.  It's punitive to the point that it can ruin the fun, and the end of the game is a tight-lipped grim march to the gallows rather than a triumphant race to the finish line.  Still, I'd forgive this if I didn't see it happen so often.  Experienced players know and anticipate this dynamic, but it takes the life out of the game for new players.  Time and again I've seen new players wilt when their big lead and weak military is confronted with an Age III War on Culture.  If military was more powerful in the earlier two ages, this wouldn't be as big of a deal, as new players would have more incentive to build military early and would know to ignore it at their own peril.  

Still, this game is tight and beautiful and one of the best Civ games out there.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
German edition by Pegasus
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Though it doesn't have a map or much of Sid Meier's dynamics, still the best civ adaption yet.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I was reluctant to like this at first as I felt the development arc was scripted, but with repeat plays I have seen a variety of fundamentally different viable approaches to the game (it helped to play with a couple different game groups to realize this). Through the Ages is really a great long heavy game that remains tense from beginning to end. The only negative thing I can say about it is the price, and the fact that there's probably too much downtime between turns with 4 players. With 3 this is pretty sweet though. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
It's hard to compare this game with another one, because it seems to do something that isn't found in other games.  There are a lot of rules that make the game beat you up from one turn to the next, sort of like Antiquity, but it's more easily managed than in that game.  The limitations of different parts of the game make you want to do more on any given turn than it's possible to do, which creates a nice tension from turn to turn, and since the game essentially forces you to pay attention to all possible strategies, at least to a certain extent, you're going to feel squeezed by the game.  It's really awesome. 

The game is ridiculously fiddly, and the rulebook seems to raise a lot of questions.  It really requires someone who knows the game well to teach it, because there are lots of things that players need to know from the start of the game, such as not neglecting their military strength.  Players who don't plan for this WILL LOSE.  Period.

The game works very well with 2 players, as well, which surprised me, considering the way the end of the first full game played out.  I can see why playing with 3 would be better (the pacts come in to play for one, and the cross-competition would make for more interesting choices), but I would gladly play this as a 2-player game, too.

This is very definitely a 9 game for me, even after only playing it 4 times.  There's just too much a player can do, and so many different strategies to play, that I can't imagine ever not wanting to play this game.

8 plays: 2 players (Full Game)
1 play: 3 players (Full Game, through Age I)
4 plays: 3 players (Full Game)

RATING: 8
Long to play but very satisfying.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
As a big fan of the Sid Meier's Civilization series of PC games, all I can do is shake my head in amazement. I am absolutely floored by Vlaada Chvátil's take on the classic franchise. Somehow this incredible design feels every bit as epic as the computer game, with a clever mechanic to represent almost every feature that makes the computer games so great. The way new discoveries appear and fly across the time line. The way the tokens interact with the player board to represent growth, stagnation, famine and corruption. The way territorial expansion really stretches your military thin but ratchets up your ability to grow again. It all just works so well. Even more remarkable is that it creates this wonderfully detailed civilization experience completely without a map! It truly is a stellar piece of game design.

There are only a couple of downsides to the game. One is that it almost does too good of a job portraying the original computer games. If you have never played any of Sid Meier's masterpieces, a lot of the more abstract concepts of Through the Ages may be difficult to wrap your head around. The rulebook is a bit of a chore as well, but in some ways I suppose that is to be expected from such a complex game. Finally, the price being charged for this game is absolutely ridiculous. Considering that the components are mostly cards and some small wooden cubes, I'd say the price is almost double what it should be. Yet the gameplay lurking inside that box is worth every penny. I can't get enough of it!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Maybe next weekend a 4th Full play and completing?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
There's a lot to like here. It's challenging and variable, tactical and strategic, and has loads of turn angst.  I'm not sold on the military system (draw luck, incentives to beat on the weak, the uselessness of aggressions and wars when everyone is--sensibly--keeping pace). I also wish there was some uncertainty about what's in the stacks, and not just about the timing.  So bring on an expansion!

But I know of few games that generate this kind of turn angst. I have a lot of little nits to pick with it, but it's freaking brilliant.

Most of my plays are via the nice interface at boardgamingonline, which has spoiled me. Much easier to play that way than in person. Plus it has some variant card sets (new leaders and wonders), so...hard to justify owning/playing the physical copy. Would rate BGO a 9, FTF a 6.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
There's a lot of things I really like about the game, but the point-at-one-person nature of wars and agression is something I can't stand. I think that is simply a design flaw. This is the main reason for my rating.

(btw this is based on one play, where I was the agressor, and won the game, but I almost didn't want to do it, but I said, okay let's play the game how it was designed. it seems it was designed for this, because I won)

There is also considerable luck with the cards, some of which is fixed by the new edition.
The game is also very long, which is understandable from a mechanisms viewpoint, but I'd just rather play two or three or ten other games. Also this length means that other than taking some interesting cards, you never really feel you did something big, but then again, just taking a card is not too interesting. I actually like the fiddly administration part of the game, but it never felt like it really mattered other than to not make mistakes there.

I guess I should try the simple game without agression.

edit: I did try the simple game. It's clearly not what the game was designed for, it's only maybe good for learning the rules. Didn't help my opinion.

RATING: 7.75

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
A Civ building game playable in 2-3 hours.

3-27-11 - Upgraded to a 10.  This is a game I look forward to playing time and time again.  

5-6-12 - Revised to a 4.  After playing this quite a bit, I have noticed a lot of flaws that have cropped up. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Wow...the box looks surprisingly small,  considering the hype and the MSRP.  Then again,   things always appear larger on the BGG I'm finding.Game is interesting - the bits are small (I guess I should have expected this from the box).  Maybe this is a trend from publishers - ItYotD was maybe 10-25% too smalle,  Through the Ages here could probably be double it's current size.  The size issue is mainly the tiny little cylinders that are tough to pick up and roll away when you drop them,  but there's also the mini-sized cards.  The Simple game seems like your standard engine building game - probably helps to know the deck,  and you convert resources into points.  The Advanced and Full game adds more interesting and more powerful cards...but all the pushing cubes around gets to be probably too much overhead by the end.  I'd also rather the whole thing took maybe a third of the time.   Growing on me a lot (well,  winning doesn't hurt).On the upside,  it feels surprisingly a lot like Civilization,  with happiness balanced with resource production.  You need to spend resources to have workers,  and then you assign them to various tasks.   Mostly seemless once you get going,  although the "worker spontaneously morphing into a building" bit got me confused for a while.  That part doesn't really make sense (why do my buildings mysteriously vanish when they're unoccupied)  but having more to track would probably make it fiddlier (and it doesn't really need that).Hmmm...I think I'm overly hard on this game just because I want to like it so much.  I keep thinking of ways of "how would I make it better",  or "how would I steal mechanics to add to another game".  Lots of good ideas,  but not quite there.  Actually,  a lot like Prophecy in that respect.I agree with Chris Farrell's assessment of the military subgame - the results are pretty much random,  and a lot of actions are spent "oh I'm behind a point,  now I need to get another one to not be behind" with the first person to be out of luck "taking it in the chin" - losing is just as bad when you're 1 military off than a whole lot.My biggest issue is that the game's solution to the compound interest problem is making the cards exponentially more powerful in the more advanced ages.   The Age III military technologies (and esp. tactics) are crazy powerful.   Those final wonders - buckets of points.  But unfortunately,  where they end up on the track is pretty much down to random luck...you can control it a tiny bit - 1 card position or so - but really - if the other person gets his stuff for cheap,  and you have to pay through the nose for yours,  you won't be a happy camper.

Makes me want to steal the ideas for my own game :)

Starting to see that this is not so much an engine-building game as it as an auction for the military - Age III military is so overwhelming that it's somewhat ridiculous.  It makes thematic sense of course,  but does mean that whoever "breaks" on that track will be out.  In some sense,  it's more about building war machines that happen to score points on the side - I guess I like the engine building bits more than the military bit,  so I'm biased,  but the engine is looking a bit like obfuscation rather than actual meaningful choices.  It is very expensive to redirect workers in this game...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Holy civilisations. This is an absolutely awesome game. As long as you put aside the time to play it and are not too tired to play then I think it is so good it almost makes you cry! So many things to do and approaches to take. Just so good.

RATING: 8

2. The publisher is working on an iOS version that would probably get played more
3. The publisher is also working on a 4th edition of the game with upgraded art that looks far superior to what's in the 3rd edition

RATING: 7
I tried so hard to like this game more. It's got civilization, development, resource management, technologies, the sweep of time, a good 2-player mode. But I get too frustrated by the limited power and slow development of civilizations, the intense emphasis on precise efficiency, and the interlocking limiting factors. The main intellectual activity is maximizing your 4-7 actions for efficiency. However, there are so many limiting factors, that you end up conducting the least bad options, and feeling frustrated that nothing is happening. Even with that, I still enjoy the game to some degree, mainly because of it's theme. About 7-10 plays.

RATING: 8
Excellent euro-style game for those who don't mind sitting down for a couple of hours and thinking/planning/ and definitely pushing some cubes around...all to build your 'civilization'.

I love how everything ties together in this game. Greater population = more production = more food required = more production upgrades required....and so on and so forth. Add to this the variety of special abilities afforded you because of your current leader, and add to that the ability to beat up your neighbor cause they might get more points and this all comes together in a flawless game. It's a civilization game for the thinking man.

I really enjoy this game. I do not do well yet, but I love a game where every decision I make is effective and all the moves I make have a real gaming purpose rather than being simply a visual to google over.

Terrific game. Period.

RATING: N/A
True story:

While I was out sick, my wife and teenage son - who only game "out of the house" a few times per year - were roped into a four-player learning game of TtA without being told that it would take forever.  Being too polite to quit, they gritted their teeth and rode the torture wagon for a full six hours before the game ended.

Did I mention that the inviter was a deadly slow player, and one of the most confusing game explainers that I know?

Horrified at the news when my family returned home, I took matters into my own hands and two men are now dead.  I don't feel the slightest bit of remorse, even though my cell block's wi-fi is unstable and my top bunk mattress is lumpy.

Let this be a lesson: Don't sucker people into playing your grossly long "favorite" game, particularly if a close relative has anger management issues and non-specific life goals.

RATING: 6
This is a great great game with a brilliant design . Still so, TtA is a constant struggle to obtain food, ore, happiness, culture, defend yourself, colonize... I mean, it's exhausting!!! And it has even given me headaches. (also, the components and the art are probably the worst I've ever seen)

Also, there's no catch up mechanism in this game at all, so usually there's always one player who won't enjoy the game and will be beaten to death repeatedly for 90~120 minutes straight. That's not fun at all in my opinion! It's a shame, I can see why people like it and I don't want to be unfair, it's just not for me.

RATING: 10
Incredibly well designed. I don't find the mechanics fiddly at all once people know what they're doing, and there's just so much interplay between the cards and the mechanics. I also think the notion that this is multi-player solitaire is nuts. The importance of keeping your military even or ahead of the other players, choosing when to spend 3 civil actions on a heavily-desired card, deciding whether or not to seed an event... What your opponents do has a tremendous impact on how you play the game, and I'm always watching and considering my opponents' choices. Apart from the steep learning curve, a simply incredible game, one of the best designs ever.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
( P - 2 [3] 4 }

Deep civ-building game that doesn't actually run long with experienced players. Three is our sweet spot.

Just describing the game is a beast. The game takes place over roughly 25 turns where players build their own civilizations by drafting cards from a shared pool and managing resources within their own kingdom. Culture is the victory point resource, but wars or aggressions between players can transfer culture to / away from a kingdom. So your final score is essentially how much culture you can create on your own plus how much culture you gain / lose from other players. Then players manage civil and military actions, science, food, energy, and several other supporting mechanics which help support everyone's bottom line - the culture engine.

The finesse in Through the Ages lies in understanding the interactions between those secondary elements. Over time, cards increase in power but also cost. So, for example, if you are deciding between Drama (2VP,1HF) or waiting for Opera (3VP,1HF), you are going to consider:

1) Can I afford the increased ore cost of Opera?
2) Can I put three people on Drama versus two on Opera and get near the same benefit for less ore, but more people?
3) Do I score more with Drama because I have to wait until Age 2 for Opera?

The core resources are ore and food. Spending food creates new people, and spending ore puts idle people to work either in military or civil service. Both resources contribute to your effectiveness - having all the food and ore you need lets you put the most people in the best positions - but you really never have all you need in every area, so it's a balancing act. Having more food and people but less ore incentivizes military because aggressions typically take ore from other players. Or, it makes cards like Shakespeare or Bach appealing because those leaders give benefits based on how many, not how much. Having fewer people and food but more ore incentivizes the creation of wonders and putting your people on the best possible spots, such as Journalism.

The secondary resources include civil and military actions, science, and political cards - mortar to the bricks of food and ore. There are six unique leaders every age that provide reductions in cost or benefits contingent on different parameters so every game plays differently and there is no one best strategy. You want to optimize but must also consider timing, synergy, and the capability of your opponents to interfere.

There are some clunker cards like Library of Alexandria or Bread and Circuses but the vast majority of cards are viable if you understand how they fit in to a larger picture. For reference here's a list of the game's all-stars:

Michelangelo
St. Peter's Basilica
Constitutional Monarchy
James Cook
Journalism
William Shakespeare
Air Force
Fast Food Chains

As far as flaws go there's clearly some luck involved, e.g. I have colonies is James Cook at the top or bottom of the deck, or I'm drawing three military cards per turn and can't find an A2 tactics. Air Force is borderline-broken and I wish there were a few more tactics in A2 instead of some of the junk pacts / greens.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
no room for improvement of the ranking here; this is a great game.  fun, complex, and longish.  lots of things to think about and do, not enough actions.  damn good.  the age cards give terrific thematic immersion, and the balance between military and civic improvements always keeps you thinking.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game has a very steep learning curve, so much so that the rules come with a recommendation to play the Simple and Advanced games first before progressing to the Full game. The rules, whilst easy to understand, are difficult to refer back to when my Significant Other and I encountered questions on numerous small issues during the game. It is perhaps best to have a experienced friend to guide you along. 

Once one understands and remembers the basic rules, this game is very challenging, engaging and replayable. The game mechanic and historical theme of this game is particularly enjoyable.

The design of the cards and tokens is the main negative. The illustrations are not very attractive, and the tokens used to represent population, resources and such are small uninspiring cylindrical tokens of different colours. These are small enough to make them slightly difficult to handle. Player interaction is also rather low, especially for two players.

Rating would be somewhat higher with better card designs and perhaps more attractive tokens. Or at least larger ones.

RATING: 7
If you like Sid Meier's Civ games you can't help but like this.  While I enjoy the map aspects of a full civ game the balancing act in TtA is a lot of fun and the escalation of abilities through technology cards and upgrading your civilization's abilities really give this a nice feel.  I've only played online using 'Boardgaming Online' and really enjoy the game's presentation in that format.  

As I play more I'm starting to dislike the conflict a bit though.  Its interesting to balance having enough military with your other needs, but if you lose the race you can get pounded right out of the game.  I don't like player elimination so that's a black mark against this game I'm increasingly not enjoying.

So this is still a game I respect... I'm just not sure how much more I actually want to play it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
What an engrossing and thoroughly satisfying experience!  Through the Ages left me wanting for another play after I was done with it.  However, even though there were a wide selection of cards, some were just overpowering compared to others, and there were ones that didn't seem particularly useful under any circumstances (almost like complete throw-aways and were just there to occupy spaces).  Also, while I think having the possibility of conflicts is an important aspect of a civlization game.  Everyone was so busy in building their own culture and avoiding confrontation that the war aspect of Through the Ages ended up feeling totally superfluous and unnecessary.  I assume this will change depending on who you play with.  Even so, I enjoyed my first play of this and would consider it a current favorite of mine as I look forward to exploring its potential further.

Update #1: A general lack of enthusiasm on my part to get into another game of Through the Ages has forced me to deduct a 0.5 point from my original score.  I even traded away the pre-order copy I had (mostly due to the poor production quality) and since haven't had the desire to acquire another one.  I still maintain that is is a very fine game and one that I appreciate immensely, but I also recognize that in order for something to age well, my desire to play it must remain high.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
There are many thing about this game not to like, but somehow I still do. On the surface, the design looks like endless bookkeeping with visual attractions varying from horrible to nonexistent. Like in all card games, some players get all the right the combos while others don't - or in the case of Through the Ages, lack exactly one action, food or resource to make them happen. It is very difficult, if not impossible, to do anything about a rival who takes a decisive lead.

Still, there are plenty of subtle of mechanisms to bring balance into the game. There is randomness, but it's manageable randomness. After Brass, the lack of visuals and eyecandy is not a big issue. The game keeps your mind occupied, when you constantly have to weigh decisions, their advantages and drawbacks. With different rulesets, you can play a shorter or a longer game. After severals hours of play, the gaming table doesn't look like that much has changed, but there's rarely a dull moment. There's always a new plan to make. Altogether quite an enjoyable gaming experience recommended for serious gamers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Long and fiddly. The last time I played this, I kept wishing I was playing Clash of Cultures instead.

RATING: 9

Finally an update, 2012:  Someone better than me taught my dumb ass this game, once and for all.  I don't "love" civilization games, but as far as they go this one is rather fantastic.  Once you learn the over-the-board version, just go play it online at boardgaming-online.com rather than fighting with all of those little pieces.  Could they have made them any worse??  I think spherical would be the only way to do so.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A game of thousand flaws from modern-gamer's perspective: a lot of downtime (or to put it differently - you need to enjoy looking at other players turns if you want to play this one), too long (4 hours for 2-player game if you are moderately experienced), fiddly (too small pieces and cards, lots of upkeep and mathematics at the end of your turn), but also a game of one unmatched virtue - it is the only real civ-builder with an epic feel (Nations does not come even remotely close, although mechanically it is a better game from modern gamer's perspective). It is also unparalleled engine-building game. 

Development of my thoughts:

Was very hard to memorize the rules at first so remained on the shelf unplayed for almost a year... But then...

Also got frustrated after playing Nations only because it has mechanics of one action per player - so it's more involved and faster, and not so much solo multiplayer as TtA where one has to wait a bit too long for his move. 

Otherwise I would still choose Tta for its depth and epic feel. With Nations I don't feel such a fulfillment when looking at my civilization at the end. 

Update 26th June 2015: Finally went through rules and played full game with spouse - rating adjusted accordingly (from 7 to 8). Faults are obvious: too much downtime and stressful bookkeeping - too much opportunities for error. We played full game through 3 evenings, which is way too long. 

BUT on the other hand it delivers: there is no other Civilization game like it, Nations doesn't come close for me because it lacks that epic feeling - it may be better game all in all, more developed in terms of play-ability, but TtA gives you the essence of civ management "Sid Meier's style". 

Another potential con, but only for game's reputation, is the lack of map and visual appeal. Once you get into it you realize however that Civilization was never actually about the map - there are other games that serve the purpose of "moving your pieces / area influence gaming", and TtA still has spatial aspects, territories and wars for them, just abstracted in (to me) still odd and hard to grasp Vlaada Chvatils mind (heck, I couldn't comprehend Dungeon Petz first time through - so it has to be my mind not resonating with this particular designer at first contact).

One thing I really admire is the one for which I also rate Twilight Struggle highly - that wonderful ability to capture historical flavor in such an abstract system. Leaders above all, but also fine details like how getting to communism by revolution is stimulated with very low science price comparing to other government technologies or how Robespierre influences revolutions or how Bach combines with theaters and so forth. Extraordinary.

Update: Traded away when New Story showed up. Decreased the rating accordingly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.25
Very abstract civilization game without a world map. You really can fantasize your civilization. Cards are a little bit to small as are the various wooden counters. The look of the game could be better, though it encourages you to use your imagination i guess. 

Gameplay has a lot of depth and good ideas to it. It's however a little bit fiddly and maybe not completely balanced.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
TtA is really neat if you've played Civ on the computer.  I can't imagine how awful this game would be to someone without that reference point.  Many mechanics are designed to simulate the game. You need to be able to visualize why certain mechanics are there or it seems like it would feel like overwhelming and meaningless token shuffling.  Even though it is a very fiddly game, I had a good time with it.  The game balance seems very good.  There are no cards which are useless.  Different strategies seem viable.
